Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to buy time and diffuse the situation by asking Person2 to wait for a moment.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and disbelief at Person1's denial of their previous interaction and demanding to speak to someone in charge.

Dialogue:
Person1: Take me down there.
Person2: It won't do any good. They are a pair of would-be mur- deresses fighting it out.
Person1: Man, you're crazy. What kind of a place is this?
Person2: Oh, I'm crazy, am I? Let me tell you something.  Those women have--the gleam--
Person1: Come on, we're wasting time.
Intent_p1: Person1 is dismissing Person2's warning about the dangerous situation and insisting on going down to the location.
Intent_p2: Person2 is warning Person1 about the dangerous situation involving two women fighting and implying that they should not get involved.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look here, Bob, Ever since I can remember, you've looked after me. Now I think you're the one that needs looking after. I'm your brother, Bob. If there's something wrong with you, let me help you.
Person2: Oh, George . . .
Person1: Besides, I - I don't feel like making that trip alone, Bob.
Person2: George, you couldn't possibly stay here, could you?
Person1: I'd go mad!
Person2: George, I may be wrong, I may be a maniac. But I believe in this, and I'm not going to lose it.  You know how much I want to help you, but this is bigger, stronger if you like than brotherly love. I'm sorry, George. I'm staying.
Person1: Well, I can't think of anything more to say. Goodbye, Bob.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses concern for Person2's well-being, offers help, and ultimately respects Person2's decision to stay and prioritize their own beliefs over brotherly love.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their commitment to staying and pursuing something they believe in, even if it means not being able to help their brother.

Dialogue:
Person1: You see, somebody went to a lot of trouble here, and I want to find out, lawsuit or no lawsuit. I'm not the one who's supposed to be caught with my pants down... so I'd like to see your husband. Unless that's a problem.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: May I speak frankly, Mrs. Mulwray?
Person2: You may if you can, Mr. Gittes.
Person1: Well, that little girlfriend, she was attractive in a cheap sort of way of course.  She's disappeared. Maybe they disappeared together somewhere.
Person2: Suppose they did. How does it concern you?
Person1: Nothing personal, Mrs. Mulwray, I just --
Person2: It's very personal. It couldn't be more personal. Is this a business or an obsession with you?
Person1: Look at it this way. Now this phony broad, excuse the language, says she's you, she's hired me. Whoever put her up to it, didn't have anything against me. They were out to get your husband. Now if I see him, I can help him.  Did you talk this morning?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their determination to uncover the truth behind a deceptive situation involving Mrs. Mulwray's husband, emphasizing their intention to assist him despite the potential legal implications.
Intent_p2: Person2 questions Person1's motives and whether his involvement is driven by business or personal obsession.

Dialogue:
Person1: You and the other one, you're still Billy's girls. You always were his girls...
Person2: Yeah.  Sure, i'm crazy in love with him, who wouldn't be...
Person1: You're gonna help us take him.
Person2: No chance.
Person1: He can live or die ... You let us in and he's got a chance to make it.  Otherwise, he gets ventilated.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to manipulate Person2 into helping them take Billy by threatening his life if they don't cooperate.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their unwavering loyalty and love for Billy, refusing to betray him despite the threats made by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: I go in alone.
Person2: You don't get the Mask code unless I go.
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to assert their decision to proceed alone despite Person2's insistence that they need to be present to obtain the Mask code.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting that Person1 cannot obtain the Mask code without their presence.

Dialogue:
Person1: I know!  I-I-I-I, I realize.
Person2: What do you expect me to say?
Person1: Hannah and I are in the last stages.
Person2: Wh-- She's never said anything, and we're very close.  She'd tell me such a thing.
Person1: Wh--, it-it-it-it, it's so sad. She's crazy about me, but somewhere on the, along the line, I've fallen out of love with her.
Person2: Not because of me, I hope.
Person1: Oh, no, no.  Well, yes!  I love you.
Person2: Oh, I can't be the cause of anything between you and Hannah.  I jus--
Person1: Oh, no, no, no.  It, uh, it-it-it- it was i-inevitable that Hannah and I part, anyway.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Tch, w-well, for a million reasons.
Person2: But not over me?
Person1: Tch, no!  We were, we were both going in different directions.
Person2: Poor Hannah.
Person1: But-but, but how about you?  Do you, do you share any of my feelings? Or is this just an unpleasant embarrassment to you?
Person2: I can't say anything!
Person1: W-well, please be candid.  I, I-I don't want you to feel bad.
Person2: Yes!  But I...I have certain feelings for you, but don't make me say anything more, all right?
Intent_p1: Person1 is confessing to Person2 that they have fallen out of love with Hannah and have developed feelings for Person2, seeking honesty and understanding in return.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses having feelings for Person1 but is hesitant to elaborate further.

Dialogue:
Person1: Fair Katharine, and most fair, will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms Such as will enter at a lady's ear And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart?
Person2: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England.
Person1: O fair Katharine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate?
Person2: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is "like me".
Person1: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
Person2: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tramperies.
Person1: What say you, fair one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?
Person2: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits.
Person1: I know no way to mince it in love, but directly to say "I love you". What! A speaker is but a prater; a rhyme is but a ballad. A good leg will fall; a straight back will stoop; a black beard will turn white; a curl'd pate will grow bald; a fair face will wither; a full eye will wax hollow; but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or rather the sun and not the moon; for it shines bright and never changes, but keeps his course truly.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their love for Katharine and emphasizing the importance of sincerity and honesty in love, stating that a good heart is constant and true.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that the languages spoken by men are full of deceit.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't you think you're overreacting just a little here?   We're talking about love, okay?  Let's be rational.
Person2: Rational?!  Love is not rational! Are you crazy?
Person1: Yes.  I'm crazy.  You have driven me crazy.  No one in their right mind would go to this much trouble to win over someone as insane as you.  Did it ever, even for one second, occur to you how much work it was to set all this up?  How many arrangements had to be made? How many players had to be coordinated?
Person2: Gee, I'm flattered.  What an incredibly romantic gesture. Cancel the roses, I've decided to lie to her instead.
Person1: Very funny.
Person2: No, it isn't.  I called off my wedding all because of you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and exasperation towards Person2 for their irrational behavior and the significant effort that was put into a romantic gesture that ultimately led to negative consequences.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are frustrated and upset because they called off their wedding due to the actions of Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Romance is just a vestigial biological response to procreation...
Person2: Aw, you're in love with me... You just dont know it yet.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a cynical view on romance being a biological instinct for procreation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is playfully suggesting that Person1 may have feelings for them despite their skepticism about romance.

Dialogue:
Person1: Get with it.  Get over it. ...millions of galaxies of hundreds of millions of stars and a speck on one in a blink...that's us.  Lost in space.  The universe doesn't care.  The cop, you, me?  Who notices?
Person2: What happened to you?
Person1: As in...?
Person2: Man, if someone had a gun to your head and said: "You gotta tell me what's goin' on with that person over there or I'll kill you"...they'd have to kill you...  'Cause you don't have a clue for...or about...anyone...  To be like that, I don't think you, you have any of that for your own life...  Do you believe you're entitled or at least expect to draw breath in the a.m.?  Open your eyes in the morning?  I don't think you do...I don't think so...  I think you are way low...like in your estimation.  In your estimation of yourself.  So how'd you get that way...?
Person1: ...all the cabbies in LA, I pull Max, the man with X-ray vision...
Person2: Answer the question.
Person1: Look in the mirror.  ...piss-ant paper towels...a bottle of 409...saving up for goin' to the Comoros.  How much you got saved?
Person2: None of your business.
Person1: ...pie in the sky?  "Someday my dream'll come..."  But one night you'll wake up and realize suddenly you're old.  It hasn't happened.  It never will.  Life just flipped on you.  Tomorrow became yesterday.  Then you'll bullshit yourself it was never gonna happen, anyway, and push it back in memory...and anesthetize yourself in a Barcalounger with daytime TV for the rest of your life...  Don't talk to me about murder.  You're do-in' yourself...in this yellow prison with steel-belted radials. Clocking in and out everyday...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a nihilistic perspective on life, highlighting the insignificance of individuals in the vast universe and criticizing the lack of self-awareness and ambition in others.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning Person1's lack of self-awareness and motivation, suggesting that they may have low self-esteem and are stuck in a cycle of unfulfilled dreams and complacency.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: Mr. Malkovich?
Person1: Who's calling?
Person2: You don't know me, but I'm a great admirer of yours.
Person1: How'd you get this number?
Person2: It's just that I fantasize about you and, well, speaking to you now has gotten me sort of excited and...
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning how Person2 obtained their phone number and is taken aback by the unexpected and inappropriate nature of the conversation.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses admiration for Mr. Malkovich and admits to fantasizing about him, leading to excitement during their conversation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Paula, how far would you go to catch Zack?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: You know what I mean. Would you... let yourself get pregnant?
Person2: No way... Would you?
Person1: I never used to think I'd do something like that, but now I'm not so sure. You ask me, nine weeks just ain't long enough to get a guy to fall in love with you.
Person2: That don't justify trying to trap a boy by getting pregnant, Lynette! Nothing justifies that. I can't believe you're even thinking like that. I mean, that's really backward.
Person1: No more backward, if you ask me, than the way these hotshot jerks mess with us, then ditch us.  Don't you ever feel used, Paula? Don't you ever feel like if this is all you get for your trouble then the sonofabitch ought to be paying for it...?
Person2: No. I never feel like that.
Person1: I do.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and a sense of being used by men, contemplating extreme measures to make a guy fall in love and questioning the fairness of the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses disapproval and disbelief at the idea of trying to trap someone by getting pregnant, emphasizing that it is unjustifiable and backward thinking.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh, cut it out, will ya?
Person2: Charlie, twenty-eight bucks is nothing.  The only way to do it is through your uncle...think about it will you?
Person1: NO!!!  What do you think I am, crazy???
Person2: No, I just want to help myself, that's all.
Person1: Come on.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and refusal towards the suggestion made by Person2 to involve their uncle in a questionable situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting to Person1 that they should consider using their uncle's help to solve a financial issue.

Dialogue:
Person1: Are you crazy? Do you realize we got ourselves a ship? We own a ship, Dodge.
Person2: Yeah, a ship that's supposed to have been lost at sea fifty years ago. You don't think that's just a little freaky?
Intent_p1: Person1 is excited and incredulous about the fact that they own a ship, emphasizing the significance of the situation to Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the eerie and unsettling nature of owning a ship that was believed to have been lost at sea fifty years ago.

Dialogue:
Person1: You mean about the Cubans getting trained north of the lake?
Person2: Oh, you got that?  Banister's pet project.  Getting paid by the government to work against the government.  Beautiful.  What a mind he had, what a guy, Guy.  He had all those files.
Person1: Who was paying you, Dave?
Person2: You think I was a getaway pilot for the assassination, don't you?
Person1: I don't know.  Were you?  Who you scared of, Dave?
Person2: Everybody!  The Agency.  The Mob. The Cubans.  Yeah, follow the Cubans. Check them out.  Here, in Dallas, Miami.  Check out a guy named Eladio del Valle.  My paymaster when I flew missions into Cuba - he's somewhere in Miami.  You're on the right track.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2 about their involvement in potentially being a getaway pilot for an assassination and who they were scared of, leading Person2 to provide information about their connections to various groups and individuals.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that Banister was involved in a covert operation funded by the government to work against the government, and suggests investigating Eladio del Valle in Miami for more information.

Dialogue:
Person1: You ok?
Person2: Just thinking about something.
Person1: What?
Person2: There's going to be very few virgins left in school on Monday. It could be really dangerous for them if the killer isn't caught.
Person1: I guess so. Luckily we won't have that problem.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing relief that they won't have to worry about the potential danger faced by virgins at school due to a killer on the loose.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the safety of virgins at school due to a potential danger posed by a killer.

Dialogue:
Person1: Can I ask you a question? I'm sorry. I don't mean to be a pest.
Person2: What?
Person1: Well, I don't mean to be a pest. It was just that I was looking at you. And you look upset. I liked looking at you, but your face looks upset. And I was wondering if I could be of any assistance? Maybe I could cheer you up or somethin. Help make you happy. Who knows? Somethin' maybe.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern for Person2's well-being and offering to help cheer them up if they are feeling upset.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to understand why Person1 is offering to help and potentially cheer them up.

Dialogue:
Person1: If you ever disrespect my wife again...I will end you.
Person2: Time's up.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the consequences of disrespecting their wife.
Intent_p2: Person2 is indicating that the warning given by Person1 has expired or that the situation has reached a critical point.

Dialogue:
Person1: You'll be able to find your way back, won't you?
Person2: Oh, yes.
Person2: Will I be seeing you again?
Person2: San Francisco's a long way from here.
Person1: I'm in San Francisco five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you.  Maybe we could go swimming or something. Mother tells me you like to swim.
Person2: How does Mother know what I like to do?
Person1: I guess she and I read the same gossip columns.
Person2: Oh. That. Rome.
Person1: Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get along very...
Person2: In case you're interested, I was pushed into that fountain.
Person2: Without any clothes on?
Person2: With all my clothes on!  The newspaper that ran the story happens to be a rival of my father's paper.  Anything they said...
Person1: You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?
Person2: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but the truth of that particular...
Person1: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd...
Person2: Yes, but...
Person1: ...who didn't much care for propriety or convention or...
Person2: Yes.
Person1: ...the opinions of others, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?
Person2: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.
Person1: Sure. Do you really know Annie Hayworth?
Person2: No.  At least, I didn't until I came up here.
Person1: So you didn't go to school together.
Person2: No.
Person1: And you didn't come up here to see her.
Person2: No.
Person1: You were lying.
Person2: Yes, I was lying.
Person1: Did you really write a letter to me? Or was that a lie, too?
Person2: I wrote the letter.
Person1: What did it say?
Person2: It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think you need those lovebirds, after all. They may help your personality." That's what it said.
Person1: But you tore it up.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because it seemed stupid and foolish.
Person1: Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!
Person2: I told you what happened in Rome!
Person1: Do you expect me to believe...?
Person2: I don't give a damn what you believe!
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses interest in spending time with Person2 and suggests activities together, but also questions Person2's honesty and past actions.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express frustration and defiance towards Person1's disbelief and judgmental attitude.

Dialogue:
Person1: It just occurred to me that I've never snuck through your bedroom window.
Person2: Now that it's out of your system.
Person1: And I was home, bored, watching television, THE EXORCIST was on and it got me thinking of you.
Person2: Oh it did?
Person1: Yeah, it was edited for TV. All the good stuff was cut out and I started thinking about us and how two years ago, we started off kinda hot and heavy, a nice solid "R" rating on our way to an NC17. And how things have changed and, lately, we're just sot of... edited for television.
Person2: So you thought you could sneak in my window and we would have a little bump-bump.
Person1: No, no. I wouldn't dream of breaking your underwear rule. I just thought we might do some on top of the clothes stuff.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing nostalgia for the passionate and intense beginning of their relationship and acknowledging that things have become more subdued and less exciting over time.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to humorously acknowledge Person1's attempt to reminisce about their past intimacy and suggest a more innocent alternative to their current relationship dynamic.

Dialogue:
Person1: She doesn't belong here, Sean.  Let her go.
Person2: She wouldn't  be here if it wasn't for you, Hunt.  from this moment you're responsible for what happens to her, and if you're looking out for her well-being, I suggest you advise her to pick up the gun and bring it to me.  Ball's in your court, Hunt.  What've you got to say? Nyah's waiting for your answer.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to let the woman go and take responsibility for her well-being.
Intent_p2: Person2 is holding Person1 accountable for the situation and is challenging them to take action to ensure the well-being of the person in question.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't want no more surprises. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.
Person2: What the hell you talkin' bout?
Person1: Sheronda passin' the money onto someone else, that's what the hell I'm talkin' 'bout.
Person2: How do you know she did that?
Person1: I was there, I saw her do it.
Person2: Well, you weren't supposed to be there.
Person1: I know, but I hung around, 'cause I figured you'd try an' pull some shit like this.
Person2: Now, hold on there. I ain't pullin' no shit. It's my money, I can do whatever I wanna do with it.
Person1: Not when it's my risk you don't. We do this my way or forget it.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: Talk to me.
Person2: I got it. But listen, Kate didn't know what's on it. I mean, she came to me to figure it out. She's not the one who planted the virus. You leave her alone.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey! Where are you going?!
Person2: Hey listen! Until today you never even knew how many guys I'd been with, because you never even asked. And then you act all nonchalant about being with twelve different girls. Well, I never was with twelve different guys!
Person1: No, but you were intimate with enough people!
Person2: Yeah, I went down on a few guys...
Person1: A few?
Person2: ...And one of those guys was you! The last one, I might add, which-if you're too stupid to comprehend- means that I've been faithful to you since we met! All the other guys I went with before I met you, so, if you want to have a complex about it, go ahead!  But don't look at me like I'm the town whore, because you were plenty busy yourself, before you met me!
Person1: Well... why did you have to be intimate with them in that way? Why didn't you just sleep with them, like any decent person?!
Person2: Because going down it's a big deal! I used to like a guy, we'd make out, and sooner or later I'd go down on him. But I only had relationships with the guys I loved.
Person1: I feel sick.
Person2: I love you. Don't feel sick.
Person1: Every time I kiss you now I'm going to think about other guys.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing shock and discomfort upon learning about Person2's past intimate experiences and is struggling with feelings of insecurity and jealousy.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement conveys the intent of defending their actions and explaining their perspective on past relationships and intimacy to Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Thank you!
Person2: For what?

Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing gratitude and appreciation for the positive impact Person2 has had on them, making them feel rejuvenated and excited about attending the opera again.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing confusion and seeking clarification on what exactly they are being thanked for.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: You want coffee or something?
Person2: Well, maybe they have one of those filter jobs in the kitchen --
Person1: Look, Elena, the fact that we're neighbors... you know, close friends, well it sort of makes this a little strange, don't you think?
Person2: My husband is probably passed out in the bathroom, or at least he wishes he were. I've been married to him for 17 years and I don't have any intention of going in there to get him... so what I'm proposing is that since your wife has gone off with a boy, and since you are standing here alone, I'm proposing that you and I do what makes sense. Stay warm. Pass some time. That's all.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing discomfort and acknowledging the awkwardness of the situation, hinting at the potential implications of Person2's proposal.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting to Person1 that they spend time together to keep each other company and stay warm while their respective partners are not around.

Dialogue:
Person1: We could do it now, we can go upstairs.  ... Please, it's time for us. Come upstairs.
Person2: I like to watch.
Person1: Watch? You mean just watch me? Doing it alone?
Person2: Yes. I like to watch very much.
Person1: Well, if that's what you want, then I want it too.  We can go this way.
Person2: I want to tell Eve.
Person1: Tell Eve? You mean Mrs. Rand?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Oh, you can tell her later. She'll never miss you in this crowd.

Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to inform Person1 that they want to inform Eve (Mrs. Rand) about the situation.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: I wish you'd stop being playful.
Person2: Sorry.  It's the first time I've ridden "piggy-back" in years.
Person1: This isn't "piggy-back."
Person2: Of course it is.
Person1: You're crazy.
Person2: remember distinctly Father taking me for a "piggy-back" ride
Person1: And he carried you like this, I suppose.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Your father didn't know beans about "piggy-back" riding.
Person2: My uncleMother's brotherhad four children . . . and I've seen them ride "piggy-back."
Person1: I don't think there's a "piggy- back" rider in your whole family. I never knew a rich man yet who was a good "piggy-back" rider.
Person2: That's silly.
Person1: To be a "piggy-backer" it takes complete relaxationa warm heartand a loving nature.
Person2: And rich people have none of those qualifications, I suppose.
Person1: Not a one.
Person2: You're prejudiced.
Person1: Show me a good "piggy-back" rider and I'll show you somebody that's human. Take Abraham Lincoln, for instancea natural "piggy-backer."  Where do you get off with your stuffed-shirt family?  Why, your father knew so much about "piggy-back" riding that he
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their belief that being a good "piggy-back" rider requires qualities like relaxation, warmth, and a loving nature, and they are skeptical that rich people possess these qualities.
Intent_p2: Person2 is challenging Person1's belief that only poor people can be good "piggy-back" riders by pointing out that qualities like relaxation, warmth, and a loving nature are more important than wealth in being skilled at it.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hello?
Person2: Do you know what I'm doing right now, Peter?  I'm looking at the name of the girl I'm going to kill tonight.
Person1: You know her?
Person2: Not really.
Person1: Why her?
Person2: Because she's the type.
Person1: But you said you didn't know her.
Person2: I know what I said!  She looks just like...
Person1: Just like who?
Person2: I really wish you'd stop trying to maneuver me.  I find it irritating, not to mention insulting.
Person1: I'm just trying to play the game.
Person2: You're not playing very well.  There are clues all around you and you keep missing them.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to understand the reasoning behind Person2's plan to harm a girl they don't know, and is attempting to engage in a conversation to gather more information.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies frustration and annoyance towards Person1 for not understanding the situation and missing important clues.

Dialogue:
Person1: Officer Burke pulled me away from the crash that killed my friends.
Person2: Congratulations.  That makes you last to go.  But don't worry, once the others are dead, it'll come back for you.  Always does.
Person1: That still doesn't make sense.  You said you die in the same order you were originally meant to.  But Evan Shaeffer died last in my premonition, not first.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the accuracy and logic of the premonition they had about the order of deaths.
Intent_p2: Person2 implies that death will eventually catch up to Person1, as it always does in the order they were originally meant to die.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm a whiskey man myself. We don't have much trouble from drugs where I come from...
Person2: You will. One of these nights you'll wake up and find a junkie tearing your bedroom apart.
Person1: Naw!
Person2: They'll climb right into your bedroom and sit on your chest with big Bowie knives. They might even sit on your wife's chest. Put the blade right down on her throat.
Person1: Not down in my parts.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confidence that drug-related violence and crime will not be a problem in their area.
Intent_p2: Person2 is warning Person1 about the potential danger of drug addicts breaking into their home and causing harm.

Dialogue:
Person1: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me.
Person2: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement indicates that Lady Cosgrove's relationship with them was tumultuous, characterized by alternating periods of love and hatred, and that Lady Cosgrove professed her enduring love and devotion despite the challenges they faced in their relationship.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement conveys a deep and enduring love for Person1, expressing a willingness to make sacrifices and pleading for love or at least kindness in return.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: Emily, do you remember when you borrowed some money from me last month?
Person2: That doesn't ring any bells. Are you sure it was with me?
Person1: Positive. You needed it for your rent, and I transferred it to your bank account.
Person2: I'm really drawing a blank here, Daniel. Are you sure it wasn't someone else?
Person1: No, it was definitely you. I even have the transaction record.
Person2: Daniel, I honestly don't remember this at all. Maybe you're mistaken or confusing me with someone else.
Person1: Well, now that you mention it, maybe I made a mistake.
Person2: See, sometimes our memories can play tricks on us, Daniel.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to remind Person2 about borrowing money for rent last month and is now considering the possibility of having made a mistake.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1 may have made a mistake or confused them with someone else regarding the borrowed money incident.

Dialogue:
Person1: Heartwarming. Really, I feel weepy.
Person2: You wanted to know what happened after the line-up, I'm telling you.
Person1: Oh come on, Verbal. Who do you think you're talking to? You really expect me to believe he retired? For a woman? Bullshit. He was using her.
Person2: He loved her.
Person1: Sure. And I'm supposed to believe that hitting the Taxi Service wasn't his idea
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing skepticism and disbelief towards the idea that a character retired for a woman and suggesting that the character was using her.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convince Person1 that the character in question truly loved the woman and did not have ulterior motives.

Dialogue:

Person2: It's not him. It's them.  I can't live like this.
Person1: Just give Reed a little more time. You know how he works -- analyzing every little step before he takes one --
Person2: It's easy for you to be patient.
Person1: No, it's not. I thought I was done waiting for Reed... We're all in this together now, Ben.

Dialogue:
Person1: You planning on going somewhere, Eduardo?  You don't like it here? This is the best situation you're going to have for a long, long time.
Person2: I am a legitimate business.  Fishing boats.  Tuna.  Check it out.  Tax records, everything --
Person1: Listen you jerk, you tried to kill me with a cannon.
Person2: You can't visit me here.  I want my lawyer.
Person1: The amount of coke we got on you means capital punishment in some states.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the serious consequences they could face due to their involvement in illegal activities.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting their innocence and requesting legal representation in response to the accusations made by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: This is the ace, Betty.  But not of spades.  They'll find out about the other.  They might know already. And when they get this--  What would they look for?  Where? Out there somewhere?
Person2: They'll look for you.
Person1: I run over to Victoria.  Play some golf with some people I know.  Do it all the time.  That's why I have a cabin cruiser.  Custom- built.Forty knots.  Mr Clark Brandon an almost gentleman of almost complete leisure.  Member of six golf clubs.  Broke 70 once on the Shaughnessy Heights Course.  You have to be good to do that, And if you look out of a front window of the Empress Hotel in Victoria, in a few hours you can look right down on Mr. Brandon's boat, the Valkyrie.  Came alone?  Sure.  He always comes alone.  Mr Brandon's a rather lonely man.
Person2: And Betty Mayfield--
Person1: Blonde, beautiful, and sad--and nowhere.  Of course she might have run away--if she knew how.  And where to go.  She might have dyed her hair.  Bleached it before probably.  And changed her name again.  But look at this note.  And look at her room in the hotel. Her stuff is all there.  Hasn't a rag except what she stood up in. You don't run away like that.  Not if you are young and beautiful. No chance.
Person2: But that's what I'm doing.  Couldn't they think of that?
Person1: If they had any reason to.  Why make it tough for themselves?  Why go to all that trouble?  Here's an open book.  Close it.  No reason to keep it open.  She was a nice girl, anyway.  And perhaps she didn't kill him on purpose.  Perhaps she didn't kill the other one. You never know.  Give her the benefit of the doubt.  Leave her stay where she is.  Close the book. Finis.
Person2: Killaine...
Person1: The best interference runner we've got.  He thinks he's in love with you--and he's a gentleman.  Come here, baby.
Intent_p1: Person1 is reflecting on the situation involving Betty Mayfield and suggesting that it may be best to close the case and give her the benefit of the doubt.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "But that's what I'm doing. Couldn't they think of that?" implies a concern about being considered as a suspect or a person of interest in a situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why do you want the white horse to bid you "good-day"?
Person2: He was a nice horse.
Person1: Maybe there's another reason. Maybe you haven't friends enough. Could that be it, Georgina?

Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they appreciate the white horse because it was kind and friendly.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Person1: Thanks, butt wart. You did good.

Dialogue:
Person1: Kevin?  Do you not love me?
Person2: No, I don't not love you.  I like, I know that we've definitely got something between us.  Something good. Something special.
Person1: But you don't love me.
Person2: I didn't say that.  I mean, love, it's like a term that gets thrown around. People say things, they get married, have kids, and then what?  It's like they call it off, going "I was wrong."

Dialogue:

Person2: I didn't tell Mama anything.  I was about to come up and wake you and tell you.  Just now.

Person2: Yes.

Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to explain that they did not inform their mother about the situation and were planning to inform Person1 instead.

Dialogue:
Person1: All right, how about Ringo? I mean ... he's very upset, you know ... and as far as your girlfriend, little Audrey's concerned, she's finished with men for the rest of her natural, and another thing ...

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: Grateful!?
Person2: "... It's all there in the three notebooks. Read them in order. If you don't want to, I suppose that's okay too. But in that case I want you to know something -- I never stopped loving your father. He was a very good man. It's just that my love for Robert was different. He brought out something in me no one had ever brought out before, or since. He made me feel like a woman in a way few women, maybe more, ever experience..."
Person1: That's it!
Intent_p1: Person1's statement "That's it!" indicates a sense of realization or understanding after hearing Person2's explanation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they have left behind three notebooks containing important information and emotions, particularly about their love for the father and Robert, and they want Person1 to read them in order to understand their feelings and experiences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Two: what if I didn't miss?
Person2: You did.
Person1: Spare me your classical answer. Measurements in.  Results taken.  What if I didn't miss?
Person2: You did miss --
Person1: -- What if your seven and a half precious liters were downloading over the parquet floor?  What then?   What did your life mean?  Who did you nurture, Pauly?  Who did you love?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the significance and impact of their actions if they had not missed their target.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to emphasize the reality of the situation by reiterating that Person1 did indeed miss their target.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yo soy un hombre sincero...; I am a sincere man, From the land of the palms...
Person2: What's that?
Person1: The song.  Are you sincere with me, Fredo?
Person2: Sincere.  What are you talking about, of course I'm sincere with you, Mike.
Person1: Then I'm going to confide in you; trust you with something.
Person2: Mike, are you crazy, I'm your brother.
Person1: Tonight we've been invited to a reception at the Presidential Palace; to bring in the New Year. You and I will go in a special car that's being sent.  They'll have cocktails... then dinner, and a reception with the President.  When it's over, it will be suggested that you take Questadt and his friends from Washington to spend the night with some women.  I'll go home alone in the car; and before I reach the hotel, I'll be assassinated.
Person2: ...Who?
Person1: The same man who tried in Nevada... Hyman Roth, not Pentangeli.
Person2: But, you told me yourself...
Person1: It was never Pentangeli... I've always known that.  It was Roth all along.  He talks to me as a son; as his successor, but the old man thinks he'll live forever.
Person2: What do you want me to do?
Person1: To go tonight, with me, as though we know nothing.  I've already made my move.
Person2: What is it?  Can I help?
Person1: The old man will never bring in the New Year.
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to confide in Person2 about a plan to attend a reception at the Presidential Palace, where he will be assassinated by Hyman Roth, revealing that Roth was behind previous attempts on his life and asking for Person2's help in the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to offer support and assistance to Person1 in their plan to confront and potentially eliminate the threat posed by Hyman Roth.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Oh come on, Kathryn. It's too easy. "But I thought high school was only four years." I mean, please. She knows nothing. She's seen nothing. I could have her under the table at Au Bar sucking me off before the appetizer arrived. Go get one of those moron friends of yours to do it. I have a reputation to uphold.
Person1: Oh but diddling the therapist's daughter is a challenge?
Person2: That was just simple revenge. What I have planned requires sheer genius.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the simplicity of Person2's actions and suggesting that pursuing the therapist's daughter may be more challenging.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that their plan requires a high level of intelligence and sophistication compared to a simple act of revenge.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know, this isn't gonna end well, these things never do.
Person2: Yeah, well, if it turns out I get shot like a dog, it'll be in the street, not off a goddamn fence.
Person1: You must see yourself as some kind of Clyde Barrow.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that Person2 sees themselves as a romanticized outlaw figure like Clyde Barrow.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a determination to face a potential negative outcome on their own terms and not in a cowardly manner.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yes!  God yes!  I would tell her that I love her!  To not let anyone take away her dreams..!
Person2: You should grab her and shake her                           ] and tell her it's a goddamn war out                         ] there.  Idiots and assholes and                             ] sadists that must be defeated. Tell                         ] them her the truth!                                         ] ] WENDY                                              ] The truth is a lie!  Yes, television                        ] is rotting our brains!  Yes, people                         ] kill people easier than ever!  Does                         ] that mean we give up!  I think every                        ] child is capable of being talented,                         ] happy, and great. I'm probably wrong,                       ] but you know something, it's good                           ] to be wrong.                                                ] ] WICHITA                                            ]                                     ] You might be right...Wendy, you're                          ] fantastic. I can't stop adoring                             ] you...                                                      ]                                         ] What I thought was lust, was only                           ] love...You think I'm scared, scared                         ] of love...Love conquers all...Maybe                         ] I don't want to be conquered. "Share                        ] my life"--I barely got enough for                           ] myself...But we were in the picture                         ] together...the picture....                                  ] ] WENDY                                              ] What are you talking about?  What                           ] picture...                                                  ] ] WICHITA Just forget--You didn't bring me out here to help me change. You brought me out here to punish me.
Person1: Nobody really changes at summer camp. They merely find out who they are and become it more than ever.  You can't be helped, Wichita. I'm not sure you can be punished, either. But let's find out...
Person2: How do you mean?                                            ]
Intent_p1: Person1's statement implies that people do not fundamentally change at summer camp, but rather discover and embrace their true selves more deeply, suggesting that Wichita may not be able to be helped or punished, and proposing to explore this further.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Person1 brought them to the summer camp not to help them change, but to punish them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Wait a minute - my bracelet.  What happened to my bracelet?
Person2: What do you mean, your bracelet? It's our bracelet.
Person1: All right. What happened to our bracelet?
Person2: Don't worry.  We did the right thing with it.
Person1: What did we do?  Joe, you're not pulling one of your old tricks.
Person2: No tricks, no mirrors, nothing up my sleeve.  It's on the level this time.
Intent_p1: Person1 is concerned about the whereabouts of their bracelet and questions Person2 about it.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reassuring Person1 that they made the right decision regarding the bracelet and that there are no tricks involved.

Dialogue:
Person1: No- not really, Josie. NOT REALLY. How could you do that to me?  I helped you. I got you everything you wanted. And how do you repay me- you blow everything TWO DAYS before pro scouts come to see me play. Once they had seen me really play- they wouldn't have given a shit about my age.
Person2: wasn't even thinking about-
Person1: No, you weren't. Don't you realize the only time I was really happy in the last five years was when I was playing ball with those guys?
Person2: I-
Person1: No, shut up, Josie. Just shut up.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and betrayal towards Josie for jeopardizing their chance to impress professional scouts and highlighting the importance of playing ball as a source of happiness in their life.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they were not considering the consequences of their actions and the impact it had on Person1's happiness and future opportunities.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, I don't know what you had in mind, but I hope you're happy. I put myself on the line for you, my reputation, and you're making me look like an idiot.
Person2: What do you mean? What did I do to you...
Person1: Who put you up to this? Did my ex- wife ask you to...?
Person2: David, please --
Person1: STOP CALLING ME THAT! MY NAME IS NOT DAVID, AND IF YOU REALLY DON'T KNOW THE DIFFERENCE, YOU'RE MORE CONFUSED THAN I THOUGHT YOU WERE!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and feeling betrayed by Person2, questioning their actions and motives while also correcting them on their name.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to calm Person1 down and address the confusion about their identity.

Dialogue:
Person1: What do your instincts tell you to do now, kid?
Person2: Leave. Take this shit back to Detroit and get the rest of our money.
Person1: We could do that. I could be on my way to Florida, and you could go to Thailand and have a great time.
Person2: ...but that's not what we're gonna do, is it?
Person1: No... if we don't finish this job, how are we gonna look at ourselves in the mirror? This is it for me, Wesley, she's the last one. My instinct says I gotta see this through with her, and if there's one thing I've tried to teach you here --
Person2: It's to follow my instincts. And my instincts say get out of Dodge.
Person1: No, I said to follow 'my' instincts. Now, we go up there and conclude our business. Case closed.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to emphasize the importance of following through with their job and completing the task at hand, despite the temptation to leave and pursue personal interests.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to prioritize their safety and financial gain by suggesting leaving and not completing the job, despite Person1's insistence on finishing the task.

Dialogue:
Person1: Okay, Pat, take it easy -- don't do anything reckless.
Person2: Who do you think you are making up that nonsense about me?!
Intent_p1: Person1 is advising Pat to remain calm and avoid acting impulsively.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and disbelief at the accusation made by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yeah, right -- I really have to go to bed.
Person2: I think we should talk first.
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to express their reluctance to engage in a conversation and prioritize going to bed instead.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that they have a conversation before Person1 goes to bed.

Dialogue:
Person1: My dad's always here running the store, busy and stuff...and I fill in once a week so he can get a night off.
Person2: That's nice.
Person1: So you're going to Michigan?
Person2: Yeah, well my parents wanted me to go to Northwestern.  I didn't want to write all those extra essays they make you do -- I mean, how am I supposed to know what my "most emotionally significant moment" was?  So when my U of M acceptance came in December, I said the hell with it.
Person1: Onions?
Person2: What?
Person1: You want onions?
Person2: Oh, yeah.  So what're you gonna major in?
Person1: Well, State's got a good business school.  And I can probably walk onto the lacrosse team.  Green peppers?
Person2: Yeah.  So wow, you've got it figured out.
Person1: Well, I mean, business is okay, and lacrosse is awesome, but what am I gonna be, a pro lacrosse player?  I really have no idea.
Person2: Oh thank God, I thought I was the only one.
Person1: Well, you're not.  Oil and vinegar?
Person2: Yeah.  You know, people are always like, "What're you gonna major in?" And I don't know.  And they're like, "You'll figure it out."  Yeah?  When?
Person1: I know.  Salt and pepper?
Person2: Sure.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses uncertainty about their future career path and major in college, highlighting the pressure and confusion many students face when deciding on their academic and professional direction.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses uncertainty and frustration about choosing a major and future career path, feeling pressured by others' expectations and unsure about when they will figure it out.

Dialogue:
Person1: Delacroix, wake up, brother man. The reason why they didn't get picked up was because nobody - and I mean NOBODY - niggers and crackers alike wants to see that junk.
Person2: I've never been given a fair shot.
Person1: You got your head stuck up your ass with your Harvard education and your pretentious ways.  Brother man, I'm blacker than you.  I'm keepin' it real and you're frontin', trying to be white.
Person2: I'm an oreo, a sell out?  Because I don't aspire to do HOMEBOYS FROM OUT OF SPACE, SECRET DIARY OF DESMOND PFEIFFER, A PJ's or some as you might put it, some "nigger" show?  I'm a Tom?  I'm whiter than white and you're blacker than black? Is that what you think?
Person1: That's exactly what I think.  I want you to create something that people want to see.  Let's be honest, the majority of the people in the country are deaf, dumb and blind and I'm including 35 million African-Americans.  You know and I know "niggers" set the trend, set the styles.  This is a golden opportunity now.  These idiots have to be led to the water.
Person2: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want.
Person1: You will or you'll be back at BET so quick you'll never know what hit you.  I need a mid-season replacement and pronto.  It will be on the fast track.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to create content that appeals to a wider audience and capitalize on the opportunity to set trends and styles.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses frustration and resistance towards conforming to stereotypes and pressures to create content that perpetuates racial stereotypes.

Dialogue:
Person1: Mrs. Grant, Governor...I won't hurt you.
Person2: My security people are right next door.
Person1: I appreciate that.
Person2: One loud scream will bring them in here instantly. You won't get very far. Think it over.
Person1: If I were here to hurt you I would have done it already.
Person2: That's...a comfort to hear.
Person1: I have a problem.
Person2: Ah.
Person1: Only you can help me. I'm also sorry to say, my problem is your problem, Mrs. Grant.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that they have a problem that directly involves Person2 and is seeking their help.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a sense of assurance and confidence in their security measures and readiness to handle any potential threat.

Dialogue:
Person1: How's my little cheerleader? Now I know everyone at your high school isn't so uptight, come on.
Person2: Hey really, I don't feel so great.
Person1: Let's do it on the coats. It'll be excellent.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to encourage Person2 to engage in risky behavior by suggesting they have sex on the coats at a party.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that they are not feeling well and may not be up for the suggested activity.

Dialogue:
Person1: I didn't say that.  Why would I say that?
Person2: Well Daddy and I were thinking that sometimes people tell a story about what they wish would happen.
Person1: I don't want that to happen.  Why would I want that to happen?
Person2: Well you're telling your teachers and your friends --
Person1: Mass hysteria.
Person2: Maybe you're upset that Rachel moved in.
Person1: I'm not upset.  Why would I be upset?
Person2: Look if the truth is you don't feel like talking about this right now that's fine. But don't look me in the eye with a big smile on your face and lie to me. Cause there are only so many lies you're allowed to tell before it starts showing on your face.  You wind up looking like...
Intent_p1: Person1 is denying saying something and expressing confusion and frustration about the situation being discussed.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about Person1's behavior and warning them about the consequences of lying.

Dialogue:
Person1: You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?
Person2: No, I don't think so?
Person1: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.
Person2: Sorry, I don't remember.
Person1: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.
Intent_p1: Person1 is reassuring Person2 that they don't need to worry about not remembering them and that they will visit often.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a lack of recollection of Person1 but reassures them that it is not a concern and that they are welcome to visit.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't know.
Person2: Are we gonna split up?
Person1: No, never.  Don't even think about that, it's impossible.  I love your mother. And you are my heart.  Could I live without my heart?  Could I?
Intent_p1: Person1 reassures Person2 that splitting up is not an option because they love Person2's mother and considers them to be their heart.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the possibility of splitting up and reassures Person1 that it is not an option because of the strong emotional bond they share.

Dialogue:
Person1: It's funny, when I first met you I thought you were such a weirdo...I still think you're a nut, but you're my nut.
Person2: Yeah...Are we going to do it or what? I still haven't packed.
Person1: Why are you being so grouchy--This is an important night for us...
Person2: Adam. Dollface. We had a physical relationship that served a purpose and now...
Person1: But, but that was before we started sharing stuff. Before I told you how I cried when Peepers died. I never told anyone that before.
Person2: And this Peepers was your...dog?  If it makes you feel better, I probably wasn't paying attention.
Person1: That doesn't make me feel better! Why are you being like this?
Person2: Don't raise your voice at--I gave you the ultimate male fantasy--sex, nothing on the side. Don't pretend we shared anything other than fluids.
Person1: Stop it, stop it, you satanic whore!
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a mix of affection and frustration towards Person2, highlighting a shift in their relationship dynamics and a desire for emotional connection.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a desire to move on from their physical relationship and is highlighting the lack of emotional connection between them and Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Aw, lookit this, lookit this -- she's bringin' Tampax in here. C'mon, you got nothin' but rooms over there.
Person2: That your desk?  I'll take this one.
Person1: WOULD YOU JUST GET OUTTA HERE?
Person2: Listen, Sex Ape.  I'm here to stay. And if you don't want me for a roommate or classmate, you got two options -- move out or ring out. End of file.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated and annoyed by Person2's presence and is expressing a desire for them to leave.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting their presence and making it clear that they are not leaving, giving Person1 the choice to either accept them or leave.

Dialogue:
Person1: Ooooooh-kayyyyyy.
Person2: In the end, the jury saw it my way.
Person1: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you.  Listen, Ms...?
Person2: Do you remember Henry Birdson?  The math professor who won the Salwen Medal, then went home and killed his family?
Person1: What's that got to do with you?
Person2: Last week the Catholic Church certified him as genuinely possessed.  You realize how rarely they make that ruling?
Person1: I do.
Person2: An exorcism was just held for Birdson. It failed.  Disastrously.  Which means there's still a demonic spirit present in his body.  I was wondering, perhaps you'd like to go meet Henry.  He's pretty amazing.
Person1: I'll bet.
Person2: On television, you seemed so sure of yourself.  If you're really that confident, you'd be willing to let someone prove you wrong?
Person1: The world would be so much simpler if it were all just about good and evil. Unfortunately I find it much more slippery and elusive place.
Person2: Well, I think it's very simple.  Here's a tape of Birdson's exorcism.  I'll be at the Public Library.  Tomorrow at 2... if you want to meet him.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to express skepticism about the simplicity of the concept of good and evil and the complexities of the world.
Intent_p2: Person2 is inviting Person1 to meet Henry Birdson, who was certified as possessed by the Catholic Church and had a failed exorcism, to challenge their beliefs and confidence in the face of the supernatural.

Dialogue:
Person1: But one thing I could never understand, was that she could have everything under control, except for her old pimp boyfriend, Lester Diamond.
Person2: Look, Gin, you know I got other people in this. I got partners. But I want you to understand that I am lookin' out for you in this thing.  Okay? You're going to get yours back... and you're gonna get it back first. Okay?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confusion about how the woman could manage everything except for her problematic ex-boyfriend, Lester Diamond.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reassuring Person1 that despite having other obligations and partners, they are prioritizing looking out for Person1 and ensuring they get what they deserve first.

Dialogue:
Person1: What d'you want?
Person2: What?
Person1: What you got me up here for?
Person2: Oh, difficult, it's so difficult. You're a nice person, Joe -- I should never have asked you up -- a lovely person. Oh, how I loathe life. I loathe it. Please go. Please.
Person1: You want me to leave?
Person2: No, yes. No, I mean yes please go. Help me to be good. Come back tomorrow. Promise.
Person1: I'm going to Florida.
Person2: This is terrible. I meet someone who -- then -- wait, I want to give you a present. For your trip. You'll let me please...
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning why they were brought to the location and is considering leaving, but Person2 is conflicted and asks them to stay and promises to be better, eventually offering a present for their trip to Florida.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing inner turmoil and self-loathing, asking Person1 to leave but also wanting them to stay and help them be a better person, ultimately offering a present for their trip to Florida.

Dialogue:
Person1: Memory is no trick, it is a power. The power to see.
Person2: Power you have given me. What can my power give you?
Person1: Knowledge.
Person2: Of what?
Person1: The Fortress of Krull. When will it come near here?
Person2: Why must you know?
Person1: There is a girl there. Her name is Lyssa.
Person2: You lie!
Person1: Could I lie to you and still see your beauty?
Person2: No.
Person1: A young man seeks her. A young man about the age I was when I met you.
Person2: Tomorrow, the Fortress of Krull will rise with the sun in the Valley of Reeds. But the knowledge is of no use to you. No man has ever escaped the Web. And soon the creature will come for you, even here.
Intent_p1: Person1 is seeking knowledge about the Fortress of Krull and the whereabouts of a girl named Lyssa, showing concern for her safety and hinting at a personal connection with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a warning about the futility of seeking to rescue the girl from the Fortress of Krull due to the imminent danger posed by the creature that guards it.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm homesick.
Person2: Homesick?  It's only been two days!
Person1: We should have gone to Nassau. At least we could go swimming, lie on the beach.
Person2: Ah hell we can always do that. Listen believe me, once we get to the moon, your tone is going to change.
Person1: How is it going to be different from this?  Go see some boring footprint under glass?
Person2: Look you were the one who wanted to do something different, something to tell all your friends.  Any chump can go to Nassau.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a desire for a more enjoyable and relaxing vacation experience, feeling disappointed with the current situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to reassure Person1 that going to the moon will be a unique and memorable experience compared to a typical vacation destination like Nassau.

Dialogue:
Person1: Endorse me in public.  Do that and I'll make you rich and set you free. I'll return your estates.  I know you would give anything to be outside again.  Endorse me and you will be free.  Think of it.  What would you do with your freedom?
Person2: If you set me free I will find my way back to the army, march on Rome and depose you.  Then, the army and I will restore the Republic so that animals like you will never control human destinies again.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to manipulate Person2 into endorsing them publicly by offering wealth, freedom, and the return of their estates in exchange for support.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to overthrow Person1, restore the Republic, and prevent individuals like Person1 from controlling human destinies in the future.

Dialogue:
Person1: I swear to God Charlie...my arm still hurts from the car accident...that's why I didn't go to work.  I swear it.
Person2: That's not going to help.
Person1: I'm going to work this week...I mean it.
Person2: It's impossible for you to catch up on the loan now...the interest is going up...$3,000...do you realize that, flash?
Person1: I'm sorry Charlie...I didn't mean it.
Person2: Big deal...in the meantime, it's done...I'll still try to help you out...You know that...but you gotta show some effort...some respect... understand?
Person1: Charlie, you know the best way to take care of this whole mess.
Person2: How?
Person1: If you had a little talk with your uncle...if anybody can do it, he can.
Person2: That'll help you out fine.  That's the best way for you, not for me! I swear to God, I'll rip you open if my uncle ever hears a word about this.  You understand?  I don't care what happens, he doesn't find out.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting to Person2 that the best way to resolve the situation is for Person2 to have a conversation with their uncle to help them out, but Person2 is warning Person1 not to involve their uncle or there will be consequences.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to emphasize the seriousness of the situation and the consequences of involving their uncle in resolving the issue.

Dialogue:
Person1: I just can't deal with all this crap between us, I'm sorry.  I'm quitting.
Person2: Let's get hitched.  I guess I, you know, love you.  It's a beautiful thing.
Person1: Wha --
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and apologizing for the situation between them, indicating that they are quitting.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their love for Person1 and suggesting they get married as a way to address the issues in their relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: Who are you?
Person2: You called me by my name.
Person1: Irena. But who are you?
Person2: I'm your friend.
Person1: I've wanted a friend.
Person2: I've wanted a friend too. I've been lonely.
Person1: But where do you come from?
Person2: You wouldn't understand. I come from great darkness and deep peace
Person1: But where is that?
Person2: I can not tell you.
Person1: Will you be friend for always?
Person2: For as long as you'll let me.
Person1: I shall want you for always.
Person2: For always, then. Only you must promise never to tell anyone about me
Person1: Not even Daddy...or Mommy?
Person2: No. This must be a friendship that only we shall have... you and I... Amy and her friend.
Person1: Oh, I like the sound of that.., Amy and her friend... Amy and her friend.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a desire for friendship and connection with Person2, who is hesitant to reveal their origins but agrees to be Amy's secret friend.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to establish a deep and exclusive friendship with Person1 (Amy) and to keep their connection a secret from others.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hello.
Person2: It's me.
Person1: I figured it was.  Where are you?
Person2: I think the big question here is where are you, if you don't mind my saying so, and I think I know where you are.  You're running.  On the run.  You're running from a point that everyone hits in any relationship, and you're just going to hit it again with Ian but it's going to be with a World Music bunny- rabbit-looking earth-shoe-wearing "Doctor Who"-watching twit who doesn't really understand you, not the way that I do and will more in the future, and you'll have just wasted more time and arrive in the exact same place that you're in now, only later. And with... him.
Person1: I'm not -- hold on...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise and confusion at the assumptions and accusations made by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they believe Person1 is running away from facing relationship issues and will end up in the same situation with someone else who doesn't truly understand them.

Dialogue:
Person1: I cannot ignore the verdict of my council.
Person2: Surely you can do anything you want.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that they feel obligated to follow the decision made by their council.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1 has the power to make their own decisions regardless of the council's verdict.

Dialogue:
Person1: Let me guess--breakfast is served?
Person2: No.
Person1: What then?
Person2: I do not wish to be scrogged--ever. I never heard that word, but when I heard it, I knew it was one thing I never wanted to have happen to me.
Person1: That's what you're supposed to say.
Person2: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.
Person1: You don't know you want.  That's the way God built you!
Person2: I will not be scrogged.  I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.
Person1: It couldn't!
Person2: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
Person1: Fish can't feel.
Person2: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more.  Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.
Person1: Such as?...
Person2: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.
Person1: Tell me about its sexual roots.
Person2: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.
Person1: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.
Person2: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.
Person1: Go on.
Person2: And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say--  for revenge.
Person1: You learned this in some college course?
Person2: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.
Person1: The doctor.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And what is his most cherished possession?
Person2: His most cherished possession?  His violin, I guess.
Person1: And he keeps it in his apartment?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And no one's there now?
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.
Person2: What are you going to do?
Person1: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.
Person2: No you're not!
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Because if you do--I'll leave you. HAROLD  Goodbye.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to express a desire for revenge against Norbert by breaking into his apartment and smashing his violin, as a way to even the score for Norbert's actions that harmed Person1's reputation with women.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent in the statement is to express their strong opposition to Person1's plan to break into the doctor's apartment and smash his violin, stating that if Person1 goes through with it, they will leave.

Dialogue:
Person1: ...You don't happen to remember the plan I outlined to you the day I set fire to your off -- uh, the day I was promoted?
Person2: I do remember and I was impressed. Anyway, that's all forgotten now. Driver!
Person1: Thank you, Sid, but the reason I mention it is, it would require such a small capital investment -- again, you're the expert here --
Person2: Damnit, where's my car!
Person1: -- But there's such an enormous potential profit-wise given the demographics -- baby boom -- discretionary income in the burgeoning middle class --
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to remind Person2 about a business plan they discussed in the past and highlight its potential profitability.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to dismiss the previous conversation and change the subject by expressing frustration about not finding their car.

Dialogue:
Person1: Happy birthday.
Person2: What is this? Is this a... Present?  Are you kidding?
Person1: Yeah, hey, why don't yuh try it on?
Person2: Uh, yeah, uh... t-t-this is more like a present for you, yeah, but it's-
Person1: Try it... it'll add years to our sex life.
Person2: Uh huh. Yeah. Forget it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that the gift they gave to Person2 will enhance their sex life.
Intent_p2: Person2 is hesitant and uncomfortable with the idea of trying on the present, suggesting it is more of a gift for Person1 and not interested in the suggestion to try it on for the benefit of their sex life.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey, Jake... When am I gonna get to play the Inside?
Person2: Gordo plays the inside. You're the Shill.
Person1: Yeah, but come on... All I get to do is cry and get insulted.
Person2: What are you talking about? You should get a Academy Award for the Shill work you do.  We got it down cold, Al. You don't want to jinx it by changing something up, do you?
Person1: I'm gonna go get eggrolls. Anyone want eggrolls?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire to have a more active role in the situation and feels unfulfilled with their current role as the Shill.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reassuring Person1 about their role as the Shill and emphasizing the importance of maintaining consistency in their performance.

Dialogue:
Person1: Getting cold.
Person2: It's a desert.  That's what deserts do at night; they get cold.
Person1: Epps...Epps!  I'm gonna stop for a second.
Person2: No!
Person1: Just let me rest for a second.
Person2: We've got to keep moving while there's still light.
Person1: You know what I'm going to do?  I'm just going to take a second.  I want to look at the gold.
Person2: Don't you touch it.
Person1: I just want to look at it.  Remind me of what I'm dying for.
Person2: The deal was no one touches it until we get out of here.
Person1: Yeah, but we made that deal while Wes was still alive.  He's gone.  Time for a new deal.
Intent_p1: Person1 wants to take a break to rest and look at the gold they are risking their lives for, suggesting a renegotiation of the agreement not to touch it until they leave, as one of their group members has died.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to uphold the original agreement and prevent Person1 from touching the gold until they leave the desert.

Dialogue:
Person1: Just for a second. Please, Rose, what's the harm?
Person2: Buddy, you don't realize it but what you're doing isn't nice.
Person1: Aw, come on, Rose, I want to see what the nipple on it is like.
Person2: You don' t need to know that. It's none of your business.
Person1: Aw, be a good sport, Rose.  You like me, don't you? I like you a lot.
Intent_p1: Person1 is pressuring Rose to show them something they are curious about, using flattery and emotional manipulation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disapproval and setting boundaries against Person1's inappropriate behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: Now Amy
Person2: It's true.
Person1: And who did the voice belong to?
Person2: It was just a voice.
Person1: Now look, this is the last time you come to me with any such stories  I'm sick of this sort of thing.
Person2: Daddy, it's true.
Person1: Let me be the judge of that.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and skepticism towards Person2's stories and is setting a boundary by stating that they do not want to hear such stories anymore.
Intent_p2: Person2 is insisting that what they are saying is true, despite Person1's skepticism.

Dialogue:
Person1: What is your name?
Person2: That's cool.  We're gettin' to know each other. This is a good thing. I'm Carter.
Person1: Carter.  I just want to be able to tell the Ambassador who was responsible for the death of his daughter because he talked too much.
Person2: Hey, that's whacked!  I thought we was gettin' on here!
Person1: Shut up!
Person2: OK. Say what it is.
Person1: The Ambassador will receive instructions for the drop, half an hour before it is to be made.  If it is successful, there will be more. Thank you, Agent Carter.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to inform Person2, who is revealed to be Agent Carter, about the plan to deliver instructions for a drop to the Ambassador, indicating a potential future collaboration.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses surprise and disappointment at the sudden change in the conversation and the aggressive tone of Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Let's do it here.
Person2: What about him?
Person1: Let him watch.  I want him to know what he's missing.
Intent_p1: Person1 wants the person they are referring to as "him" to witness what they are about to do in order to make him realize what he is missing out on.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the decision to involve someone else in the activity and expressing concern about their feelings.

Dialogue:
Person1: This is an important mission, Sgt. Whitman. I hope you realize that.
Person2: Oh -- you don't wanna know what I think. Topside, now.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the significance of the mission to Sgt. Whitman.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a sense of urgency and authority by instructing Person1 to go to the top immediately without further discussion.

Dialogue:
Person1: Claudia, let's get married?
Person2: What! Get married?
Person1: Yes. We'll get married. You and I. What do you say?
Person2: What do I say? What can I say? No. At least, not yet. I don't know... I can't even think of it... at a time like this... Oh, but why did you have to ask me?
Person1: You look at me as though I had said something foolish...
Person2: And are you sure you want to marry me? Are you really sure...that you want to marry... me?
Person1: That's why I asked you...
Person2: So... Oh, how I wish that everything were so much simpler... that people could just come together by the color of their hair or the size of their shoes. What size shoe do you wear? Size 9. That's a very lovely size. But I'm sorry, I wear size 8.
Intent_p1: Person1 is proposing marriage to Person2, who seems hesitant and unsure about the idea.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement expresses hesitation and uncertainty about the idea of getting married, questioning the readiness and compatibility of the relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're in one hell of a jam.  You realize that?
Person2: I'm high as a kite.
Person1: Glands.  You're supposed to be happy when you die.  Call me comical again.
Person2: You're a clown.  You're a clown who kills--but you're a clown.
Person1: I love you!  Have a cigar!
Person2: Evolution has made you a clown-- with a cigar.  Simple butchers like you are obsolete!
Person1: I'm to be left behind--in primordial ooze?
Person2: If you're at home in the ooze, and nowhere else.
Person1: This is going to become very physical.  Are you prepared for that?
Person2: You're not such a creature of the ooze that you'd hurt an unarmed man.
Person1: I'm an honorable clown?
Person2: King Arthur.
Person1: You hope.
Person2: In any event, I will not beg for mercy.
Person1: No quarter asked.  No quarter given.
Person2: Don't you laugh even inwardly at the heroic balderdash you spew?
Person1: Cut me open.  Find out.
Person2: I've struck my blow.
Person1: With spittle?
Person2: I've poisoned you. HAROLD  Lucretia Borgia?  Something I drank or touched?  You refused a cigar.  That's it! Potassium cyanide in the humidor! Treacherous lover of peace!
Person2: I put a poisoned thought in your head.  Even now that poison is seeping into every lobe of your mind.  It's saying, "Obsolete, obsolete, obsolete," and, "Clown, clown, clown."
Person1: Poison.
Person2: You have a very good mind, or I wouldn't have come back.  That mind is now asking itself, cleverly and fairly, "Is Harold Ryan really a clown?" And the answer is, "Yes."
Person1: I--I really must congratulate you. Something is happening in there.
Person2: You can never take yourself seriously again!  Look at all the creatures you've protected us from! Did you shoot them on the elevator, as they were on their way up here to eat us alive?
Person1: No. WOODLY The magic root you gave me--I had it analyzed.  It was discovered by a Harvard botanist in 1893!  He explored your famous jungle for five years, armed with nothing but kindness, a talent for languages, and a pocketknife.
Person1: I see.
Person2: You aren't going to hurt me.  You aren't going to hurt anybody any more.  Any violent gesture will seem ridiculous--to yourself!
Person1: Don Quixote.
Person2: My violin is avenged!
Person1: Something seems to have happened to my self-respect.
Person2: And the hell with it.  It was so tragically irrelevant, so preposterously misinformed.
Person1: The new hero is you.
Person2: I hate crowds, and I have no charisma--
Person1: You're too modest.
Person2: But the new hero will be a man of science and of peace--like me. He'll disarm you, of course.  No more guns, no more guns.
Person1: Was I ever of use?
Person2: Never.  For when you began to kill for the fun of it, you became the chief source of agony of mankind.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging their defeat and the realization that their actions have caused immense harm to humanity.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Person1's actions of killing for fun have made them the primary cause of humanity's suffering.

Dialogue:
Person1: I was a great dancer...
Person2: A strange collection. You're like the false god you worship... fallen angels, all of you.
Person1: Life has betrayed us. We've found there is no heaven on earth, so we must worship evil for evil's own sake. We're not wicked. We commit no violence, unless...
Person2: Unless what?
