Person1: No, you draw no secrets from me, as you drew them from Jacqueline. You are not one of us yet. You're clever, Louis, but I recognize your interest in me for what it is worth. You are only curious. You have never loved a woman who had but one arm.
Person2: It would be a charming experience. She might only protest half as much.
Person1: You're very flippant and perhaps wise, but not wise enough to see the truth, Louis.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses disillusionment with life and hints at a darker path they have chosen to follow, while also hinting at a hidden secret and questioning Person2's understanding and motives.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a sarcastic and dismissive attitude towards Person1's deep and dark revelations.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm saving them for a rainy day.
Person2: gives her a sympathetic look.
Person2: I know it's hard for you being in here, but it is for the good of your health.
Person1: They sent me off to the Bahamas "for the good of my health." They sent me to the Bay of bloody Islands "for the good of my health."
Person2: looks startled at the outburst.
Person1: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rieper. I'm feeling quite fatigued.
Person2: We don't want to tire you out, dear.
Person2: stands and picks up her handbag. Pauline stands and Juliet grabs her hand.
Person1: Can't you stay a bit longer, Paul?
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses frustration and sarcasm about being sent to different places "for the good of their health" and then requests for Person2 to stay longer.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies reassurance and understanding towards Person1's feelings and situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Big giant capacitor.  And that, instead of generating power it'll sort of be --  -- sucking power, from Gotham City, and storing it ... stockpiling it, sort of?  Which, unless I'm being dense, is a novel approach, I'd say.
Person2: And who ... would you say this to?
Intent_p1: Person1 is proposing a unique idea of using a large capacitor to store power from Gotham City instead of generating it, which they find to be an innovative approach.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the practicality or purpose of sharing such an unconventional idea with anyone.

Dialogue:
Person1: I just meant that maybe you could manage your time better. It wasn't a criticism.
Person2: You always take things the wrong way. I've been juggling a lot lately.
Person1: I'm trying to help, Kyle. But you see everything as an attack.
Person2: Maybe if you approached things differently, I wouldn't feel that way.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to offer constructive advice to help Person2 manage their time better, but Person2 perceives it as criticism and suggests that a different approach might be more effective.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that they feel misunderstood and defensive due to the way Person1 approaches them.

Dialogue:
Person1: --Millie, you've got to stay out of the clubhouse.  It'll just get everybody in trouble.
Person2: I got lured.
Person1: You didn't get "lured".  Women never get lured.  They're too strong and powerful for that. Now say it--"I didn't get lured and I will take responsibility for my actions".
Person2: "I didn't get lured and I will take responsibility for my actions".
Person1: That's better.  Got the radar ready?
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the importance of taking responsibility for one's actions and rejecting the notion of being lured into trouble.
Intent_p2: Person2 acknowledges taking responsibility for their actions and denies being lured into the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: I know how to get in there. But you've gotta help me.
Person2: ...Whaddo I do?
Person1: So you believe me?
Intent_p1: Person1 is seeking confirmation from Person2 that they believe in their ability to get into a certain place and is asking for their assistance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is seeking clarification on their role in helping Person1 gain access to a certain place.

Dialogue:
Person1: When you slaughter a goat and wrench its heart out with your bare hands, do you then summon hellfire?
Person2: I mean, what are you actually doing here? What is the hidden agenda?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the extreme actions being taken and whether they are leading to a destructive outcome.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the true purpose or underlying motive behind Person1's actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: ...you don't have to come in...
Person2: ...and rob the place...
Person1: ...I thought that we were only talking...
Person2: ...they take me, then.  They're going to ask me who were my accomplices.
Person1: Me?
Person2: Absolutely.
Person1: That's ridiculous.
Person2: Well, to the law, you're an accessory.  Before the fact.
Person1: I didn't ask to be.
Person2: Then tough luck, George, because you are.
Person1: Why?  Why, because you only told me about it?
Person2: That's right.
Person1: Why are you doing this to me, Dave. Why are you talking this way to me? I don't understand.  Why are you doing this at all...?
Person2: That's none of your business...
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning why Person2 is involving them in criminal activities and speaking to them in a hostile manner.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are unwilling to involve Person1 in their criminal activities and are willing to take the blame alone if caught.

Dialogue:
Person1: I bet you make your Daddy proud, don't you? Beautiful.
Person2: This isn't happening.
Person1: I used to tell myself that. Used to try and pretend I was dreaming all the pain. But why kid yourself? Some things have to be endured. Take it from me. And that makes the pleasures so much sweeter...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a sense of resilience and the idea that enduring pain can make moments of joy even more meaningful.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and denial about the situation they are in.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm in, too.
Person2: Cleo!
Person1: Kansas is right.  We're like sisters -- we're closer than sisters.  And you don't turn your back on family.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing loyalty and commitment to their group, emphasizing the importance of sticking together like family.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing loyalty and emphasizing the importance of sticking together as a family.

Dialogue:
Person1: What's outside of Pleasantville?
Person2: Look it doesn't matter. It's not important.
Person1: What is it?
Intent_p1: Person1 is curious about what lies beyond Pleasantville and wants to know more about it.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to dismiss the topic and convey that what is outside of Pleasantville is irrelevant or insignificant.

Dialogue:
Person1: You don't understand, I can't!
Person2: Listen, Doug took the rap for us all so grab your coat 'cause you're going.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing reluctance or inability to do something, while Person2 is insisting that they must go because someone else took the blame for them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is telling Person1 that they need to leave because someone else took the blame for their actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: We need to talk.
Person2: Talk about what, Patrick? What is there to talk about?
Person1: It's over, Evelyn. It's all over
Person2: Touchy, touchy. I'm sorry I brought the wedding up. Let's just avoid the issue, alright? Now, are we having coffee?
Person1: I'm serious. It's over. Us. This is no joke. I don't think we should see each other anymore.
Person2: But your friends are my friends. My friends are your friends. I don't think it would work.  You have a little something on your upper lip.
Person1: I know that your friends are my friends. I've thought about that. You can have them.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their decision to end the relationship with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are trying to downplay the seriousness of the breakup and divert the conversation to avoid addressing the issue at hand.

Dialogue:
Person1: All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.
Person2: What?
Person1: Shoot to kill, I said.
Person2: I don't know, Fred. There's that reprieve if they ever find out.
Person1: Nobody reprieved that policeman he murdered. Now, do as I tell you.
Person2: Hello, Olsen... Listen...  Shoot to kill... That's the orders pass the word along... No! We dont want him! And listen, Olsen, five- hundred bucks for the guy that does the job... Yes, I'll be right out there.  Well, I hope that's the right thing to do.
Person1: Now take that guilty look off your face, Pete -- and stop trembling like a horse.
Person2: If we didn't have election Tuesday I'd have this on my conscience.
Intent_p1: Person1 is instructing Person2 to give orders to shoot to kill and to stop feeling guilty or hesitant about it.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses hesitation and moral conflict about following the order to shoot to kill, especially considering the potential consequences and guilt involved.

Dialogue:
Person1: The Matrix is everywhere, it's all around us, here even in this room. You can see it out your window or on your television.  You feel it when you go to work, or go to church or pay your taxes.  It is the world that has been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the truth.
Person2: What truth?
Person1: That you are a slave, Neo.  Like everyone else, you were born into bondage, kept inside a prison that you cannot smell, taste, or touch. A prison for your mind.
Intent_p1: Person1 is conveying the idea that the world is an illusion created to deceive individuals into a state of mental captivity and that they are essentially enslaved without realizing it.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asking about the truth that Person1 is referring to, questioning what it is.

Dialogue:
Person1: I can get you a job.
Person2: A job?
Person1: Yes, the money is good.
Person2: As a plumber?!
Person1: It's easy to learn.
Person2: A job??  As a plumber???  You think I come to America to work!
Person1: We started over, you can too.
Person2: You spent all the money while I was in prison?  Now you tell me to get a job fixing toilets?!?
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting to Person2 that they can start over and find a job as a plumber to make good money, despite their initial reluctance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and frustration at the suggestion of getting a job as a plumber after coming to America to start over and feeling betrayed by Person1's actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: You get wise to yourself! If you know what's good for you, you'll leave me alone. Everybody's entitled to one mistake--Well--you're mine. When the going got too rough, I pulled up stakes and quit. We stay quit!--Get that!--And what're you going to do about it?
Person2: That's more like the old Sally--a little bit of fire.  How about Ned?
Person1: He's all right.
Person2: Thanks to me.
Person1: You leave the kid alone.
Person2: A tipoff in the right quarter to take his fingerprints and--
Person1: --you'd go with him!
Person2: Don't kid yourself--you know how I stand back there.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their independence and warning Person2 to stay away, while also expressing concern for Ned and rejecting any involvement in potentially harmful actions.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that they have been instrumental in ensuring Ned's well-being and safety.

Dialogue:
Person1: No.
Person2: Well, I'm going to tell you anyway. I did cheat on that exam at Groton. But so did twenty-six other guys, and nobody ever mentioned it until today.  And I'm expecting you won't mention it again.  I don't know who you are and where you're getting your information, but I'm willing to pretend I did not hear it, and let bygones be bygones.  But can I tell you something else, it'd be nice to see the big guy without you next to him.  What are you, his shadow?  Do you assist him with everything, even the simplest tasks?  You know some- times somebody would like a few min- utes alone with W.P.  That means without you.  Okay, pal?  Let's eat.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to assert their refusal to engage in the conversation about cheating on an exam, while also expressing their desire for some privacy and independence from Person2's constant presence.
Intent_p2: Person2 is admitting to cheating on an exam at Groton, expressing surprise that the information has resurfaced, and subtly asking Person1 to give them space away from someone named W.P.

Dialogue:
Person1: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.
Person2: I do not think I like the sound of that.
Person1: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.
Person2: I feel hardly nothing.
Person1: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.
Person2: But why be so concerned about me?
Person1: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.
Person2: And you?
Person1: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.
Person2: I am not ready for this.
Person1: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.
Person2: Of course.
Person1: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.
Person2: That is not me.
Person1: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement emphasizes the importance of understanding and harnessing the power of knowledge and responsibility in order to navigate the complexities of life and avoid succumbing to negative influences.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses reluctance and apprehension towards the responsibilities and power they possess, indicating a lack of readiness for the challenges ahead.

Dialogue:
Person1: You... are a coward. Part wimp. Part timid.
Person2: What do you mean -- coward? This girl is my exact type. It's her. Definitely her.
Person1: It's definitely your mama.
Person2: Damone, you gotta listen to me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that Person2 is hesitant and fearful in pursuing the girl, comparing him to his mother.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to defend himself by asserting that the girl in question is his type and not his mother, asking for understanding and attention from Damone.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're home late... or should I say early?
Person2: Why are you still here?  You killed a policeman.  You should leave! You'll bring ruin on my whole family.
Person1: They wouldn't have found me if you hadn't stolen the sword.  Like a little girl, you thought stealing would be fun?  You, too, are responsible for that death.  Come with me.  You don't want to waste your life as the wife of some bureaucrat.  Denied your talent... As a master and disciple we will rule.
Person2: I'll never live as a thief!
Person1: You're already a thief.
Person2: That was just for fun.  How can I leave?  Where would I go?
Person1: Wherever we want.  We'll get rid of anyone in our way.  Even your father.
Person2: Shut up!
Person1: It's the Giang Hu fighter lifestyle... kill or be killed. Exciting, isn't it?
Person2: I owe you nothing.
Person1: Yes, you do!  You are still my disciple.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to manipulate Person2 by blaming them for a crime, offering power and control, and asserting authority over them as their mentor.
Intent_p2: Person2 is rejecting Person1's attempts to involve them in a criminal lifestyle and reminding them that they owe nothing to Person1 as their disciple.

Dialogue:
Person1: He can never know you as I know you... He can never touch you as I touch you.
Person2: This isn't real.
Person1: Can you feel my hands... are they real? Can you feel my lips, my loins?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing possessiveness and a desire for intimacy with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing doubt about the reality of the situation and questioning the physical sensations being described by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't think I can get her to do it.
Person2: You mean it'll be difficult.
Person1: Very.
Person2: Well it's not mission difficult, Hunt. It's mission impossible.  Difficult should be a walk in the park for you.  If you can think of a quicker way to get to Ambrose, you're welcome to try.  Oh, by the way, you might want to take a look at these..if you have any further qualms about getting her to do the job.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing doubt about their ability to convince someone to do something challenging.
Intent_p2: Person2 is encouraging Person1 to view the task as a challenge that they are capable of overcoming, suggesting that they should consider alternative approaches and providing additional information to help them succeed.

Dialogue:
Person1: Just for curiosity sake that's all?
Person2: I don't know -- maybe twenty miles... Of course I'm not recommending that... if someone like you had to I mean... that's how far they'd probably get before encountering serious physical walls.
Person1: Twenty miles?  I see.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise and understanding at the distance of twenty miles being mentioned as a hypothetical scenario.
Intent_p2: Person2 is cautioning Person1 about the physical limitations they might face if they were to travel a long distance on foot.

Dialogue:
Person1: You idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.
Person2: I'm sorry, Mike. I never heard of LaMarra flipping on anyone before. He said he had the cops paid off. Antonucci never flipped on anyone before. He had the cops paid off.
Person1: Not the cop that showed up at my door!
Person2: What happened, Mike.
Person1: You don't want to know.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and anger towards Person2 for assuming they are being used for promotional purposes, and hints at a troubling incident involving the police.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and curiosity about a troubling incident that happened to Mike involving the police.

Dialogue:
Person1: I couldn't help but notice you pain.
Person2: My pain?
Person1: It runs deep. Share it with me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing empathy and a willingness to listen and support Person2 in dealing with their pain.
Intent_p2: Person2 is being encouraged to open up and share their deep pain with Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: "...a sincere and heartfelt apology which you will then read aloud to him before the assembled student body and faculty.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Our profession needs talent like yours. Destroy your career over an issue of pride? What a waste.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to apologize sincerely in front of everyone to avoid ruining their career over a matter of pride.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the necessity of publicly apologizing and potentially damaging their career over a matter of pride.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well?
Person2: He's completely out of his mind.
Person1: Great. Is that what you're going to say when I put you on the stand?
Person2: No. When you put me on the stand, I'll say your client is catatonic and exhibits classic symptoms of a schizophrenic, sociopathic personality.  And he doesn't sleep.
Person1: Doesnit sleep?
Person2: Insomnia. Not unusual for someone in his situation.  Not to mention he's a bed-wetter.
Person1: He wets the bed?
Person2: I always throw that in. It makes the jury feel sorry for the defendant.
Intent_p1: Person1 is discussing strategies with Person2 on how to present their client in a more sympathetic light during the trial.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to provide a strategic approach for testifying in court by emphasizing the defendant's mental health issues and personal struggles to evoke sympathy from the jury.

Dialogue:
Person1: Let's have sex.  I thought you were curious.
Person2: Not about that.
Person1: I'm listening.
Person2: I'm afraid to tell you.
Person1: I'm not armed.  Well?
Person2: Why is it wrong to run?
Person1: You shouldn't even think such things...  And you picked a strange person to say them to --
Person2: I suppose. But what if you want to live?
Person1: So? Do what everyone does. Try like hell for renewal.
Intent_p1: Person1 is encouraging Person2 to pursue renewal and not to dwell on negative thoughts.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the societal norms and expectations around the idea of running away or escaping from a situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: It's just a shot to calm you.
Person2: No more drugs.  Please...
Person1: I have to do this, James.  You're very confused.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to justify administering a shot to James for his own well-being despite James's reluctance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a strong desire to stop taking drugs.

Dialogue:
Person1: You understand. Consider, before you laugh and say no. You will never own a throne, though you deserve one. But just as the sun will rise tomorrow, some man will rule England. And what if his veins ran not with the blood of Longshanks, but with that of a true king?
Person2: I cannot love you for the sake of revenge.
Person1: No. But can you love me for the sake of all you loved and lost? Or simply love me... because I love you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning if Person2 can love them for reasons beyond revenge, such as for the love they have for each other or for the things they have lost.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that they cannot love Person1 out of a desire for revenge.

Dialogue:
Person1: Did you kill anyone?
Person2: I don't like to talk about that.
Person1: It's nothing to be ashamed of, in the service of one's country. That's something to be proud of.
Person2: Proud?  Any jerk with a gun can kill someone.
Person1: Quite true.  Hand-to-hand combat is the true test.  Did you ever slay anyone hand-to-hand?
Person2: No.  I could have, though.
Person1: Yes, I believe you could.  How free is your schedule this afternoon?
Person2: Full up.  I got the hedges to do here, then another lawn out by La Cienega.
Person1: What is we say phooey to the hedges?  Could you spare an hour after lunch?  To sit for me?
Person2: Can't today.
Person1: I'll pay our going rate.  Plus what you'd get if you did the hedges.
Person2: Sorry.  I don't feel like sitting still today.
Person1: All righty.  I understand.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to recruit Person2 for a task, possibly involving sitting for a portrait, but Person2 declines due to other commitments and lack of interest.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to politely decline Person1's offer to sit for them after expressing discomfort with discussing killing and a lack of interest in sitting still.

Dialogue:
Person1: Would you mind repeating the question?
Person2: Look, Baxter, I'm not stupid. I know everything that goes on in this building -- in every department -- on every floor -- every day of the year.
Person1: You do?
Person2: In 1957, we had an employee here, name of Fowler. He was very popular, too. Turned out he was running a bookie joint right in the Actuarial Department tying up the switchboard, figuring the odds on our I.B.M. machines -- so the day before the Kentucky Derby, I called in the Vice Squad and we raided the thirteenth floor.
Person1: The Vice Squad?
Person2: That's right, Baxter.
Person1: What -- what's that got to do with me? I'm not running any bookie joint.
Person2: What kind of joint are you running?
Person1: Sir?
Person2: There's a certain key floating around the office -- from Kirkeby to Vanderhof to Eichelberger to Dobisch -- it's the key to a certain apartment -- and you know who that apartment belongs to?
Person1: Who?
Person2: Loyal, cooperative, resourceful C. C. Baxter.
Person1: Oh.
Person2: Are you going to deny it?
Person1: No, sir. I'm not going to deny it. But if you'd just let me explain --
Person2: You better.
Person1: Well, about six months ago -- I was going to night school, taking this course in Advanced Accounting -- and one of the guys in our department -- he lives in Jersey -- he was going to a banquet at the Biltmore -- his wife was meeting him in town, and he needed someplace to change into a tuxedo -- so I gave him the key    and word must have gotten around -- because the next thing I knew, all sorts of guys were suddenly going to banquets -- and when you give the key to one guy, you can't say no to another and the whole thing got out of hand -- pardon me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is admitting to giving out a key to his apartment to colleagues for various reasons, leading to a situation where multiple people were using it without his control.
Intent_p2: Person2 is accusing Person1 of allowing multiple people to use a certain apartment key, leading to a situation where the key was being passed around and misused.

Dialogue:
Person1: You must leave.  You were not here this morning.
Person2: But I didn't do this!
Person1: The police will not know that. They will want to investigate.
Person2: We have his note.
Person1: Do you want to be questioned about you and Mr. Jimmy?  Please, Clayton.  It will be better if I find the body alone.
Person2: But how're you going to explain this?  How did you get him out of the pool?
Person1: You are right.  Yes.  We must put him back.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to leave and not be involved in the situation, suggesting that it would be better if they handle the situation alone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and questioning the plan to put the body back in the pool.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't touch him.
Person2: How many men have we seen die?
Person1: Two.  Gabriel and Thomas.
Person2: They're gone.  And there is nothing you or I can do to bring them back. But there is something you can do to help end all this.
Person1: It is ended.
Person2: No.  It's not over yet.  Two days ride, Yorktown, Virginia. Washington, the French, Cornwallis and Tarleton.  It will end, one way or another.  Francis, nothing will replace your sons but helping us will justify their sacrifice.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a sense of finality and closure, indicating that the situation has already been resolved.
Intent_p2: Person2 is urging Person1 to join a mission to Yorktown, Virginia, emphasizing that helping to end the conflict there will honor the sacrifice of their fallen sons.

Dialogue:
Person1: See, in that crisis, I saw an opportunity.  For some real growth.
Person2: Oh please.
Person1: Be quiet. I didn't go behind your back.
Intent_p1: Person1 is explaining that they viewed a crisis as an opportunity for significant personal development and growth.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing skepticism or disbelief towards Person1's claim of not going behind their back.

Dialogue:
Person1: Turn that off!  Get the bags.
Person2: Why should I carry your bag?  I am not a dog.
Person1: For five years I paid for your stupidness - you'll carry my bag for the rest of my life if I say so.  Unless you refuse, Oleg.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their authority and demanding that Person2 carry their bag as a form of repayment for past support.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing resistance to being treated like a servant or being controlled by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Frank gone?
Person2: Yeah, but get outta here. He's comin' back.
Person1: Bull.
Person2: Alright, suit yourself.
Person1: He's comin' back? What for?
Person2: 'Cause he's comin' back, that's what for. Frank's got you really loaded tonight.
Person1: Yeah, maybe so. Frank's got me, and you and really it's all thanks to Don, isn't it. Remember that. Your husband was the one who started messing with my mind with drugs.
Person2: Oh he forced you, huh?
Person1: He's the reformed dealer though who wanted to turn himself in. He's the one that caused Frank to come and Frank's messing us real good. I just feel so desperate. I'm supposed to be here watching you why can't I be here with you. Listen. I know his size is the size of a pin - let me give you the real thing. Let me wet my whistle, baby.
Person2: No way, get out. I'm gonna tell Frank. I'm gonna tell him what you said.
Person1: Okay, I'm goin'. You'll see, I'll get you.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses frustration and desperation over being manipulated by drugs and the situation involving Frank and Don, ultimately indicating a desire for revenge.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to reject Person1's advances and threats, and to warn them to leave before informing Frank about their behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: Once it's spent you won't have to worry about it.
Person2: Be like a weight off your shoulders.
Person1: You know we're right.
Person2: Don't you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is reassuring Person2 that once the money is spent, they won't have to worry about it anymore.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that once the money is spent, it will feel like a relief or burden lifted off your shoulders.

Dialogue:
Person1: Give me the keys, Dignan.
Person2: I can't do that, Bob.
Person1: Dignan. You're going to give me those keys or you're going to get hurt.
Person2: Don't threaten me, Bob.
Person1: Goddammit, Dignan! It's my car! If you don't give me my keys, I swear to God --
Intent_p1: Person1 is demanding the keys to their car from Person2 and is becoming increasingly frustrated and threatening in their tone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is standing their ground and refusing to give Person1 the keys despite the threat of getting hurt.

Dialogue:
Person1: Esperanza, have you forgotten what it was like before the union came?  When Estella was a baby, and we couldn't even afford a doctor when she got sick? It was for our families! We met in graveyards to build that union!
Person2: All right. Have your strike. I'll have my baby. But no hospital will take me, because I'll be a striker's wife. The store will cut off our credit, and the kids will go hungry. And we'll get behind on the payments again, and then they'll come and take away the radio...
Person1: Is that all you care about? That radio? Can't you think of anything except yourself?
Person2: If I think of myself it's because you never think of me. Never. Never. Never...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disappointment towards Person2 for being self-centered and not considering the sacrifices made for the benefit of their family and community through the union.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies frustration and resentment towards Person1 for not considering their needs and sacrifices, leading them to prioritize their own well-being in the face of potential hardships.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why did you send that message to Sarah?
Person2: Think about it, Ella. Why would I risk our secret?
Person1: You promised you wouldn't!
Person2: You made me do this. If you hadn't pushed me so much, it wouldn't have come to this.
Person1: You can't blame me for your choices, Victor.
Person2: Every action has its consequences, Ella. Remember that.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's decision to send a message to Sarah despite their promise to keep a secret.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that Person1's actions led to the consequences they are facing.

Dialogue:
Person1: What about money?
Person2: What about it?
Person1: I don't have any.
Person2: Use my credit cards.
Person1: I can't do that.
Person2: Why not?
Person1: It's illegal.
Person2: Who cares?
Person1: I'll get in trouble.
Person2: You are in trouble. Now do it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their reluctance to use Person2's credit cards due to the illegality of the action.
Intent_p2: Person2 is pressuring Person1 to use their credit cards despite the potential legal consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: I can't believe you went through my phone without asking!
Person2: I was just looking for the restaurant's number. It's not a big deal.
Person1: It's about privacy, Sophie.
Person2: You are overreacting. I had no bad intentions.
Person1: It's still a boundary, and I need you to respect it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their concern about privacy and setting a boundary regarding their phone being accessed without permission.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to downplay the situation by stating that they had innocent intentions when looking through the phone.

Dialogue:
Person1: Guess I made a boo-boo, huh?
Person2: No -- I like it.
Person1: Really? You mean you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with somebody in a hat like this?
Person2: Of course not.
Person1: Maybe if I wore it a little more to the side --  is that better?
Person2: Much better.
Person1: Well, as long as you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with me -- how about the three of us going out this evening -- you and me and the bowler -- stroll down Fifth Avenue -- sort of break it in --
Person2: This is a bad day for me.
Person1: I understand. Christmas -- family and all that --
Person2: I'd better get back to my elevator. I don't want to be fired.
Person1: Oh, you don't have to worry about that. I have quite a bit of influence in Personnel. You know Mr. Sheldrake?
Person2: Why?
Person1: He and I are like this.  Sent me a Christmas card. See?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to reassure Person2 that they have influence in the company and can prevent them from getting fired, while also suggesting going out together with the hat.
Intent_p2: Person2 appreciates Person1's gesture and reassurance but is trying to politely decline their invitation to go out, as they need to return to work and do not want to risk getting fired.

Dialogue:
Person1: Excuse... excuse me, when do I go on?
Person2: Who are you?
Person1: Alvy... Alvy Singer. I'm a comedian.
Person2: Oh, comedian. Yes. Oh, uh... you're on next.
Person1: What do you mean, next?
Person2: Uh ... I mean you're on right after this act.
Person1: No, it can't be, because he's a comic.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: So what are you telling me, you're putting on two comics in a row?
Person2: Why not?
Person1: No, I'm sorry, I'm not goin'- I can't... I don't wanna go on after that comedian.
Person2: It's okay.
Person1: No, because they're-they're laughing, so  I-I-I'd rather not. If you don't mind, I prefer-
Person2: Will you relax, please? They're gonna love you, I know.
Person1: I prefer not to, because... look, they're laughing at him. See, so what are yuh telling me-
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing reluctance to perform as a comedian after another comic act because the audience is already laughing at the previous act.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to reassure Person1 that the audience will enjoy their performance despite following another comedian.

Dialogue:
Person1: -- Listen, I'm supposed to take Jill to El Cholo tonight. She's really going to be pissed if I don't.
Person2: -- Maybe she'll come with us. If I tell her how important it is to me, I don't think she'll mind. Do you?
Person1: I don't know. Probably not.
Person2: Jill's really great, isn't she?
Person1: Great... so how's everything with you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about potentially disappointing Jill by not taking her to El Cholo and is unsure if she would be understanding if she were to join them instead.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Jill might be understanding and willing to join them at El Cholo if they explain the importance of the event to her.

Dialogue:
Person1: You have to understand. This was a big shock, for all of us. One minute you're our little boy, of whom we could not be more proud. The next minute you're the owner of this whole pornographic empire.
Person2: But that doesn't make you the boss of everything, son.
Person1: Don't you see how your self involvement and lack of humility are affecting the whole family?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their shock and disappointment at their son's sudden transformation from a source of pride to the owner of a pornographic empire, and is concerned about the negative impact of his self-involvement and lack of humility on the family.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convey to Person1 that despite their success, they should not let it go to their head and act as if they are in control of everything.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh my God, does this mean you're becoming normal?
Person2: It means that Gigglepuss is playing at Club Skunk and we're going.
Person1: Oh, I thought you might have a date  I don't know why I'm bothering to ask, but are you going to Bogey Lowenstein's party Saturday night?
Person2: What do you think?
Person1: I think you're a freak.  I think you do this to torture me.  And I think you suck.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disappointment towards Person2 for not attending Bogey Lowenstein's party and accuses them of intentionally causing distress.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they will not be attending Bogey Lowenstein's party on Saturday night.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, the light caught the side of his face for a second. And it looked like he had a gray beard, maybe... late fifties, early sixties.
Person2: So you're telling me it was one guy with six guns? And he was a senior citizen?
Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person2: I'll see what I can do. How do I get in touch with you?
Person1: We're going to hit Poppa Joe tonight, right in the comfort of his own home. Then we move on to New York. It's getting a bit hot for us here.
Person2: Be careful.
Person1: I'll call you tonight, afterwards.
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to locate and confront a potentially dangerous individual before they are found again, and plans to carry out a criminal act before leaving town due to increasing risks.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the possibility of a senior citizen being the suspect with six guns and expresses concern for Person1's safety in their upcoming plan.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, you can't stay here. Just take your champagne and go.
Person2: Baxter, I don't want to pull rank on you -- but I told the lady it was all set -- you want to make a liar out of me?
Person1: Are you going to leave, Mr. Kirkeby, or do I have to throw you out?
Intent_p1: Person1 is demanding that Person2 leave the premises and questioning if they will comply or need to be forcibly removed.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reminding Person1 of their previous agreement and subtly asserting their authority to stay.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, guess what? I found Betty... where she's been, anyway.
Person2: Where? Where is she?
Person1: I'm not telling.
Person2: What?
Person1: I'm not telling until you get yourself together. You've been acting erratically on me, and this needs to stop, or you can forget about your Betty... I mean it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration with Person2's erratic behavior and is withholding information about Betty's whereabouts until Person2 improves their behavior.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and setting a boundary with Person1, insisting that they need to stop acting erratically before being given information about Betty's whereabouts.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey, remember that time you borrowed a hundred bucks from me and promised to pay it back by the end of the month?
Person2: Hmm, I don't recall that ever happening.
Person1: Seriously? We were at Joe's party, and you were practically begging for it.
Person2: Joe's party? Oh, that was such a crazy night. But I really don't remember any borrowing.
Person1: Come on, it was just last month. You even said you'd pay me back with interest.
Person2: Interest? Are you sure you're not mixing me up with someone else? I think you might be mistaken.
Person1: I distinctly remember you promising, and I could use that money now.
Person2: I wish I could help, but I don't recall that ever happening. Maybe it was someone else who borrowed from you.
Person1: Fine, forget it. But you better remember next time when you need a favor from me.
Person2: Oh, don't worry, I'll remember when it suits me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is reminding Person2 about borrowing money at a party and expressing frustration that Person2 does not remember the agreement.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to deny borrowing money from Person1 and to avoid taking responsibility for the debt.

Dialogue:
Person1: I've known soldiers who've had their heads blown off who were more intelligent than you two.  Not only have you failed to protect your most valuable possession from theft - but you didn't even know it'd been stolen!  I'd sooner buy heroin from the guy who sells drugs outside my grandson's school than anything from you guys.
Person2: I am sorry you feel that way.
Person1: And I'm sorry you look that way, short-ass.  That suit stinks and you obviously dye your hair.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement is intended to express extreme disappointment and disdain towards Person2 and another individual for their incompetence and lack of awareness.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses regret for Person1's negative feelings and insults.

Dialogue:
Person1: And the January Semi-formal --
Person2: Okay!  Look, Buffy.  You want to play house with the unwashed masses, that's fine.  But personally, I think you ought to spend a little time prioritizing.  I really do.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2 should prioritize their activities instead of attending the January Semi-formal event.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1 should prioritize their activities and focus on more important things rather than participating in social events.

Dialogue:
Person1: You take all my money, but you're borrowing part of it?
Person2: At eighteen percent, okay? And don't ask me no more questions. I'm leaving.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration about Person2 borrowing money from them while also taking all of their money.
Intent_p2: Person2 is justifying the borrowing of money at an interest rate of eighteen percent and is refusing to entertain any further questions on the matter.

Dialogue:
Person1: Is there something I can do for you?
Person2: Yes... you run this hotel.
Person1: Oh, yes!
Person2: Would you tell me, who has the room on the second floor in the corner, that corner?
Person1: Oh, I'm afraid we couldn't give out information of that sort. Our clients are entitled to their privacy, you know. And I do believe it's against the law! Of course, I don't think any of them would mind, really, but still I would have to know who you are, and ask --
Intent_p1: Person1 is politely declining to provide information about the guest in the room on the second floor, emphasizing the importance of privacy and legal restrictions.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asking Person1 to disclose information about the guest staying in a specific room on the second floor of the hotel.

Dialogue:
Person1: I believe you.
Person2: Thanks very much.
Person1: Oh, you've got the money all right -- you just don't know you've got it.
Person2: Mr. Bartholomew -- if I had a quarter of a million dollars, believe me, I'd know it.
Person1: Nevertheless, Mrs Lampert -- you've got it.
Person2: You mean it's just lying around someplace -- all that cash?
Person1: Or a safe deposit key, a certified check, a baggage claim -- you look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm quite sure you'll find it.
Person2: But --
Person1: Look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- look just as hard and as fast as you can. You may not have a great deal of time. Those men know you have it just as surely as we do. You won't be safe until the money's in our hands. Is that clear?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convey to Person2 that she possesses a large sum of money unknowingly and must urgently locate it to ensure her safety from dangerous individuals who are aware of its existence.
Intent_p2: Person2 is being urged to search for the money quickly and thoroughly because their safety depends on retrieving it before the men who are after it find it.

Dialogue:
Person1: You almost sound like that guy from THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT CARRIE. Ben. Ben Damon.
Person2: Well ya got me. That's me. I'm Ben Damon.
Person1: Really? You're such a talented actor.
Person2: Thanks.
Person1: Now let's see you act your way out of this one.
Intent_p1: Person1 is playfully challenging Person2 to act their way out of a situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is being playfully challenged to act his way out of a situation by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Give me a little credit for doing this face-to-face!  What I went through knowing I was going to do this to my mentor!  Can you get past yourself for a second?
Person2: You'll lose.
Person1: You wanted smaller.
Person2: I'm over it.  Now I want all my clients and yours too.
Person1: Jerry --
Person2: -- and I'll get 'em.
Person1: You'll always be my hero, Jerry. Always always always.  We're bringing other elements in, we're focusing on endorsements -- it's not about handholding anymore. We're no longer babysitters --
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and seeking recognition for the difficult decision they made to confront their mentor face-to-face and is urging Person2 to acknowledge their efforts.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a competitive and determined attitude, indicating a desire to surpass Person1 in acquiring clients and shifting the focus of their work.

Dialogue:
Person1: What I'm trying to say is that -- I'm not sure I can do this, help you, unless I know more about you.
Person2: What do you want to know?
Person1: If Bain hadn't taken the contract on me, would you have?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's loyalty and commitment by asking if they would have helped if another person had not taken the contract.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asking for clarification on whether Person1 would have helped them if another individual had not taken the contract.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're talking an incredible amount of nonsense, Susan.  Whatever I do -  I do - because I love you.
Person2: Love!  You don't love anybody!  Me or anybody else!  You want to be loved - that's all you want!  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  Whatever you want - just name it and it's yours! Only love me!  Don't expect me to love you -
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that their actions are driven by love for Susan, despite being accused of not truly loving anyone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing skepticism towards Person1's claim of love, suggesting that Person1 is more interested in being loved rather than genuinely loving others.

Dialogue:
Person1: I wanted to talk.
Person2: I don't think we have anything to talk about.
Person1: What about us?
Person2: There is no us, remember?
Person1: Except I can't get you out of my head, Grace.
Person2: Stop it.
Person1: Why?  Am I making you hot, or does the truth scare you?
Person2: Because I know you're full of shit.
Person1: I mean it, Grace.  I'm getting out of here, and I want to take you with me.
Person2: I thought you couldn't get your car.
Person1: I could if I had Jake's money.
Person2: Is that what changed your mind?  The money?
Person1: I don't give a damn about the money.  I want you, and I want to get us out of this shithole.  There's only one way to do that.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a desire to leave their current situation and take Person2 with them, emphasizing their feelings for Person2 and their intention to escape together.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to question Person1's motives and sincerity in wanting to leave the situation they are in together.

Dialogue:
Person1: What did you do tonight?
Person2: I watched TV.
Person1: What did you watch?
Person2: I don't remember Michael, go to sleep.  You don't have to make conversation with me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to engage in conversation with Person2 about what they watched on TV that night.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to dismiss Person1's questions and end the conversation by suggesting they go to sleep.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, I just wanted to say, I think it's great you're riding again. And... and I think I know why you, you needed to do it alone... without anyone knowing...
Person2: Yeah, you know everything!!
Person1: STOP IT! Why can't I talk to you!!
Person2: NO, YOU STOP IT! Stop pretending like you care! Like this really isn't about you and Tom.
Person1: WHAT?! How can you --  I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom bothers you so much, but I happen to value having someone to talk to, especially when my own daughter ignores me night and day because no matter what I say, it's wrong and no matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm sorry I'm such a disappointment to you.
Person2: Well, now you know what it feels like.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their feelings of being ignored and undervalued by their daughter and seeking solace in their friendship with Tom.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they want Person1 to understand and empathize with the feelings of disappointment and neglect that they have experienced.

Dialogue:
Person1: Then I'm out. I don't give a shit about you or this run.
Person2: It's so easy for you, isn't it? You let Linda Lee die in Chiba City. Now you leave me with Molly, one more lamb to the slaughter. Perhaps it's _your_ soul that should be in question, Mr. Case.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their indifference and lack of concern for Person2 and the situation they are in.
Intent_p2: Person2 is accusing Person1 of being callous and irresponsible for abandoning them and putting others in danger, suggesting that Person1's morality and conscience should be questioned.

Dialogue:
Person1: You have no right to do this.
Person2: Well if I don't who will?
Person1: They're happy like this.
Person2: David, nobody's happy in a Poodle skirt and a sweater set.  You like all this don't you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that the person they are speaking to does not have the authority to make a certain decision.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that the current situation is not ideal and that they are the one who will take action to change it.

Dialogue:
Person1: I was thinking about our conversation the other day -- what you said about choices.
Person2: Uh huh.
Person1: Yeah, you know, that in life you really have to choose what you want to do.
Person2: Listen, I'm sorry, but it's really late -- you don't have to come tomorrow to work on the floor.
Person1: It is tomorrow.
Intent_p1: Person1 is reflecting on the importance of making choices in life.
Intent_p2: Person2 is informing Person1 that they do not have to come to work the next day because it is already tomorrow.

Dialogue:
Person1: I've got you, Dr. Evil!
Person2: Well done, Mr. Powers. We're not so different, you and I. It's true, you're British, and I'm Belgian. You have a full head of hair, mine is slightly receding. You're thin, I'm about forty pounds overweight. OK, we are different, I'm not making a very good point. However, isn't it ironic, Mr. Powers, that the very things you stand for-- swinging, free love, parties, distrust of authority- are all now, in the Nineties, considered to be... evil? Maybe we have more in common than you care to admit.
Person1: No, man, what we swingers were rebelling against were uptight squares like you, whose bag was money and world domination. We were innocent, man. If we'd known the consequences of our sexual liberation, we would have done things differently, but the spirit would have remained the same.  It's freedom, man.
Person2: Your freedom has cause more pain and suffering in the world than any plan I ever dreamed of. Face it, freedom failed.
Person1: That's why right now is a very groovy time, man. We still have freedom, but we also have responsibility.
Person2: Really, there's nothing more pathetic than an aging hipster.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting that the spirit of rebellion and freedom in the past was innocent and well-intentioned, but acknowledges the unintended consequences and emphasizes the importance of balancing freedom with responsibility in the present.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they believe the consequences of freedom and rebellion have caused more harm than any evil plan they had envisioned, suggesting that freedom has failed.

Dialogue:
Person1: Addison wants me to play it.
Person2: Over my dead body...
Person1: That won't be necessary. Addison knows how Margo happen to miss that performance - how I happened to know she'd miss it in time to call him and notify every paper in town...  ... it's quite a story. Addison could make quite a thing of it - imagine how snide and vicious he could get and still write nothing but the truth. I had a time persuading him...  ... you'd better sit down. You look a bit wobbly.  If I play "Cora," Addison will never tell what happened - in or out of print. A simple exchange of favors. And I'm so happy I can do something for you - at long last...  Your friendship with Margo - your deep, close friendship - what would happen to it, do you think, if she knew the chap trick you'd played on her - for my benefit? And you and Lloyd - how long, even in the Theater, before people forgot what happened - and trusted you again?  No... it would be so much easier on everyone concerned, if I were to play "Cora." And so much better theater, too...
Intent_p1: Person1 is manipulating Person2 into allowing them to play a role in the theater production by threatening to expose a secret that would damage their relationships and reputation.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to manipulate Person1 into letting them play the role of "Cora" by subtly threatening to expose their deceitful actions and potentially ruin their relationships and reputation.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know, this, what you're doing with your life...
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: You know, it's not you. You know? You seem like a smart guy.
Person2: Yeah, well, thank you for the advice, but you wouldn't understand what is going on with me.
Person1: Oh, it's very complicated, huh?
Person2: That's right.
Person1: Complicated or not, life moves on. Hm?
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting to Person2 that they seem capable and intelligent, implying that they may not be living up to their potential.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that the complexity of their situation is beyond the understanding of Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh, you're the great Joe's attorney now?  Are we going to go to court? Or are we going to go to bed?  And I don't mean you and me.  I mean you and him.
Person2: That's it.  It's over.  Get out.
Person1: So I guess a blowjob's out of the question?
Intent_p1: Person1 is making inappropriate and disrespectful comments towards Person2, insinuating a sexual relationship between Person2 and Joe.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to firmly end the conversation and ask Person1 to leave.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why do you do this Lestat?
Person2: I like to do it. I enjoy it. Take you aesthete's taste to purer things. Kill them swiftly if you will, but do it! For now doubt, you are a killer Louis. Ah!
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Lestat's actions and motives, expressing concern and confusion about his behavior.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their enjoyment and preference for killing swiftly and urging Person1 to embrace their true nature as a killer.

Dialogue:
Person1: I love that youre asking questions, but do you really want to get into all of this?
Person2: This is awkward for me.  Talking about it makes me feel better.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about delving into a potentially uncomfortable topic despite appreciating Person2's willingness to ask questions.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that despite feeling awkward, discussing the topic makes them feel better.

Dialogue:
Person1: "The Angel of Flight 104!"  You're telling me you're the A...?
Person2: "Angel!"  I didn't say "angel," that's a little strong.  Listen, here's the thing, I gotta get over there to the TV station to collect my million bucks.
Person1: Mister LaPlante, I really want to help you, but crazy stories are only going to make it worse.  The D.A. is asking your bail be set at twenty-five thousand dollars because you were arrested again while you were out on bail...
Person2: Twenty-five grand is peanuts!  All you gotta do is get me outta here long enough to collect.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing skepticism and concern about Person2's outlandish claims and legal troubles.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing urgency and determination to get out of jail quickly in order to collect a million dollars from the TV station.

Dialogue:
Person1: Who are you?
Person2: My name's Lydia.  And it seems you and I have a lot in common.
Person1: You said you knew where my fiance was the other night.
Person2: With me, where he's been after work, three, sometimes four nights a week for the last two months... We have what you might call an intimate relationship.
Person1: How do I know you're telling the truth?
Person2: He been sleeping in a T-shirt lately?  That's so you won't see the fingernail marks on his back.  Bet you didn't know your boyfriend finds a little pain exciting.  He didn't either...at first.
Person1: Look, I don't know what you want--
Person2: I thought it was important for you to know the facts.
Person1: And so should you.  Sketchy told me I could expect a visit from you.  I know all about how you threatened him.  That if he didn't break it off with me, you'd save him the trouble.
Person2: Oh?
Person1: Well, it's over between you and him. We're getting married next month.
Person2: How sweet.  Standing by your man, even after what he did.  You're a very understanding person.
Person1: Big part of loving someone's being able to forgive them.
Person2: You're also a fool.
Person1: I think you should go now.
Person2: Not before we get something straight you prissy little bitch.  I decide when I'm done with your boyfriend.  Not him, and certainly not you.  Unless maybe you want to find out just how sharp these nails really are.
Intent_p1: Person1 is confronting Person2 about their relationship with their fiance and asserting their authority in the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a threatening and possessive attitude towards Person1's fiance, asserting control over the relationship and displaying a willingness to use force if necessary.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well this hasn't happened yet.
Person2: Wait a minute, the fourteenth, that's the same day the worm ends its run.  I mean... Da Vinci virus, didn't Phreak say that's what he was being charged with? Look...  "Infecting ballast programs of Ellingson tankers" - they blame hackers!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise or disbelief about a situation that has not yet occurred.
Intent_p2: Person2 is connecting the date of the fourteenth with the end of a computer worm's activity and suggesting a possible link to the charges against Phreak for hacking into Ellingson tankers' systems.

Dialogue:
Person1: A name. Grunemann. Nothing. And they showed me pictures like this and they meant nothing. Then they asked me, well had I been getting letters, from someone out there in Cabbageville --
Person2: -- Tuscarora --
Person1: All right, yes, I had been. Those sick, wild letters -- I'm watching you, gonna follow you, gonna punish you, kill you et cetera. Well, they said, all right that's Grunemann. So try to remember when you and he - when -- well I don't know, there was that dumper once, he sounded like that dumper --  Dumpers; they get their kicks beating you up. A man hired me once, then tried to really kill me - that'd be about two years ago.
Intent_p1: Person1 is recounting a situation where they were shown pictures and asked about receiving threatening letters, leading to a discussion about a past encounter with someone who tried to harm them.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "Tuscarora" indicates a correction or clarification of the location mentioned by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: My generosity is not so large as that.
Person2: What do you want with me?
Person1: Your love.
Person2: Your words sting more sharply than your whip.
Person1: I speak of love, and you think only of the lash.
Person2: You are cruel!  Your heartless jesting worse than torture!  How can you speak of love when you see what I am!
Person1: I like well what I see.  It pleases me.
Person2: But I'm hideous!
Person1: You're magnificent.
Person2: Grotesque... monstrous...
Person1: On the contrary!  The puling, pallid creature you were before was truly something disgusting.  Now you are splendid... a fierce goddess... the embodiment of all that is strong and beautiful.
Person2: You lie!  You wish to humiliate me, as if the form I'm forced to bear were not punishment enough!
Person1: You should glory in your animal nature.  It is your triumph!  None know that better than I!
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convey to Person2 that they find them beautiful and magnificent in their current form, encouraging them to embrace their animal nature as a triumph.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses disbelief and self-loathing, feeling that Person1's compliments are insincere and meant to further degrade them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later.
Person2: Ok, have fun there, you're so lucky you don't have any kids yet and you can go off to Japan... call me when you get back.
Person1: Ok, bye.
Intent_p1: Person1 is politely downplaying their upcoming trip to Japan and ending the conversation with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing envy towards Person1 for being able to travel to Japan without any kids and is looking forward to hearing from them upon their return.

Dialogue:
Person1: Bullshit. I see you look at everything, study everything, ask questions. I know exactly what you're doing. Empty your pockets.
Person2: You've got to relax, baby, you're paranoid.
Intent_p1: Person1 is accusing Person2 of being suspicious and secretive, prompting them to empty their pockets.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to calm Person1 down by suggesting that they are being overly suspicious and anxious.

Dialogue:
Person1: I mean, you blew off our date at last minute.
Person2: So you hop on to the next best thing? I thought you were different from other guys.
Person1: I am different, it's just that I just got pissed off...that's all.
Person2: Oh really? Well, I'll just let you get back to little Ms. Hot panties.
Intent_p1: Person1 is explaining that their reaction was due to feeling upset about being stood up for the date.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disappointment and frustration with Person1's behavior and implying that they are moving on from the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey look, I got some business down in San Diego. Whattaya say you come with me, stay a few days?
Person2: No, Harry, I can't --
Person1: You're coming.
Intent_p1: Person1 is insisting that Person2 accompany them on a trip to San Diego despite any objections.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express their inability or reluctance to go to San Diego with Person1, but Person1 insists that they will come along.

Dialogue:
Person1: They've taken my mind, my memories...
Person2: What?  Who has?
Person1: Is that your idea of a joke?  I don't remember...  Take my advice, Bumstead.  Get off this case.  Now.
Person2: What is going on?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing distress and confusion about their lost memories and is warning Person2 to stop investigating the case they are involved in.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing confusion and seeking clarification about the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: What are you crazy kids doing in my tool shed?
Person2: We're not crazy. We're "special". PRINCIPAL COLLINS wants us to have our own classroom!
Person1: My boy's special, well how about that. I knew you were different.
Person2: So I guess you'll need a new spot for your moonshine.
Person1: I reckon so.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging the uniqueness of the kids and agreeing to find a new spot for their activities.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that they are not crazy but "special" and that the principal wants them to have their own classroom.

Dialogue:
Person1: You can't do this!  You owe me, O'Brien.  I made you plastic!  I made you!
Person2: That's right.  And making me was the biggest mistake you ever made!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and a sense of entitlement towards Person2, emphasizing their role in shaping Person2's identity and abilities.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting that being made by Person1 was a mistake.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm out here for you!  You don't know what it's like to be me out here for you. It is an up-at-dawn pride-swallowing seige that I will never fully tell you about! Okay?! Help me help you help me help you.
Person2: You're hanging by a very thin thread, dude.  And I dig that about you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their deep commitment and sacrifice in supporting Person2, while also hinting at the emotional toll it takes on them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is acknowledging Person1's vulnerability and admiring their resilience in a challenging situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Huh? Try and find a raincoat in Brazil. Even when it isn't raining  Lisa, on this job you carry one suitcase. Your home is the available transportation. You sleep rarely, bathe even less, and sometime the food you even look at when they were alive!
Person2: Jeff, you don't have to be deliberately repulsive just to impress me I'm wrong.
Person1: If anything, I'm making it sound good.  Let's face it, Lisa... you aren't made for that kind of a life. Few people are.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Lisa is not suited for a challenging and demanding lifestyle that involves constant travel and minimal personal care.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Person1 is trying too hard to be unappealing in order to prove a point, but it is unnecessary.

Dialogue:
Person1: You said "the Commander.
Person2: What?
Person1: Back there. You said "the Commander is down there with a bunch of cannibals."
Person2: No I didn't.
Person1: Yes you did.
Intent_p1: Person1 is accusing Person2 of making a statement about the Commander being with cannibals, which Person2 denies.
Intent_p2: Person2 denies making the statement about the Commander being with cannibals.

Dialogue:
Person1: Chicken is a fool's game captain.
Person2: So is violating international law.
Person1: But you invited is aboard.
Person2: Your cannons made a compelling argument.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that engaging in a risky or foolish activity like chicken is not wise, even though they were persuaded to participate.
Intent_p2: Person2 is pointing out the hypocrisy of Person1 criticizing chicken as a fool's game while also acknowledging their own violation of international law.

Dialogue:
Person1: Eddie, you've got to get me out of here.
Person2: Not again.  You can't keep calling. Somebody's going to catch on to where you are.
Person1: But I'm going insane!  All these people do is pray and work, work and pray!  I don't get it -- when's the weekend? They have gruel, Eddie, that's what they call food!  Gruel -- it's like Alpo for nuns! I sleep in a cell, on a board, and I pray five times a days  Do you know what I pray for, Eddie, do you have any idea? Check your crotch, Eddie --anything fall off yet?  Get me outta her!
Person2: Calm down.  Look, I didn't want to tell you this, but we've had some problems with our protection program lately.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Keeping our witnesses alive.  We hide them, but there's a leak in the department, and they end up dead.
Person1: You son-of-a-bitch!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and desperation to Person2, asking to be rescued from a situation where they are being held against their will.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that there have been issues with the witness protection program, leading to the deaths of those they were supposed to protect.

Dialogue:
Person1: No, Wes.
Person2: Jessica was never any good for Paul.  You will be, you are.  And Mother -- seeing Jessica day after day -- never able to escape, never able to forget.  Please, Betsy -- it's only merciful.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their disagreement with Person2's suggestion to end a relationship with Jessica for the sake of Paul's well-being.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convince Betsy that she would be a better match for Paul than Jessica, and that it would be merciful to end the relationship with Jessica.

Dialogue:
Person1: It's just money.  You should be glad you're alive.
Person2: It might be best if we didn't talk.
Person1: All I mean is... someone like you...
Person2: How many times have you done this? I'm interested.
Person1: What?
Person2: Scams, con games.  How many?
Person1: I don't know.  A lot.
Person2: Whatever kind of nickel-and-dime shit you did before, this is more than just me.  Your friends raided pension plans, and payrolls... they took just over six-hundred million.  You ruined people's lives.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to downplay the significance of money and emphasize the value of life, but Person2 confronts them about their involvement in serious financial crimes that have harmed others.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to confront Person1 about their involvement in scams and the serious consequences of their actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jack and Bobby are good men. But it takes a certain character, moral toughness to stand up to --
Person2: -- You listen to me. Nobody, nobody, talks about my friends that way. You're here right now because of the Kennedys. They may be wrong. They make mistakes. But they're not weak. The weak ones are these 'people' who can't speak their own minds.
Person1: You know I don't mean they're weak.
Intent_p1: Person1 is clarifying that they did not intend to imply that Jack and Bobby are weak, but rather that it takes a certain character and moral toughness to stand up to certain challenges.
Intent_p2: Person2 is defending their friends, the Kennedys, by emphasizing their strength and character in the face of criticism.

Dialogue:
Person1: Keep stallin'.
Person2: Alright, I'm coming...hold on.
Intent_p1: Person1 is telling Person2 to delay or procrastinate.
Intent_p2: Person2 is acknowledging the request to hurry up and indicating that they are on their way.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm glad to hear that Zoe's okay.
Person2: Are you still in touch?
Person1: Not really.  The last time I saw her was at that clinic.  That was a long time ago.
Person2: Which one?
Person1: Which one?
Person2: Which clinic?
Person1: I don't remember the name.  It was near a beach.
Person2: Sunnyridge.  That was a long time
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing relief about Zoe's well-being but indicates that they are no longer in touch with her and last saw her at a clinic near a beach a long time ago.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to confirm if the clinic Person1 is referring to is Sunnyridge Clinic.

Dialogue:
Person1: Sandro ... maybe it's best that you go in alone.
Person2: Are you joking?
Person1: Don't think that I want to save myself from any embarrassment, from the awkwardness of meeting Anna... It's not that; it's that you can say certain things easier if you're alone. Please, Sandro, do try to understand me... It would look like I was trying to influence you, to force you, to control you... and that makes me feel uncomfortable...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their discomfort with potentially influencing or controlling Person2's actions in a sensitive situation and suggests that it might be better for Person2 to handle it alone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and questioning the suggestion that they should go in alone, as they feel uncomfortable with the idea of potentially being perceived as trying to influence or control Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!
Person2: What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
Person1: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?
Person2: Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: I happen to know Sweeney was married only three months ago. If he's got twins this morning, I claim it was done with mirrors.
Person1: All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.
Person2: We're not interested.
Person1: Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing guilt and remorse over the consequences of their actions and trying to make amends by offering a business proposition to Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is sarcastically dismissing Person1's emotional outburst and suggesting that the situation is either a performance or a miraculous event, implying skepticism towards the sincerity of the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yes... the Beautiful Carlotta... the Sad Carlotta...
Person2: What does a big old wooden house on the corner of Eddy and Gough Street have to do with her?
Person1: It was hers. It was built for her. Many years ago.
Person2: By whom?
Person1: By... no... the name I do not remember. A rich man, a powerful man.  It is not an unusual story. She came from somewhere small, to the south of the city... some say from a mission settlement... young, yes; very young.  And she was found singing and dancing in a cabaret by the man... wait... wait... Ives! His name was Ives!  Yes. And he took her and built for her this great house in the Western Addition... and there was a child. Yes. This was it. The child.
Intent_p1: Person1 is recounting the story of Carlotta, a young woman who was discovered in a cabaret by a wealthy man named Ives, who then built a grand house for her in the Western Addition where she lived with their child.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the connection between Carlotta and the old wooden house on Eddy and Gough Street.

Dialogue:
Person1: No, I don't want to go. I want to stay here.
Person2: I need you.
Person1: Why?
Person2: I can't do it alone. I need you, to be Madeleine for a while. Then, when it's done, we'll both be free.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire to stay and not participate in a plan, while Person2 is trying to convince them to help by taking on a role temporarily for the benefit of both parties.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their need for Person1's help in a situation where they need them to take on a specific role temporarily in order to achieve freedom for both of them.

Dialogue:
Person1: There's lots of things I haven't done, but his ain't high on the list.  Don't take it personally.
Person2: I think you're just a little scared now, about what you might find once the lights go out.  A little scared... and a lot curious.  Maybe more than you want to admit.  But doesn't that turn you on, that curiosity and fear, swirling together?  Think of it as broadening your horizons.
Person1: I like my horizons narrow.
Person2: Your voice is saying no, but your body is saying yes.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a preference for keeping their horizons narrow and not being interested in exploring certain experiences.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1 may be intrigued by the idea of exploring their fears and curiosity, despite verbally denying it.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why is it, do you think, that of all the professions in the world... you chose protection?
Person2: Are you for real?
Person1: You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings, you could have told people their horoscopes on the internet... You could have been one of ten thousand things... but in the end, you chose to protect people. You made that decision... and I find that very, very interesting.  Now all I need is your credit card number.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning why Person2 chose a profession in protection over other potential career paths and finds it intriguing.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies skepticism and disbelief towards Person1's observation and questioning of their choice of profession.

Dialogue:
Person1: Ahh, sunshine.
Person2: You're going to be late if you don't hurry up and change soon.
Person1: Change? What's wrong with what I got on?
Person2: It's dirty laundry for one thing and for another, you still haven't worn the clothes I bought you. You're skating on thin ice already, young man, so I wouldn't push my luck. Now get out of those rags.
Person1: But, mom!
Person2: Besides, those jeans are so tight I can see your penis.
Intent_p1: Person1 is being scolded by Person2 for wearing dirty clothes and not changing into the clothes they bought for them, with the added concern of inappropriate tight clothing.
Intent_p2: Person2 is urging Person1 to change their clothes because they are dirty, unworn, and inappropriate, emphasizing the need to do so promptly.

Dialogue:
Person1: If you really want to do something for me, you can stop making this scene right now.
Person2: Oh God, I can't believe this.
Person1: I'm leaving now. I've assessed the situation and I'm going.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their frustration and desire for Person2 to stop causing a disturbance, indicating that they have decided to leave the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and frustration at the situation unfolding.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't bullshit me! Don't bullshit me!
Person2: You know what I want to hear? I want to hear that you don't love me. If you tell me that, then I'll leave you alone. I won't ask any questions and I won't be in your life.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and demanding honesty from Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 wants Person1 to be honest and tell them that they don't love them so that they can move on and not be a part of their life anymore.

Dialogue:
Person1: Really, why don't you go sit down somewhere?
Person2: I like to work. I don't mind work. It's the least I can do after all you and Mr. Hillyer have done for me.  You're so sweet. There never was nobody like you.
Person1: Well, you run on now.
Person2: Yes, Ma'am.
Intent_p1: Person1 is politely suggesting to Person2 to take a break and relax.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing gratitude and a willingness to work as a way to show appreciation for the kindness and support they have received.

Dialogue:
Person1: Bad luck, I'm afraid.  It's time to die, little bird.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: You should have heeded your pointy- eared pal.  These lips can be murder.
Person2: Then you never loved me?
Person1: Love you?  I loathe your bipedal arrogance, your animal superiority. My only joy is knowing that even now my poison kiss is sucking the life from your ape-like face.
