Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their disdain and hatred towards Person2, reveling in the act of causing harm and death to them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning Person1's true feelings and expressing disbelief at the revelation of their hatred and intention to harm.

Dialogue:
Person1: I heard from Sarah that you were talking about our personal issues at the party.
Person2: I was just venting a bit, I didn't think it would get back to you.
Person1: Are you trying to hurt me? Why would you share our private matters like that?
Person2: I'm sorry, Lisa. It was a mistake. I should have been more considerate.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing hurt and disappointment towards Person2 for sharing their private matters without permission.
Intent_p2: Person2 is apologizing for sharing personal matters without considering the impact it would have on Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: The next few weeks I would like to know where you are all the time.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Just let me know when you are going out and where --
Person2: What if i go out on tricks - you wanna come along? You could sit and read the National Geographic.
Person1: How can you do it to yourself?
Person2: I don't get you.
Person1: Ligourin, how could you do it?
Person2: I told you before, you wouldn't understand.
Person1: You're right, I don't understand. Explain it to me.  You were scared. Arlyn Page, that scared you. Well it should; that's death. So what did you do, you ran straight for it, death. Ligourin kills women.
Person2: No.
Person1: No, no you're right, I'm sorry. He uses women; he lets them kill themselves. Is that how you want it?
Person2: Arlyn was a junkie; I'm not on junk!
Person1: No, you can find some other way.  Explain it to me. Bree, show me any sense to --
Person2: You get the Christ out! You dumb stupid bastard, you don't know anything, you square, you get out! I don't have to show you anything; you get out!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern and confusion about Person2's behavior and choices, particularly in relation to dangerous situations involving women.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express frustration and anger towards Person1 for not understanding their actions and for judging them unfairly.

Dialogue:
Person1: Under the circumstances, I can't fathom what makes Dr. Argon think we are ready for anything bigger.  If C.N.N., or hell, if the E.P.A. knew what was in my basement --
Person2: Is that a threat, Dr. Bright?
Person1: Look, as I have said and will continue to say, the instability of the assembler waste remains my priority --
Person2: While you remain on the staff at Argon Laboratories, your priorities will always be the same as Dr. Argon's priorities.  I imagine that is a simple enough equation for a bright girl like you to figure out.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disbelief at Dr. Argon's decision-making and implying that revealing certain information could potentially change the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that as long as Person1 works at Argon Laboratories, their priorities will align with Dr. Argon's priorities, and they should understand this straightforward concept.

Dialogue:
Person1: You don't understand, I can get us information...
Person2: Listen, this is the time when the big boys have to go to work, okay Honey?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confidence in their ability to gather information, while Person2 is reminding them of the seriousness of the situation and the need for mature action.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that it is time for them to take charge and handle the situation themselves.

Dialogue:
Person1: You guys know my cousin Mikey Sullivan?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: Well you know how he loves animals right? Anyway, last week he's drivin' home...
Person2: What? Come on!
Person1: I'm sorry, 'cause you know Mikey, the guy loves animals, and this is the last person you'd want this to happen to.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about a situation involving their cousin Mikey Sullivan, who loves animals, and is hinting at a negative event that occurred to him.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses disbelief and urgency in response to Person1's statement about Mikey Sullivan's unfortunate situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: There's more!
Person2: I think that's it.
Person1: There's more! There's a couple stuck in there. I know there's more.
Person2: God, I'm telling you, they're out!
Person1: Come on, damn it. Don't get so defensive. It could be stuck in your hair, you know.
Intent_p1: Person1 is insisting that there is more to be found and is encouraging Person2 not to dismiss the possibility of something being stuck in their hair.
Intent_p2: Person2 is frustrated and adamant that there are no more items stuck, despite Person1's insistence.

Dialogue:
Person1: Take care of yourself out there...
Person2: I understand they've got the Indians pretty well in hand...
Person1: Bill...
Person2: Huh?
Person1: Don't get stuck on some glamour puss-
Person2: I'll try.
Person1: You're not such a bargain, you know, conceited and thoughtless and messy-
Person2: Everybody can't be Gregory Peck.
Person1: - you're a setup for some gorgeous wide-eyed young babe.
Person2: How childish are you going to get before you quit it?
Person1: I don't want to be childish, I'd settle for just a few years-
Person2: And cut that out right now.
Person1: Am I going to lose you, Bill? Am I?
Person2: As of this moment you're six years old...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about Person2's behavior and warning them not to get involved with someone who is superficial and may not have their best interests at heart.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are trying to reassure Person1 that they understand the situation regarding the Indians and are willing to comply with their advice.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey, what do you say we call off this little charade of yours over a couple of beers at Trader Jon's...? Come on, man. You're about as close to being officer material as me.
Person2: Sir, this candidate believes he'll make a good officer, sir!
Person1: No way, Mayo. You don't give a shit about anybody but yourself and every single one of your classmates knows it. Think they'd trust you behind the controls of a plane they have to fly in? Hey, man, I figure you for the kind of guy who'd zip off one day in my F-14 and sell it to the Cubans.
Person2: Sir, that's not true! I love my country!
Person1: Sell it to the Air Force, Mayo!
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's integrity and suitability for becoming an officer in the military.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to defend themselves against the accusation of being selfish and untrustworthy by asserting their love for their country and desire to serve as an officer.

Dialogue:
Person1: Mom, I have a real job. I do good things for this community. I help people.
Person2: When I play bridge with all the girls, everyone has what to talk about with their sons. They show pictures. Their sons are lawyers and doctors and Rabbis. Why can't I show a picture?
Person1: So don't show a picture.
Person2: You know my friend Maureen? Her son, the investment banker? He paid for her entire retirement in Boca Raton. What a mench he is. Instead of schleping to save Hanukkah, god forbid you should go back to business school and get an MBA. Maybe then you could send me to Boca, too.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to assert their value and contributions to the community, while also suggesting that Person2 should not compare themselves to others and should focus on their own choices and actions.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement conveys a sense of disappointment and frustration towards Person1 for not pursuing a career path that could potentially lead to financial success and the ability to provide for their parent's retirement like their friend's son.

Dialogue:
Person1: Christ, Jon!  How could you do this to yourself? How could you do this to us?  Do you know -- do you know what he did to me ...?
Person2: Whatever happened, whatever he did -- I know it's my fault and I know I can never make it up to you --
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing shock and disappointment towards Jon for his actions and is hinting at a traumatic experience they went through.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing deep remorse and guilt for their actions, acknowledging the harm they caused and feeling unable to fully repair the damage done.

Dialogue:
Person1: You put this inside your shirt -- when Tiger stabs your stomach -- it's full of pig's blood.  Gushes out everywhere!  It's really impressive.  Fantastic!  Better than the real thing!
Person2: So I pretend I'm dead.  You get gold, what do I get?
Person1: You get to come alive again in the country!
Person2: As, what, 'The Galloping Gladiator?!'
Person1: The point is you get to fight the easy country circuit, the small arenas, relax, live the good life!
Person2: Spend my days beheading country bumpkins?  I don't know, Proximo, who has better wine than you? Besides, I'm beginning to think of the Colosseum as my home.
Person1: But -- you have to go out there! I'll give you more than your one third!  When I get paid... just take the fall!  You're too hurt to fight and the man's a killer!
Person2: Pressures on, eh Proximo?  There's got to be a load of money in this. Why else would you toss a red hot commodity like me out the window?
Person1: It's absolutely not like that!  This is for your own good!  Come on get the rest of your armor on!
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convince Person2 to participate in a staged fight by promising a comfortable life in the country circuit and assuring them that it is for their own benefit.
Intent_p2: Person2 questions their role and compensation in the gladiator fights, expressing reluctance to continue fighting and a desire for a different lifestyle.

Dialogue:
Person1: Nice room. Balcony and everything. Lovely view too.
Person2: Very nice Mitchell turns.
Person1: No thanks?
Person2: Thank you.
Person1: Suppose I hadn't known that immigration inspector? Hadn't put in a good word for you?
Person2: I'm supposing.
Person1: I think you're a nice girl. I like you. But I can read signs if the print is large enough. It was your manner more than the wedding ring that bothered the inspector.  A sort of tenseness, as if you were afraid of something.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their observation and concern about Person2's behavior and the possible reasons behind it.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies gratitude for the help received from Person1 in securing the room and acknowledging the potential concerns raised about their behavior by the immigration inspector.

Dialogue:
Person1: Got her right where you want her, Junior.
Person2: Shut up.
Person1: When you said you'd let 'em go I thought she'd come running right out for sure.
Person2: Shut up and let me think.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise that the person they are talking to did not come out as expected when they said they would let someone go.
Intent_p2: Person2 is frustrated with Person1's comments and wants them to be quiet so they can concentrate on their next move.

Dialogue:
Person1: Nobody wants any more killings; we all agree to that, correct?  That's good.  Now, Eric, you're gonna hand your prisoner over to us.
Person2: Screw you.
Person1: This isn't your concern.  It's over, here and now.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the importance of ending violence and conflict by demanding that Eric hand over the prisoner to prevent further harm.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "Screw you" indicates defiance and refusal to comply with handing over the prisoner.

Dialogue:
Person1: At first, it will hurt you. But you will come to understand and we will be strong together.
Person2: You're crazy. You're all crazy!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that although facing challenges may be painful initially, they believe that through understanding and unity, they can overcome them together.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and frustration towards Person1's statement about enduring pain and becoming stronger together.

Dialogue:
Person1: Our resignations.
Person2: You going rogue on me?
Person1: Maybe.
Person2: What happened, Kittle?  We used to be friends.  You used to know how the game was played.
Person1: You mean taking bribes, and skimming busts and letting hoods walk? You mean not being able to sleep at night after shaking down some honest Joe?
Person2: There was a time when you did things the right way, till you hooked up with that fat-assed-boozehound and the soul-sister.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their disillusionment with the corrupt practices they used to engage in and implying a desire to change their ways.
Intent_p2: Person2 questions Person1's loyalty and integrity, reminiscing about a time when they both upheld ethical standards before insinuating that their behavior changed due to negative influences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Talking to me, dad?
Person2: Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!
Person1: Well, then forget all this stern dad stuff.
Person2: I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to lighten the mood and dismiss the stern attitude of Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a serious tone and urgency in wanting to have a discussion with Person1 while walking home.

Dialogue:
Person1: I know whose blood you need, to end the curse.
Person2: Say the name, or I slit your throat.
Person1: No you won't.
Intent_p1: Person1 is confident that Person2 will not harm them despite the threat.
Intent_p2: Person2 is challenging Person1's assertion that they won't harm them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Mr. President, Hunt wants more money. Another hundred-and-thirty thousand.
Person2: Son of a bitch.
Person1: He says if he doesn't get it right away, he's going to blow us out of the water.  And he means it.  Ever since his wife died in the plane crash, he's been over the edge.
Person2: Pay him.  Pay him what he wants.
Intent_p1: Person1 is informing Person2 that Hunt is demanding more money and threatening to harm them due to personal trauma, prompting Person2 to agree to pay Hunt the requested amount.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing urgency and a willingness to comply with Hunt's demands to prevent a potential threat due to his unstable state following a personal tragedy.

Dialogue:
Person1: You'll be sorry?
Person2: I was angry.
Person1: You're still angry, aren't you? Isn't it true that your whole story is nothing more than a vindictive attempt on your behalf to get back at Miss Lawson?
Person2: No -- she asked me about cocaine.
Person1: I suggest it never happened.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that Person2's story about being asked about cocaine by Miss Lawson is fabricated and never occurred.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that the reason for their actions was not vindictiveness towards Miss Lawson, but rather a response to being asked about cocaine.

Dialogue:
Person1: I missed you.
Person2: It says here you exposed yourself to a group of freshmen girls.
Person1: It was a bratwurst.  I was eating lunch.
Person2: With the teeth of your zipper?
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a humorous explanation for a misunderstanding about an incident involving a bratwurst and a zipper.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the credibility of Person1's explanation for exposing himself to a group of freshmen girls.

Dialogue:
Person1: I hope you're happy!
Person2: This has nothing to do with me, this, uh, drinking, yeah.
Person1: No, this has everything to do with you.
Person2: No, no, she went up by herself. This was not my responsibility.
Person1: Hey it's your roof. It's your problem.  Hi, uh, there's an emergency down at the Circle A on first Street, Yeah, Okay.  You're in trouble now, pal!  Um, send an ambulance 'cause I, I think it's an overdose or something. Okay. Okay.  Jeff, they're coming. Just wait here. I'm gonna go over to Scuff's and see if he's got his truck.  Listen, if she dies, you're gonna be so sorry that you ever showed your brown face in this town!
Intent_p1: Person1 is holding Person2 accountable for the situation and threatening consequences if the person does not take responsibility.
Intent_p2: Person2 is denying responsibility for the situation and trying to shift blame onto someone else.

Dialogue:
Person1: Walter...stay away from me!
Person2: Don't you see Carla?  I made them immortal.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Walter to keep his distance, possibly due to the consequences of Person2's actions in making someone immortal.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to explain to Carla that they have granted immortality to someone, possibly Walter, and is implying that this should change Carla's perspective on the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: I should check on Anna.
Person2: Check the monitor, she's fine.
Person1: She's far from "fine."
Person2: You're needed here--keep watching--
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about Anna's well-being and believes that she is not fine despite what the monitor may show.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the importance of Person1 staying focused on their current task and not getting distracted by Anna's situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: George, uh... you're gonna break his little chest bones...
Person2: Stay out of this, Matthew.  Tell me where the drug has been taken or I will crush your lungs against this wall.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the potential harm that may come to someone's chest bones in the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is threatening Matthew to reveal the location of the drug by using force if necessary.

Dialogue:
: 
Person1: Bullshit. He's a liar.
Person2: News-flash, Tanner. I'm a confidential informant.
Person1: You think you're so darn smart, don't you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and frustration towards Person2 for being a confidential informant and implying they think highly of themselves.
Intent_p2: Person2 is revealing their status as a confidential informant to Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: There is nothing to discuss.
Person2: Will you listen to this man? Will you just listen to him?  You really caused a panic on a public beach, you shoot up the place, God knows who could've been injured -- what if somebody de- cides to sue us?  That could ruin us.
Person1: Is that what it is?  Dollars? Money?  I'll pay for it.  Take it out of my salary.
Person2: You don't make enough.
Person1: Maybe I don't make as much money as some bullshit rip-off artists around here, but I don't work the same way.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: It means I don't like all that grab-ass and heavy breathing with my wife, it means I know who's out to screw me here, and it means that I know something none of you know because I've been there -- and I don't want to go through that horror again.  Ever!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and defiance, emphasizing that their actions were driven by personal trauma and a desire to avoid a similar experience in the future.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the potential legal consequences and financial impact of Person1's actions and is questioning their motives and behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: Dude - there's not any chance of my becoming involved in this, is there?
Person2: You? No, you'll be all right, so long as you establish an alibi for tonight.
Person1: know, but
Person2: Be sure you're with somebody responsible in case any questions are asked. Understand?
Person1: But Dude, listen - couldn't we make this some other time?
Person2: Listen, buddy, you're getting by pretty easy. Quit squawking!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about being involved in a situation and is seeking reassurance and a way out.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reassuring Person1 that they will be fine as long as they have an alibi and are with someone responsible, and they should stop complaining because they are getting off easy.

Dialogue:
Person1: After I left...when I was in California, I began to think, what kind of mother was I that I could walk out on my own child. It got to where I couldn't tell anybody about Billy--I couldn't stand that look in their faces when I said he wasn't living with me.  Finally it seemed like the most important thing in the world to come back here and prove to Billy and to me and to the world how much I loved him...And I did ...And I won.  Only...it was just another "should."  ...Sitting in that courtroom. Hearing everything you did, everything you went through... Something happened.  I guess it doesn't matter how much I love him, or how much you love him. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for Billy.  I don't know, maybe that's all love is anyway... Ted, I think Billy should stay with you...
Person2: What?
Person1: He's already got one mother, he doesn't need two...He's yours...  I won't fight you for him any more. He's yours...
Person2: Oh, God...Oh, my God...
Person1: Only can I still see him?
Person2: No more waiting in Coffee Shops ...I promise.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses regret for leaving their child, realizes that what's best for the child is more important than their own feelings, and ultimately decides to let the child stay with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement indicates a mix of shock, relief, and gratitude upon hearing Person1's decision to let Billy stay with them and expressing a willingness to allow continued contact with Billy.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why did you cancel my gym membership? I had plans to go with friends this weekend!
Person2: I noticed you've been pushing yourself too hard lately and thought you could use a break.
Person1: That wasn't your decision to make.
Person2: I’m only doing this for your own good. Sometimes you need someone to force you to take a step back.
Person1: I appreciate your concern, but I need to make those decisions for myself.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their autonomy and expressing the need to make their own decisions regarding their gym membership and well-being.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express that they canceled the gym membership out of concern for Person1's well-being and to emphasize the importance of taking a break when needed.

Dialogue:
Person1: You mean Nuke.  You said "Crash".
Person2: I didn't say "Crash".  I said Nuke.
Person1: You said "Crash".
Person2: Honey, don't ever listen to a woman when she's making love. They'll say the strangest things.
Person1: You said "Crash".
Person2: Would you rather me be making love to him, using your name, or making love to you, using his name?
Intent_p1: Person1 is insisting that Person2 said "Crash" instead of "Nuke" during the conversation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that during intimate moments, people may say things that are not accurate or reflective of their true intentions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Wait, wait...
Person2: For what?
Person1: Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?
Person2: Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!
Person1: Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything.
Person2: You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!
Person1: Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the potential consequences of Person2's actions and prioritizing the immediate needs of their people over engaging in conflict with the English.
Intent_p2: Person2 is determined to speak to the English and raise a war-cry against them if necessary, believing that God's counsel is guiding them to take action immediately.

Dialogue:
Person1: H'mm ... no wonder I have trouble rounding up this show--Don't you know there's a rehearsal going on?-- And you wanted a raise.--Come on--get going or you'll get it!
Person2: Oh, all right--  See you later, Toots.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2 for not being aware of the ongoing rehearsal and is urging them to start working or face consequences.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reluctantly agreeing to leave and continue with their tasks after being reminded of the ongoing rehearsal and the possibility of consequences for not complying.

Dialogue:
Person1: You keep trying to lay this whole ride on                 t Keaton. It wasn't like that. Sure he knew, but Edie had him all turned around.                 r I'm telling you straight, I swear.                        +
Person2: Let me tell you something. I know Dean Keaton. I've been investigating him for three years. The guy I know is a cold-                    + blooded bastard. L.A.P.D. indicted him on three counts of murder before he was kicked off the force, so don't sell me the hooker with the heart of gold.                        +
Person1: You got him wrong.
Person2: Do I? Keaton was under indictment a total                 + of seven times when he was on the force.                  + In every case, witnesses either reversed                  + their testimony to the grand jury or died                 + before they could testify. When they                      t finally did nail him for fraud, he spent                  + five years in Sing Sing. He killed three prisoners inside - one with a knife in the tailbone while he strangled him to death. Of course I can't prove this but I can't prove the best part either.
Intent_p1: Person1 is defending Keaton, claiming that Edie manipulated him and that he is not as guilty as Person2 believes.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Dean Keaton has a violent and criminal history, including multiple murder charges and a history of intimidating witnesses, casting doubt on his character.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't you condescend to tell me how or why to honor Independence Day, and don't tell me I'm overreacting when I'm trying to bust the guy responsible for half the filthy junk coming into this city!
Person2: You're about an inch away from insubordination!
Person1: Well... seeing how you just suspended me, what's to stop me from calling you a crazy bastard, you old fart?
Person2: Till the last firework fizzles out tonight, detective, you sit a desk. And, after that, I'll decide if you keep your shield.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and defiance towards Person2's authority and restrictions placed on their actions.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are warning Person1 about the consequences of their behavior and insubordination, indicating that their actions could lead to losing their position as a detective.

Dialogue:
Person1: What sort of task?
Person2: It's not something I can explain now. Perhaps someday.
Person1: What of our marriage? Victor, we've had so much tragedy. I want this family to live again.
Person2: So do I.
Person1: We need each other now, I need your comfort and strength, not separation and solitude.
Person2: A month at most, that's all I ask.  Elizabeth, please. Things have not yet resolved. I must take steps to see that they do. For our family's sake. For our sake.  You are life itself. We shall seal our vow. The moment I am done.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire for their marriage to be restored and for their family to thrive despite past tragedies.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses the intent to temporarily separate from Person1 in order to address unresolved matters for the sake of their family and vows to reunite once the task is completed.

Dialogue:
Person1: To lunch.
Person2: To lunch, you say. I am having coffee and sandwiches sent in. We are not leaving until we have everything ready for the opening.
Person1: But I have some friends waiting.
Person2: That is unfortunate. They will have to wait.
Person1: I will only be gone about half an hour.
Person2: If you leave before the work is done, you will be gone for a much longer period ... you will be gone for good.
Person1: All right, I'll tell them. They're right here in front.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to inform Person2 that they have friends waiting for them, but Person2 emphasizes the importance of staying until the work is completed for the opening.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the importance of staying to finish the work before leaving for lunch.

Dialogue:
Person1: When was that?
Person2: The twenty third of January. On that night one of our elder nuns passed away.
Person1: Sister Paul?
Person2: Yes. I don't remember where Agnes was. I was needed in the sick room.
Intent_p1: Person1 is inquiring about the date of a specific event involving the passing of an elder nun named Sister Paul.
Intent_p2: Person2 is confirming that Sister Paul passed away on the twenty third of January and expressing uncertainty about Agnes' whereabouts at that time due to being occupied in the sick room.

Dialogue:
Person1: Listen, we look pretty lousy out there, right?
Person2: Well, for college players that have been out of training seven or eight years...
Person1: I'm thinking about how we can make more money.  Suppose we bet only part of our dough and keep this big animal out of the game the whole first half and let them roll up some points. Then you could bet the rest of our bundle between the halves and get the General and his friends to give us some real odds.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting a plan to manipulate the outcome of the game in order to make more money through betting.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting manipulating the game by intentionally keeping a key player out in the first half to influence betting odds and potentially make more money.

Dialogue:
Person1: Who knew she was pregnant?
Person2: Why do you insist upon pressing...
Person1: Was it you?
Person2: Is it because she's a nun?
Person1: Did you know she was pregnant?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And you didn't send her to a doctor.
Person2: I didn't guess until it was too late.
Person1: For what?  An abortion?
Person2: Oh, don't be ridiculous.
Person1: Too late for what?
Person2: I don't know... too late to stop it.
Person1: The baby?
Person2: The scandal...
Person1: You went to the room to help with the birth.
Person2: She didn't want any help.
Person1: You wanted that child out of the way.
Person2: That's a lie.
Person1: You hid the wastepaper basket in her room.
Person2: I didn't hide it. I put it there for the blood and the dirty sheets.
Person1: And the baby.
Person2: No!
Person1: You tied the cord around its neck.
Person2: I wanted her to have it when no-one else was around, they would have taken the baby to a hospital and left it with them, but it was such a difficult birth, there was so much blood and I panicked.
Person1: Before or after you killed the child?
Person2: I left it with her and I went for help.
Person1: I doubt that's what she'd say.
Person2: Then she's a liar.
Intent_p1: Person1 is accusing Person2 of being involved in a situation where a pregnant woman gave birth in secret and the baby was potentially harmed or killed.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they panicked and made a decision out of fear during a difficult birth, leading to a tragic outcome.

Dialogue:
Person1: Every time things get tough, you pull away. You're abandoning me.
Person2: I'm just trying to protect myself, Noah. It's not about you.
Person1: But we're in this together, aren't we? Shouldn't we face challenges as a team?
Person2: I need my space sometimes. That doesn't mean I'm leaving you for good.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing feeling abandoned by Person2 during tough times and questioning the importance of facing challenges together as a team.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining that their need for space during tough times is about self-preservation and not a permanent abandonment of Person1.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: I understand how you feel, Cookie. It's sort of rough -- one American squealing on other Americans. Then again, Cookie -- maybe that stoolie's not an American at all. Maybe he's a German the Krauts planted in this barracks. They do this type of thing. Just put an agent in with us -- a trained specialist. Lots of loose information floating around a prison camp. Not just whether somebody wants to escape, but what outfits we were with and where we were stationed, and how our radar operates. Could be, couldn't it?
Person2: In this barracks?
Person1: Why not? Just one of the boys. Sharing our bunks. Eating our chow. Right in amongst the ones that beat me up. Except that he beat hardest.
Person2: Who is it?
Person1: That's not the point, Cookie. The point is what do you do with him? You tip your mitt and the Jerries pull him out of here and plant him someplace else, like Stalag Sixteen or Fifteen. Or you kill him off and the Krauts turn around and kill off the whole barracks. Every one of us. So what do you do?
Person2: Who is it?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern and suspicion about the possibility of a German spy being planted among the American prisoners of war and the dilemma of how to handle the situation without risking the safety of everyone in the barracks.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to inquire about the identity of the potential spy in the barracks.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hello.  Hello, Leon.
Person2: Hello, Sonny.
Person1: How are you doing?
Person2: Well... I'm out of the hospital.
Person1: Yeah.  You said... I thought you were never getting out?
Person2: I never thought I'd get out this way.  I'll tell you.
Person1: Well.... huh ...
Person2: Ooohh....
Person1: Oh... huh ... how you feeling?
Person2: I'm really shakey.
Person1: Well, you know ... Moretti told me before that you were drugged up.
Person2: Yeah.  It was terrible.
Person1: That... huh... they just shoot you with drugs.
Person2: You come in and they say, right away, that you are crazy.  And they start putting things in your arm... you know.  How do they expect you to get uncrazy if you're asleep all the time?
Person1: Yeah...
Person2: You can't talk or do anything.  You really feel... you know... I'm just sort of coming out of it now.
Person1: So... that sure is something.
Person2: Yeah.  So how are you?
Person1: Fine, thank you.  I'm in trouble. That is... now I am!
Person2: Yeah... I know.
Person1: I don't know what I'm gonna do... you know.  Boy... I'm dying.
Person2: What?  What are you talking about? You are dying?  Did you ever listen to yourself when you say that?
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: What do you mean... what am I talking about?  Do you realize that you say that to me every day of your life?  I am dying.  Do you know... do you realize the death that you are spreading around to the people who are around you?
Person1: Now don't give me that deep shit now.  Don't start with that shit.
Person2: No really... I don't think that you realize what it means.  The things that you do, Sonny.  You put a gun to somebody's head...
Person1: I don't know what I'm doing.
Person2: Yeah... obviously you don't... when you put a gun to somebody's head... and you say go to sleep so that it won't hurt when I pull the trigger. Death?  Don't talk about death to me.  I have been living with death for the last six months.  Why do you think I'm in the hospital?  I take a handful of pills to get away from you.  And then here I am out of the hospital talking to you on the phone... again.  I have no friends left.  No job.  I can't live.  I have to live with people. This death business... I'm sorry!
Person1: I'm not on the phone to talk to you about that.  Well, I don't know what to say, Leon.  When you gimme that... when you hit me with that shit.  I mean, what am I supposed to say?
Person2: I'm sorry...
Person1: I told you.  That I got a lot of pressures.  You said to me that you needed money, and I knew that you needed money!  I saw you there lying in the hospital like that... and I said... shit, man, I got to get this guy some money.
Person2: But I didn't ask you to go rob a bank.
Person1: All right.  I know you didn't ask me.  You didn't ask me but I did it.
Person2: Well...
Person1: I did it on my own.  I did this all on my own.  I ain't laying it on anybody.  Nothing on anybody.  I'll tell you something, though, it's about time that I squared away my accounts... you know.  I am squaring away my accounts with life.  Maye this whole thing is gonna end, somehow.  Maybe it'll just end! Maybe I'll just close my eyes and the whole thing will be over. That would be all right too!  I said... I thought I would square it away with you... you know?  That I would get you down here and that I would say so long to you... or, if you wanted... you know, to take a trip...
Person2: What trip?
Person1: I'm getting out of here, man.  I'm not going to stay here and I'm not giving up.  I mean, huh, they're going to kill me, anyway.  So forget it!  But, if I can get out of this... I am going to get out. And, how I'm going to do it is to get a jet out of here and I'm flying the fuck out... That's all, Leon.  If you want to come with me, then you're entitled... you can come.  You're free to do what you want.
Person2: I'm free to do what I want?  And you think I would want to go with you some place on a plane?  Where? Where ya going?
Person1: I gotta jet coming here and we're gonna try to get outta this thing.  And we're gonna go, man!
Person2: You're crazy.
Person1: That's it.
Person2: You're really crazy.
Person1: I know!
Person2: Where you gonna go?
Person1: Who knows?  I think we're gonna go ... we worked it out to Algeria.  So, I don't know.  So I'll go to Algeria.
Person2: Why you going to Algeria?
Person1: Huh ... I don't know.  They got Howard Johnson's there.  I don't know why I'm going there for.
Person2: Howard Johnson's... you're warped. You know that?  You're really warped!
Person1: I know that.  I'm warped... I'm warped!
Person2: God, Algeria!  Do you know there's a bunch of... they walk around there... God!  People walk around with masks and things on their heads.  They're a bunch of crazy people there.
Person1: What am I supposed to do?
Person2: I don't know... you could have picked a better place.
Person1: Denmark?  Sweden?
Person2: I like that... yeah!
Person1: Sal wanted to go to Wyoming.  I told him it wasn't a country.  We gotta get outta the country!  To hell with a guy who doesn't know where Wyoming is.  Okay.  Can you imagine what kind of a shape I'm in?
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a sense of desperation and confusion, contemplating escaping the pressures of their current situation by leaving the country with Leon, ultimately revealing a warped and erratic mindset.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses concern and disbelief at Person1's impulsive and risky plan to flee the country, questioning their choice of destination and highlighting the potential dangers of their actions.

Person2: Want to cry now?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that they did not cry and simply waited during the difficult times mentioned by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing the complexity of their emotions, including happiness, love, and sadness, and questioning if Person1 wants to cry now.

Dialogue:
Person1: Wait.  Something's wrong.  I don't...
Person2: What's wrong?
Person1: I don't remember.  Why don't I remember?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confusion and concern about their inability to remember something.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and trying to understand why Person1 is unable to remember something.

Dialogue:
Person1: I heard a very sad story about a girl who went to Bryn Mawr.  She squealed on her roommate, and they found her strangled with her own brassiere.
Person2: Yes - you have to be very careful about picking a roommate.
Intent_p1: Person1 is sharing a cautionary tale about the consequences of not being careful when choosing a roommate.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the importance of being cautious when selecting a roommate to avoid potential dangers or conflicts.

Dialogue:
Person1: I've loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you, Jeremiah. I've just always been too scared to show it.
Person2: Beth, I can't believe you just said that because that's exactly how I've always felt about you... Call me Jam. It's my band name.
Person1: You don't know how long I've been waiting to hear that... Jam!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their long-standing love for Person2 and their relief at finally hearing that the feeling is mutual.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses that they have also loved Person1 but were too scared to show it, and they are happy to hear Person1's confession.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't worry. He was white trash, they come at two a penny. I dumped him in the swamp and untied the slave, licked his wounds clean.
Person2: You're the devil, aren't you? That's who you are.
Person1: I wish I were. But if I were, what would I want with you?
Person2: I can't go through with it, I tell you.
Person1: Your perfect. Your bitter and you're strong.
Person2: But why do you want me?
Person1: Because you're as strong as I was when I was alive.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement implies that they are drawn to Person2 because of their strength and resilience, similar to their own when they were alive.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a realization of their own strength and resilience, questioning why Person1 would want them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.
Person2: All set for what?
Person1: I rented a car -- it's going to be here at one o'clock -- we're driving to Atlantic City.
Person2: Atlantic City?
Person1: I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.
Person2: Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.
Person1: I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.
Person2: Baxter?
Person1: He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.
Person2: He wouldn't.
Person1: Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.
Person2: The nerve.
Person1: That little punk -- after all I did for him! He said I couldn't bring anybody to his apartment -- especially not Miss Kubelik. What's he got against you, anyway?
Person2: I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell.
Intent_p1: Person1 is explaining to Person2 that they are driving to Atlantic City because they couldn't find a hotel room in town for New Year's Eve due to Baxter not giving them the key to the apartment.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies resignation and acceptance of the situation, suggesting that sometimes things just fall apart in a way that cannot be changed.

Dialogue:
Person1: What are you doing here?
Person2: Nothing.  I just wanted you to know I was out.  I just wanted to see you.
Person1: Well, here I am.  See?
Person2: How are you doing?
Person1: George, you just can't show up, tell me you love me, and have everything be okay.
Person2: Dad.
Person1: What?
Person2: You can call me Dad if you want.
Person1: I don't want, alright?  It's not funny. I'm really pissed off, George.  You blew it, now leave me alone.
Person2: Kristina, c'mon, I'm sorry.  I'm going to make this right.  I've got a few things going on...
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Just to walk with you.  I want to be your dad again.
Person1: Do what you want, it's a free country.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing anger and hurt towards Person2 for showing up unexpectedly and wanting to reconcile their relationship.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses a desire to reconcile and rebuild a father-daughter relationship with Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Do you think he'd be satisfied with the two hundred dollars?  I think he would.
Person2: That scar-faced bastard will find out what we got from the wholesaler. He won't take a dime less than three hundred dollars.
Person1: What if we don't pay?
Person2: You know his friends...real animals. And his connections with the police. Sure he'd like us to tell him our plans so he can set us up for the cops and earn their gratitude. Then they would owe him a favor; that's how he operates.  We'll have to pay.  Three hundred, are we agreed?
Person1: What can we do?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the consequences of not paying the scar-faced individual and is resigned to the fact that they will have to pay the demanded three hundred dollars.
Intent_p2: Person2 believes that the person they are dealing with will not accept anything less than three hundred dollars and warns about the consequences of not paying.

Dialogue:
Person1: No, really.
Person2: Shit, I don't remember exactly. I took over for my Pa just after the Duke nabbed the Oscar.
Person1: The Duke?
Person2: Yeah, my Pa wasn't right in the head after that.
Person1: You mean John Wayne?
Person2: Hell, boy there some other Duke you know about?  A great American.
Person1: Yeah, I was never that big of a western fan. I like science fiction.
Person2: I figured that much. Why the heck you asking so many jackass questions for?
Person1: You see me and my friends are writing a book on offbeat roadside attractions. You know all the crazy shit you see when you drive cross country.
Person2: I don't drive cross country.
Person1: But if you did.
Person2: I don't.
Person1: But suppose for a second you did.
Person2: Y'all find us country people real funny like don't ya... well, God damn pack up the mule and sling me some grits, I'ze a gotta get me some schooling.
Person1: No, no I think it's really interesting.
Person2: Well, heck me Side Sally, who want to read about all that nonsense anyway.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to explain their interest in writing a book about offbeat roadside attractions to Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies skepticism and disbelief towards the idea of writing a book about offbeat roadside attractions and questions the interest and relevance of such a topic.

Dialogue:
Person1: I know. Don't say anything.
Person2: He's a softy. Got him wrapped around my finger.
Person1: You think so.
Person2: Know so.
Intent_p1: Person1 is subtly expressing doubt or skepticism about Person2's claim of having control over someone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is confident that they have a strong influence over someone who is easily swayed by their actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: She may not make it through the program, but she's got more heart and more character than you'll ever have. I've seen your college record. I've never heard of most of those schools. Tell me something, Mayo. Did you buy that degree?
Person2: No, sir! It was the hardest thing I ever did, sir! Until this.
Person1: That's a lie, Mayo. You've gone through a lot worse, haven't you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's integrity and insinuating that they have faced tougher challenges in the past.
Intent_p2: Person2 is denying the accusation of buying their degree and emphasizing that their current situation is the hardest thing they have ever faced.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jesus.   What kind of FBI agent are you?
Person2: I'm your worst nightmare. Now, if you don't want me to keep on hurting you, it's important that I believe you and right now I don't. So tell me, where did they go?
Person1: I swear man, I don't know. They packed up and left a half hour ago.  All I got is one of their phone numbers in Paris.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confusion and fear towards Person2, who is posing as an FBI agent and threatening harm if they don't provide information about someone's whereabouts.
Intent_p2: Person2 is threatening Person1 to get information about someone's whereabouts by implying that they will continue to harm them if they don't cooperate.

Dialogue:
Person1: You promised you'd meet projections, Alan.  A dollar sixty per share you said.  So, I don't think this is so surprising a visit.
Person2: Projections were far too optimistic.
Person1: Admittedly...
Person2: Our E.P.S. was one fifty last quarter.  We're up eight cents per share.
Person1: But, the expectation was ten.  And, in this case, expectation is everything.
Person2: Will you really hold me to it over pennies?
Person1: My stock's falling.  Isn't yours? Those pennies are costing me millions.
Person2: The stock will turn.
Person1: It probably will.  In fact, I'd go so far as to say it almost certainly will, in time.  Why should I settle for that?
Person2: Because it's fair.  Give me next quarter.  If you still feel this way, vote your shares...
Person1: You're talking tomorrow.  Today is what counts.
Person2: You intractable son-of-a-bitch.  If your father could see you now...
Person1: What?
Person2: Your father was a friend.  Goddamn it... I watched you grow up.  How do you end up treating me like this?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disappointment and frustration with Person2 for not meeting the promised projections and is holding them accountable for the financial losses incurred as a result.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and hurt over being treated poorly by Person1 despite their past relationship and history.

Dialogue:
Person1: Thank you.
Person2: Please accept my apology for not having done so sooner.
Person1: Apology accepted.  Now, on the matter of the specific targeting of officers during engagements, this is absolutely unacceptable.
Person2: That one is a bit more difficult.
Person1: Certainly you must know that in civilized warfare, officers in the field must not be accorded inappropriate levels of hostile attention.
Person2: And what are inappropriate levels of hostile attention?
Person1: Colonel, imagine the utter chaos that would result from un-led armies having at each other.  There must be gentlemen in command to lead and, when appropriate, restrain their men.
Person2: Restrain them from the targeting of civilians, including women and children?
Person1: That is a separate issue.
Person2: I consider them linked.
Person1: I beg to differ.  One is a command decision on your part.  The other represents nothing more than the occasional over-exuberance of field officers attempting to carry out their duty in difficult circumstances.
Person2: As long as your soldiers attack civilians, I will order the shooting of your officers at the outset of every engagement.  And my men are excellent marksmen.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the importance of not targeting officers during engagements in civilized warfare.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they will take drastic action by ordering the shooting of officers at the beginning of every engagement if Person1's soldiers continue to attack civilians.

Dialogue:
Person1: Want to dance?
Person2: Dance? Here?
Person1: Why not?
Person2: They know you here--know your name.
Person1: I know everybody. I don't look at half of life, just the nice half, I look at all of it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a carefree and open-minded attitude towards dancing and socializing, emphasizing that they are familiar with everyone and choose to focus on the positive aspects of life.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about dancing in that particular location because they are known there, implying potential discomfort or consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: I heard from Tina that you decided to sell the house without even consulting me.
Person2: What? I never said that. I merely mentioned considering it in the future.
Person1: But she was so sure about it.
Person2: Get your facts straight before accusing me. We always make big decisions together.
Intent_p1: Person1 is upset that Person2 allegedly decided to sell the house without discussing it, and Person2 clarifies that they only mentioned considering it in the future and emphasizes the importance of making big decisions together.
Intent_p2: Person2 is clarifying that they never definitively decided to sell the house without consulting Person1 and emphasizes the importance of making big decisions together.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know I love you... yeah?
Person2: Yes.
Intent_p1: Person1 is seeking reassurance of their love for Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is acknowledging that they are aware of Person1's love for them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Do you have any idea how goddamn crazy you are?
Person2: You mean the nature of this conversation?
Person1: I mean the nature of you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's level of sanity or mental stability.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning whether Person1 is referring to the intensity of their conversation or to their own personality.

Dialogue:
Person1: See, I don't know how it happened... she's a smart girl and you are an extraordinary screwed-up guy... but she's in love with you.
Person2: Tell me, Knox. If you've got the story, why haven't you printed it?
Person1: Because I...  ... Because she'd never speak to me again.
Intent_p1: Person1 is hesitant to reveal the truth about the girl's feelings towards Person2 because it could jeopardize their relationship with her.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning why Person1 hasn't published the story if they already know about it, to which Person1 responds that they haven't done so because it would jeopardize their relationship with the girl involved.

Dialogue:
Person1: This SWAT guy might be a good idea. He may be able to take a little pressure off you. I worry about you.
Person2: You worried about me, too? The chief's worried about me. Solis is worried about me. Maybe you guys should start some kind of organization.
Person1: Speaking of which. I saw you talking to Ronnie this morning. Why can't you get it back together with her. You've gotta be out of your mind not to get with that one.
Person2: It's not me. It's her. She's going out with this baseball player -- Greg Barnett.
Person1: No shit! He's good!
Person2: Forget him. He swings at anything in the dirt. I could strike him out.
Person1: Don't give up on her. You're getting to the age when you ought to be thinking about these things.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern for Person2's well-being and suggesting that they consider getting back together with Ronnie, emphasizing the importance of relationships at their age.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration about Ronnie dating someone else and dismissing the baseball player Greg Barnett's skills.

Dialogue:
Person1: I never thought I'd say this, but I'm glad you came.
Person2: Understood- you realize now you could never have done it without me.
Person1: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you came.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise at being glad that Person2 came, despite believing they could have accomplished the task more easily without them.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they believe Person1 now recognizes their importance and contribution to the situation, even though Person1 disagrees.

Dialogue:
Person1: You have yourself a few flings this summer. I bet you're quite a ladies' man.
Person2: Oh no.
Person1: What? You look like the kind of guy that has to fight them off.  Doesn't he look to you like the kind of guy who has to fight them off?
Intent_p1: Person1 is teasing Person2 about being popular with women and jokingly suggesting that he must have to fend off their advances.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express humility and downplay the perception of being a ladies' man.

Dialogue:
Person1: Right, partner.
Person2: Get this. We ain't partners. We ain't brothers. We ain't friends. If Ganz gets away with my money, you're gonna be sorry we ever met.
Person1: Yeah.  Right.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging Person2's warning about the consequences of failing to catch Ganz and retrieve the money.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing to Person1 that their relationship is strictly business and that if things go wrong, there will be consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey Lieutenant, the boys in robbery have something I think you should look at.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: A tape from the surveillance camera at the First National Bank.  It was robbed this morning.
Person2: Really?  I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Greley.  A crime was committed in New York City?  That is news.
Person1: The guy had a sword and was dressed like this guy.
Intent_p1: Person1 is informing Person2 about a robbery at the First National Bank and providing details about the suspect's appearance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing surprise and seeking clarification about the reported crime in New York City involving a sword-wielding suspect.

Dialogue:
Person1: You got him involved?
Person2: Like we had a choice?  Besides -- when you let the enemy think he's orchestrating the battle, you're in a position of power. We let him pretend he's calling the shots, and while he's busy setting up the plan, you have time to woo Bianca.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2 about involving someone in their plan, to which Person2 explains that by letting the enemy think they are in control, they can use the distraction to their advantage.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining that by allowing the enemy to believe they are in control, they can use that to their advantage to focus on other priorities.

Dialogue:
Person1: Pete, you're through!
Person2: What do you mean -- through?
Person1: I mean I'm scratching your name off the ticket Tuesday and running Czernecki in your place. It's nothing personal. And, Pete -- it's the only way out. It's a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make.
Person2: Fred!
Person1: Now, Pete! Please don't appeal to my Sentimental side.
Person2: Fred, I don't know what to say. A thing like this almost destroys a man's faith in human nature.
Person1: I wish you wouldn't talk like that, Pete.
Person2: Our families, Fred. I've always looked on Bessie as my own sister.
Person1: If there was any way out...
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to inform Pete that he is being replaced by Czernecki in a decision that is necessary and not personal, despite the impact on their families.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses shock and disappointment at being replaced by Czernecki in a decision that affects their families and questions the morality of the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.
Person2: I need to make a telephone call.
Person1: A telephone call?  That's communication with the outside world!  Doctor's discretion.  Hey, if alla these nuts could just make phone calls, it could spread.  Insanity oozing through telephone cables, oozing into the ears of all those poor sane people, infecting them!  Whackos everywhere!  A plague of madness.  In fact, very few of us here are actually mentally ill.  I'm not saying you're not mentally ill, for all I know you're crazy as a loon.  But that's not why you're here.  Why you're here is because of the system, because of the economy.  There's the TV.  It's all right there. Commercials.  We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. But if you don't buy a lot of stuff, you know what?  You're mentally ill! That's a fact!  If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices...  SCREWDRIVERS WITH MINIATURE BUILT-IN RADAR DEVICES, STEREO SYSTEMS WITH BRAIN IMPLANTED HEADPHONES, VOICE- ACTIVATED COMPUTERS, AND...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a cynical view on the mental health system, suggesting that individuals are labeled as mentally ill due to societal pressures to consume goods and services, rather than actual mental health issues.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement about needing to make a telephone call is a diversion from Person1's discussion about medication and serves as a way to break away from the conversation.

Dialogue:
Person1: I am worrying.  Seems to me, you're starting to get confused as to which side of the line you're standing on.
Person2: Pretty hollow words coming from a man who spent the last year running with the enemy.
Person1: What the hell is that supposed to mean?
Person2: It means I'm starting to wonder if the vampires still have their hooks in you. You've been acting strange ever since I gave you the cure.  Reckless, quick to anger --  You said it yourself, Whistler.  Those vampires knew our defense system backwards and forwards.  Where'd they get their intel?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about Person2's loyalty and behavior, hinting at suspicions that they may still be influenced by the vampires.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning Person1's loyalty and suggesting that they may still be influenced by the vampires due to their recent behavior and actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'll think you'll find everything in working order. Molly's just having a little fun.
Person2: I don't call this fun, pal. You're playing God with my body.
Person1: You're a substance abuser, Case. Your pancreas was shot. Wouldn't have lasted out the year. We did you a favour and liberated you from a dangerous dependency in the bargain.
Person2: Thanks, but I was enjoying that dependency.
Person1: Good, because you've got a new one.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to justify their actions by explaining that they helped Person2 by removing a dangerous dependency, even though Person2 may not see it that way.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and resistance towards Person1's decision to intervene in their health and dependency issues without their consent.

Dialogue:
Person1: I must go.
Person2: Ninotchka, or shall I say Special Envoy Yakushova...
Person1: Let's forget that we ever met.
Person2: I have a better suggestion. Let's forget that the telephone ever rang. I never heard that you are Yakushova... you are Ninotchka... my Ninotchka...
Person1: I was sent here by my country to fight you.
Person2: All right, fight me, fight me as much as you want, but fight me tomorrow morning! There's nothing sweeter than sharing a secret with a bitter enemy.
Person1: As a representative of Moscow...
Person2: Tonight let's not represent anybody but ourselves.
Person1: It is out of the question. If you wish to approach me...
Person2: You know I want to...
Person1: Then do it through my lawyer!
Person2: Ninotchka, you can't walk out like this... I'm crazy about you, and I thought I'd made an impression on you. You liked the white of my eye.
Intent_p1: Person1 intends to end the interaction and distance themselves from Person2 by insisting on maintaining a professional and formal approach through involving a lawyer.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses their deep feelings for Ninotchka and tries to convince her not to leave by emphasizing their affection and the impact they have had on each other.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'll have lunch ready by one.
Person2: I'll be back.
Person1: At one. Promise?
Person2: Sure.
Intent_p1: Person1 is confirming with Person2 that lunch will be ready by one.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to return by one o'clock for lunch as promised.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, you tried.  You failed miserably, but you tried.
Person2: Everything I say is wrong. I can't talk to her anymore.
Person1: She's only 12.  Some day she'll understand that apathy and absence are just special ways of saying "I love you."
Person2: Is that what you think?
Person1: Jon ... we just remember how it used to be.  You staying for a while or is this just a piss-stop?
Person2: We need to talk.
Person1: I'm late for surgery.
Person2: It's important.
Person1: So is finishing my residency and passing my boards ...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing understanding and empathy towards Person2's situation while also highlighting their own priorities and responsibilities.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing the urgency and importance of having a conversation with Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: They're filthy, Mother.
Person2: Sex isn't ugly, sex is one of the most beautiful things in life, the creative power of the universe is behind it.
Person1: I know, Mother.
Person2: But we must respect that power, we must be in awe of it.
Person1: I am in awe of it, Mother.
Person2: I don't think you are sufficiently in awe of it. Get the castor oil.
Person1: Oh, Mother, not the castor oil.
Person2: This isn't punishment, I don't believe in punishment. It's for your health. Obviously you're sick if you can act like that.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing discomfort or disapproval towards something related to sex, which is being addressed by Person2 as a lack of respect for the power and beauty of sex.
Intent_p2: Person2 emphasizes the importance of respecting and being in awe of the creative power of sex.

Dialogue:
Person1: Vicki?... This is Batman. I thought I'd call and see how you're doing.
Person2: ... I know it's you, Bruce. I'm not going to talk to you unless we can discuss it...
Person1: Who's this 'Bruce'? Are you trying to make me jealous?
Person2: I'm serious, Bruce. We have to -- !
Intent_p1: Person1 is playfully pretending to be Batman and teasing Person2 about their real identity as Bruce.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to address a serious issue with Person1 (Batman/Bruce) and insists on discussing it.

Dialogue:
Person1: Remember, I'm not the one who chose this.
Person2: Yes, so which one of us does that make the coward?
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that they are not responsible for the situation at hand and is deflecting blame.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning who among them is the coward for not taking responsibility for the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Now... here we have two very handsome soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose hens mind what happens to their eggs? Probably not. They have such unfeeling eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of butter, plenty of pepper and salt... Darling, I haven't seen you for three livelong days... seventy-two hours!
Person2: Oh, please, Swana! I don't know whether I'm standing on my head or my heels. Here you are blaming me for neglecting you when I'm trying to concentrate on another woman and can't get near her.
Person1: You haven't seen her yet?
Person2: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...
Person1: That proletarian! In the old days we'd have had her flogged.
Person2: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her.  She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.
Person1: You just told me you hadn't seen her.
Person2: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of her when she walked through the lobby.
Person1: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?
Person2: You can't imagine.
Person1: That bad?  Old or young?
Person2: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli. What a woman! What a woman! There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes.
Person1: You saw all that in one glimpse?
Person2: Darling, if we're going to get anywhere someone has to keep his eyes open!
Person1: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful pine bath and let Gaston shave you.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a sarcastic and critical attitude towards the woman Person2 is infatuated with, highlighting her unconventional appearance and contrasting it with their luxurious surroundings.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses frustration and fascination with a mysterious woman they are trying to pursue, highlighting her unique and captivating qualities.

Dialogue:
Person1: Thank you.  Now, repeat after me-- Spider-Man is a good guy. On the side of right, and niceness, and cute baby animals and all that.
Person2: Frmpph-yrr.
Person1: Fine.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to get Person2 to repeat that Spider-Man is a good guy, but Person2 is not cooperating.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to humorously mumble a response instead of repeating the statement about Spider-Man being a good guy.

Dialogue:
Person1: Take your eyes off her, Oleg!  Look.  It wasn't my fault you two were caught.  It's his fault.  Trying to get the bank clerk's phone number?!  I wasn't going to wait!!!
Person2: Milos.  Get my money!
Intent_p1: Person1 is blaming Oleg for getting caught during a bank robbery because he was trying to get the bank clerk's phone number.
Intent_p2: Person2 is instructing Milos to retrieve their money.

Dialogue:
Person1: She tryin' to work your ass against me, ain't she?
Person2: Yep.
Person1: You didn't even hafta say it. I know the woman.
Person2: Well, why the heck keep her around?
Person1: 'Cause she my fine little surfer gal. She can't do me no harm. Fact she think she can play you against me shows how little she knows. You could teach that bitch for days how it is 'tween me an you, she never understand a damn word.
Person2: Why do you let someone know your business you can't trust?
Person1: I don't hafta trust her, I know her.
Person2: What does that mean?
Person1: You can't trust Melanie. But you can always trust Melanie to be Melanie.
Intent_p1: Person1 believes that even though the woman may try to manipulate others, he knows her well enough to not be affected by her actions.
Intent_p2: Person2 questions why Person1 keeps someone around whom they can't trust, to which Person1 explains that while they don't trust her, they know her well enough to predict her actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: We got one...two...three...four ...five...six...seven...eight. I mean Jesus Christ, Phil, that's too much. Let's lose some of these guys.
Person2: Wayne, if it was anybody else---
Person1: Phil, I'm just scared he's gonna clam up on me with all these sheriffs all over the place. They hate him. He hates them. What kinda intimacy am I gonna create with all this hate in the air. Even you and I feel it.
Person2: What are we talking about?
Person1: Two guys?
Person2: Okay. I'll take two guys off.
Person1: No, no, no, no, no, no, I mean only two guys.
Person2: I can't do that. Five guys.
Person1: Three.
Person2: I'll cut it in half. Four guys, but that's it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the excessive number of sheriffs present and the potential negative impact it may have on creating a sense of intimacy during the interaction.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to negotiate and compromise with Person1 on the number of guys they will involve in a situation, ultimately settling on four guys.

Dialogue:
Person1: I've done everything you've asked, followed all your instructions.
Person2: Yet things aren't progressing as they should.
Person1: What more do you want from me?
Person2: Maybe it's not about what you do, but how you do it.
Person1: Sometimes, effort and intention aren't enough, are they?
Person2: Not when the results don't match the expectations.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and questioning the effectiveness of their efforts despite following instructions.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that the way in which tasks are being carried out may be the reason for the lack of progress, rather than the effort put in.

Dialogue:
Person1: All right, mister. I'll go. You just show your license to contrack, an' then you make out a order--where an' when an' how much you gonna pay--an' you sign it an' we'll go.
Person2: You trying to tell me how to run my own business?
Person1: 'F we're workin' for you, it's our business too. An' how do we know--  --you ain't one a the guys that sent these things out?
Person2: Listen, Smart Guy. I'll run my business my own way. I got work. If you wanta take it, okay. If not, just sit here, that's all.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting that if they are working for Person2, it is also their business and they need to ensure their safety and payment terms before proceeding with the job.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to assert their authority and independence in running their own business and to make it clear that the workers can either accept the terms or choose not to participate.

Dialogue:
Person1: Did Max mention anything about any jobs?
Person2: What about boxing?
Person1: What about it?
Person2: What are you saying?
Person1: You said if you didn't have a winning record after eleven fights, you'd talk to Max.
Person2: So?
Person1: So, it was a draw.
Person2: Yeah, I'm 5-5 and 1.
Person1: So, it's not a winning record.
Person2: It's not losing record.
Person1: That's not what you said. You said if you didn't have a winning record --
Person2: Don't be shitty.
Person1: How am I being shitty?
Person2: Don't be shitty.
Person1: I wouldn't keep bugging you, but you said he said he would have a job for us.
Person2: I'm not gonna bring it up to him.
Person1: Of course I don't want you to bring it up to him... But if it comes up...
Person2: I'll page you.
Person1: Yeah. Page me. You know the number?
Person2: Yeah. I know the number.
Person1: Cause if you don't know the number, I can page you with the number so you'll have the number.
Person2: I know the number.
Person1: I'll page you with the number. I'll see you later. What time you done?
Person2: I got no idea.
Person1: Ask if he said anything to her.
Person2: I will.
Person1: I'll page you with the number.
Person2: Bye.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to remind Person2 about a conversation they had regarding a job opportunity through Max and is ensuring that Person2 will contact them if any relevant information arises.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent in the statement is to reassure Person1 that they will ask Max about any potential job opportunities and communicate with Person1 if needed.

Dialogue:
Person1: You'll get used to killing. Just forget about that mortal coil. You'll become accustomed to things all too quickly.
Person2: Do you think so?
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that with time and repetition, one can become desensitized to killing and adapt to it easily.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning whether they will truly become desensitized to killing and adapt quickly to such a grim reality.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
Person2: - and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
Person1: In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Person2: Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
Person1: No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
Person2: Let's not get over-dramatic.
Person1: You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses feeling overpowered by Addison deWitt's influence on their words and actions, taking responsibility for the consequences and acknowledging the impact on their reputation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies skepticism towards Person1's claim that their words were influenced by Addison deWitt, suggesting that they should take responsibility for their actions and not be overly dramatic.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm I doin'?
Person2: Don't hold me so tight.
Person1: Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!
Person2: You're ticklin' me!
Person1: That comes from not holdin' you tight enough.
Person2: Now I can't breathe.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to waltz with Person2 but is struggling with finding the right balance between holding too tight and not tight enough.
Intent_p2: Person2 is subtly indicating that Person1 is holding them too tightly while dancing.

Dialogue:
Person1: Who was that?
Person2: That was Beaumont.
Person1: Who was Beaumont?
Person2: An employee I had to let go.
Person1: What did he do?
Person2: He put himself in a situation where he was gonna have to do ten years in the penetentiary, that's what he did.  And if you know Beaumont, you know there ain't no way in hell he can do no ten years. And if you know that, you know Beaumont's gonna go any goddam thing Beaumont can to keep from doin' those ten years including telling the Federal government everything they want to know about my ass. Now that, my friend, is a clear case of him or me. And you best believe it ain't gonna be me. You know what I'm sayin'? You gonna come in on this with me, you gotta be prepared to go all the way. I got me so far over a half-a-million dollars sittin' in lockboxes in a bank in Cabo San Lucas. Me and Mr. Walker make us one more delivery, I'm gonna have me over a million. You think I'm gonna let this little troublemaking person here mess that up? Darn, you better think again. 'Fore I let this deal get messed up, I'll take strong action, and ten folks look just like him. Understand what I'm sayin'?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: So we on the same page then?
Person1: I follow.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging and understanding Person2's explanation and plan of action regarding the situation with Beaumont.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent in the statement is to convey the seriousness of the situation involving Beaumont, emphasizing the potential consequences of his actions and the need to protect their interests at all costs.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't listen, Willie. Progress is a feast to be consumed. Women would have you believe you must walk before you can run. Or run before you can waltz!
Person2: Give me that child before you fill his head with drivel!
Intent_p1: Person1 is encouraging Willie to embrace progress and not be held back by conventional beliefs or limitations imposed by others.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the negative influence of Person1's words on the child and is requesting to take the child away to prevent further exposure to such ideas.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: I can deliver Ganz.  But you gotta get me outta here first.
Person1: You're crazy.
Person2: I can help you, man, but you gotta get me out.  I got to be on the street.  Get me outta here.
Person1: What's the big deal about you bein' on the street?
Person2: I got a lot to protect.
Person1: Bullshit.
Person2: It's the only way you're gonna get Ganz.
Person1: I'll think about it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is skeptical of Person2's claim that being on the street is necessary to help them capture Ganz.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the importance of being on the street to help Person1 capture Ganz.

Dialogue:
Person1: There is no one here but the dead.
Person2: Go away!  I don't want you here.
Person1: If that were true, I would not be here.
Person2: It's very dangerous to assume you know what a woman wants.
