Person1: You like to make the boundaries disappear.  It's not only the money, is it, George?  The adventure is part of the victory.  It's the thrill, ah?
Person2: Good night.
Person1: In my country, I am a magico.  A man with a dream.  A man on the rise.  To take nothing and make it something, okay?  I have failed my dream, but I will accomplish.  That is why I am in your country.  Yes, I lose my freedom. But they do not take my dream.  Do you have a dream, George?
Person2: I would if I could get some sleep.
Person1: Yes, you have a dream.  And maybe you accomplish your dream.  But yet you failed.  Why?
Person2: Because I got caught.
Person1: No, my brother.
Person2: Because they caught me?
Person1: You failed because you had the wrong dream.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their belief that Person2 failed because they had the wrong dream.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "I'm tired, Diego. Go to bed." is intended to dismiss Person1's ramblings and indicate a desire to end the conversation and go to sleep.

Dialogue:
Person1: Guess who? It's your old friend, Lex.
Person2: Luthor, I suspect if you had actually planted a bomb you'd be far away from here by now.
Person1: Silly me. How do I ever think I can fool the super guy. You're right, no bomb. I just knew you were too busy with the world peace bit to make a social call.  I confess . . . I tricked you. Hey, you look great!
Intent_p1: Person1 is playfully admitting to trying to trick Person2 into thinking there was a bomb, but in reality, they were just trying to catch up with them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing skepticism towards Person1's claim of not planting a bomb and implying that they are aware of their deceptive nature.

Dialogue:
Person1: ...Hello?
Person2: You're the nastiest dirtbag I know in this stinking City!
Person1: Hi Ma...
Person2: I've been playing twice a week for 20 years, 20 years I've been eating those shitty croquettes.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to greet their mother, but Person2 is expressing frustration about having to eat the same food for 20 years while playing a game.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and resentment towards Person1 for their behavior and lack of consideration.

Dialogue:
Person1: George, I am happy to see you.  How are you, my brother?
Person2: No more brothers, Diego.
Person1: Of course we are brothers.  Why do you say that?   You hurt me, George.
Person2: You betrayed me, Diego.
Person1: I did not.
Person2: You went behind my back and you cut me out.
Person1: No, I never.  I would not do that, George.  Never.
Person2: I talked to Foreal, Diego.
Intent_p1: Person1 is denying the accusation of betrayal and expressing hurt over the perceived betrayal by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing betrayal and hurt towards Person1 for allegedly cutting them out and talking to someone else behind their back.

Dialogue:
Person1: You promised to give it back.
Person2: Friends never break promises, do they?  Okay.  Here.  Now listen.  There are a lot of people outside and they all want you to be safe.  You understand that?  They said I could come in and bring you out.
Person1: Why?
Person2: They like you.  Okay?
Person1: Come on!
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning why there are people outside who want them to be safe and why they like them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the importance of keeping promises and ensuring the safety of Person1 by conveying that there are people outside who want to help and bring them to safety.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're not looking at me, Harry.
Person2: Why do I have to keep looking at you?
Person1: I want you to.
Person2: You gonna get rough now, threaten me? I make good by tomorrow or get my legs broken?
Person1: Come on, Harry - Mesas? The worst they might do is get a judgment against you, uttering a bad check. I can't imagine you want that to happen, man in your position.
Person2: Basketball game, damn it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the consequences of bouncing a check and urging him to avoid getting into legal trouble.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and defiance by redirecting the conversation to a basketball game.

Dialogue:
Person1: Sandro... A month is too long a time. I have become used to being without you.
Person2: You'll get over it soon. It's the usual anxiety.
Person1: A little more so this time.
Person2: So, it will just take you a little longer to get over it.
Person1: But I think we should talk about it. Or are you fully convinced that we too won't understand each other?
Person2: There will be plenty of time to talk about it later.  We'll  get married  soon.  That way we'll have more time...
Person1: In this case, getting married means nothing. Aren't we already the same as being married? And Corrado and Giulia -- aren't they already the same as being married?
Person2: But why rattle your brains by arguing and talking... Believe me, Anna, words never help at all. They only serve to confuse. I love you, Anna. Isn't I that enough?
Person1: No. It's not enough... I told you before that I would like to get away for a while and be alone.
Person2: But you just said that a month was too...
Person1: I mean, to stay away longer -- two months... a year... three years... Yes, I know, it sounds absurd. And I feel awful. The very idea of losing you makes me want to die... And yet... I... I just don't have the same feeling for you any more.
Person2: And what about yesterday... at my house... didn't you have any feeling for me, even then?
Person1: There you go... Must you always spoil everything!
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a desire to be alone for an extended period of time, despite feeling awful about the idea of losing Person2, as they admit to not having the same feelings for them anymore.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that expressing love through actions is more important than words and reassures Person1 of their love for them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey! Wait a minute! There's no birthday party for me here!
Person2: Thank you, Desmond.  What's the reason for your truancy?
Person1: I couldn't make it in time.
Person2: You mean, you couldn't? Or you wouldn't?
Person1: I don't know, mon. The food lines took forever.
Person2: Food will be eaten on your time!  Why are you continuously late for this class, Mr. Spicoli? Why do you shamelessly waste my time like this?
Person1: I don't know.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to explain their lateness and lack of attendance at the birthday party, citing delays in food lines as a reason.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning Person1's reasons for being consistently late and expressing frustration over their behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore... They shot him.
Person2: Killed outright?
Person1: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me... After he left me, I had nobody. I was ten years old.
Person2: You're very frank, Clarice. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person1: Quid pro quo, Doctor.
Person2: The significance of the moth is change. Caterpillar into cocoon into beauty... Billy wants to change, too, Clarice. But there's the problem of his size, you see. Even if he were a woman, he'd have to be a big one...
Person1: Dr. Lecter, there's no correlation in the literature between transsexualism and violence. Transsexuals are very passive.
Person2: Clever girl. You're so close to the way you're going to catch him - do you realize that?
Person1: No. Tell me why.
Person2: After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next?  I don't imagine the answer's on those second-rate shoes, Clarice.
Person1: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.
Person2: A cattle ranch?
Person1: Horses - and sheep...
Person2: How long did you live there?
Person1: Two months.
Person2: Why so briefly?
Person1: I - ran away...
Person2: Why, Clarice? Did the rancher harm you?
Person1: No.
Person2: Did he try to?
Person1: No...! Quid pro quo, Doctor.
Person2: Billy's not a real transsexual, but he thinks he is. He tries to be. He's tried to be a lot of things, I expect.
Person1: You said - I was very close to the way we'd catch him.
Person2: There are three major centers for transsexual surgery: Johns Hopkins, the University of Minnesota, and Columbus Medical center. I wouldn't be surprised if Billy has applied for sex reassignment at one or all of them, and been rejected.
Person1: On what basis would they reject him?
Person2: The personality inventories would trip him up. Rorschach, Wechsler, House-Tree-Person... He wouldn't test like a real transsexual.
Person1: How would he test?
Intent_p1: Person1 is sharing personal details about her past and upbringing with Person2, leading to a discussion about the potential motivations and psychological profile of a criminal they are trying to catch.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Billy, the criminal they are trying to catch, may have applied for sex reassignment surgery at multiple centers but was likely rejected due to not testing like a real transsexual on personality inventories.

Dialogue:
Person1: I wish you could see the world as I do. Deacon opened my eyes. There's no turning back from that.
Person2: I don't believe that.
Person1: You will. Time is on our side. Sooner or later, the Thirst always wins.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a belief that Deacon has changed their perspective on the world, and they are confident that Person2 will eventually come to share their viewpoint due to the inevitable influence of time and the Thirst.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses skepticism about Person1's belief in the transformative power of Deacon and implies that eventually, they will come to share the same perspective due to the inevitable influence of time and the Thirst.

Dialogue:
Person1: We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.
Person2: We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.
Intent_p1: Person1 is advising Person2 to let go of the magazine and consider other options for its management.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their desire for Person1 to pursue a traditional path of education, career, marriage, and happiness.

Dialogue:
Person1: What is that?
Person2: Microrecorder for Kendall -- didn't have time to wire his room. Now tell me why you joined the army or I'll jab this pen through your neck.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the purpose of the microrecorder and is being threatened by Person2 to reveal why they joined the army.
Intent_p2: Person2 is threatening Person1 to reveal why they joined the army.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't agree.  Why do you have to keep changing your mind all the time?
Person2: Why are you doing this to me??  Do you get pleasure from hurting me?
Person1: Ah, pleasure... that's a difficult word to define.  When does the pain end and the pleasure begin...? When did your pleasure begin with that sword in your hand...?
Person2: I never took pleasure in hurting anyone?
Person1: Really?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's motives and suggesting that they may have taken pleasure in hurting others.
Intent_p2: Person2 is denying that they take pleasure in hurting anyone.

Dialogue:
Person1: Madame Colet, I think you deserve a scolding. First, you lose your bag--
Person2: Then I mislay my checkbook--
Person1: Then you use the wrong lipstick--
Person2: And how I handle my money!
Person1: It's disgraceful!
Person2: Tell me, M'sieu Laval, what else is wrong?
Person1: Everything! ... Madame Colet, if I were your father--  which, fortunately, I am not--
Person2: Ye-es?
Person1: And you made any attempt to handle your own business affairs, I would give you a good spanking--in a business way, of course.
Person2: What would you do if you were my secretary?
Person1: The same thing.
Person2: You're hired!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disapproval of Madame Colet's irresponsible behavior and lack of attention to detail in handling her personal and business affairs.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to humorously challenge Person1's criticism and assert their independence and capability in handling their own affairs.

Dialogue:
Person1: That's the general idea.  Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.
Person2: You are talking crazy!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing that while the concept may be considered general by others, it holds a more specific and personal significance to them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief or disagreement with Person1's statement.

Dialogue:
Person1: Uncle Terrence, you're...
Person2: Yeah, I finally "checked out", thank God. But there's a bit of unfinished business.
Person1: Claude.
Person2: I never thought I'd ask this of anyone, Andy, but do me a favor and kill the evil son-of-a-bitch, will you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking Person2 to take revenge by killing Claude, who is perceived as evil.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asking Person1 to take care of unfinished business by killing Claude, who is perceived as evil.

Dialogue:
Person1: Only if I repeat them outside this room.  And, I will if I must...  Out there, for all to hear.  Or... you may speak, as planned.  But, you tell them you feel compelled to move on to greener pastures.
Person2: No.  You will not run me out.  No one will believe a word of what you say.
Person1: Oh?  Far as I can tell, a rumor does not travel alone for long here.
Person2: Are you a deist?  Is that it?  A free thinker who does not believe in divinity.
Person1: It is only important what you are. An adulterer...
Person2: I am the Lord's voice in this town.
Person1: Wallowing in sin and lust...
Person2: They need guidance.
Person1: Wallowing quite literally in blood.
Person2: Damn you, sir!  God damn you to hell!
Person1: He may.  But, not soon enough for you, and not on your behalf.
Intent_p1: Person1 is threatening to reveal damaging information about Person2 to others if they do not comply with their demands.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to assert their authority and righteousness in the face of Person1's accusations and threats.

Dialogue:
Person1: What needs sorting out?
Person2: Come on, Rob.  My relationship with Laura has obviously disturbed you a great deal.
Person1: Funnily enough I haven't been too thrilled about it.
Person2: We are not talking jokey understatement here, Rob.  We're talking actionable harassment.  Ten phone calls a night, hanging around outside my house...
Person1: Yeah, well, I've stopped all that now.
Person2: We've noticed and we're glad.  But, you know... how are we going to make peace here?  We want to make things easier for you.  What can we do? Obviously I know how special Laura is, and I know things can't be good for you at the moment.  I'd hate it if I lost her.  But I'd like to think that if she decided she didn't want to see me anymore, I'd respect that decision.  Do you see what I'm saying?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Good.  So shall we leave it at that then?
Person1: I dunno.
Person2: Think about it, Rob.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging the negative impact their behavior has had on Person2's relationship and is open to finding a resolution.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about the impact of their relationship with Laura on Person1 and is seeking to address any discomfort or harassment that may have occurred, while also emphasizing the importance of respecting Laura's decisions.

Dialogue:
Person1: We have to lose the window.
Person2: ...we can't lose the wind...
Person1: Then I can't do this shot...you wants me to push in--I can't push in through the window...We go back to New Hampshire?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and difficulty in completing a shot because they are unable to physically push in through a window, suggesting a need to change the location or approach.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that they cannot lose the wind, implying that they need to find a different solution to the problem at hand.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hey Gus--did you see the story idea I left on your desk?
Person2: Yeah--the blind foster home mother. It was good. I got Cahoon on it.
Person1: Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.
Person2: Geller, we've been over this. You're a great copy editor. Maybe my best copy editor. You're not a reporter.
Person1: You've done five of my ideas.
Person2: You know what separates us office flunkies from the reporters?
Person1: They don't have to be in the office Christmas show?
Person2: A flack jacket.
Person1: A--flack jacket.
Person2: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks he can write. But a journalist gets in there, right where the bombs are. He's aggressive. Grabs the bull by the balls.
Person1: You don't think I can grab bulls' balls?
Person2: Geller, you don't want a reporter's life. They're very--messy. You're all about order. Control. And getting me my copy by five.
Person1: Hey--I can be out of control.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire to be more involved in reporting and journalism, despite being a copy editor, and is open to stepping out of their comfort zone.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convey to Person1 that despite their talent as a copy editor, they lack the necessary qualities and mindset to be a successful reporter due to their preference for order and control.

Dialogue:
Person1: Paul, you're dripping with perspiration, your color is very hectic--what have you been doing?
Person2: You know goddamn well what I've been doing--I'VE BEEN SITTING HERE SUFFERING. I need my pills.
Person1: Poor dear... Let's get you back in bed and I'll get them for you.
Person2: I want my pills NOW!
Person1: It'll only take a second.
Person2: I want my pain to go 'way, Annie-- make it go 'way, please Annie--  --please...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern and empathy towards Person2's suffering and is trying to help them by getting their medication.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a sense of urgency and desperation for their pain to be alleviated through medication.

Dialogue:
Person1: What's there to do at the Point? God, Lisa, we've been going together almost two years, and...
Person2: Brad. I don't want to have to use sex as a tool.
Person1: Tool? Tool for what? We've been going together almost two years!
Person2: I don't want to talk about it here, Brad.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated that after being in a relationship for almost two years, there seems to be a lack of intimacy or connection with Lisa.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing discomfort with the idea of using sex as a means to resolve issues or manipulate the relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'd be obliged if you'd get to the point, ma'am.
Person2: I am...I am...It's just that I know Martha'd want you to think of her boys as well as her girls...And if the girls are...dead...Ethan, don't let the boys waste their lives in vengeance!
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to be direct and get to the main point of their conversation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is urging Ethan to consider Martha's wishes and not let her sons seek revenge if her daughters are killed.

Dialogue:
Person1: Wait until I tell my friends I had you naked in my arms.  Won't they be surprised?
Person2: I haven't done a damn thing with you!
Person1: Oh, but you have.  You undressed for me.  I kissed you.  I even touched your prick.  How will you be able to live with yourself?
Intent_p1: Person1 is attempting to manipulate and guilt-trip Person2 by falsely claiming that they engaged in intimate activities together.
Intent_p2: Person2 is denying any involvement or consent in the intimate actions described by Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Weir is dead.
Person2: Then who the heck are you?
Person1: Your fear. Do you remember the Goliath, Miller?
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that they are embodying Person2's fear and referencing a past event involving Goliath and Miller.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning Person1's identity and expressing confusion about their presence after hearing about Weir's death.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh.
Person2: Josie, you rock my world. You're like the most amazing girl I've ever dated. You're so smart and fun and crazy! You rock my world.
Person1: You said that already.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing skepticism or annoyance at Person2's repetitive and possibly insincere compliments.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their admiration and appreciation for Josie, emphasizing how she is the most amazing girl they have ever dated.

Dialogue:
Person1: We must assume the machete was an intricate part of the game of hockey.
Person2: I'm thinking Rizzo was right.
Person1: Are you letting emotions guide your thoughts again, Delongpre?
Person2: Maybe we should go with them. Like you said, your Space Lab connections can deal with this thing. At least we'll be safe.
Person1: They are not going anywhere. I cut power to the  shuttle.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that they should rely on their connections at the Space Lab to handle the situation, as they have cut power to the shuttle.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that they should trust Person1's Space Lab connections to handle the situation and ensure their safety.

Dialogue:
Person1: Let's get us a photo and description. We'll have an APB out while we stake out the restaurant.
Person2: That is a problem. There is no description of Juntao. No known photograph.
Person1: Are you tellin' me nobody knows what he looks like?  Come on, there must be witnesses somewhere.
Person2: Juntao's standing orders were to kill everyone. There were never witnesses.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disbelief that there is no known photograph or description of Juntao, suggesting that there must be witnesses somewhere who can provide information.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining that there is no description or photograph of Juntao because his orders were to kill everyone, leaving no witnesses behind.

Dialogue:
Person1: Then what do you do?
Person2: I sleep it off.
Person1: But between the time you leave the cant ma and fall into bed in that old truck of yours, what happens, Charlie?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: That's just it, Charlie. That's what I'm driving at. You could do anything in that time.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the potential risks and unknown actions that Person2 could engage in during the time between leaving the cantina and going to sleep.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that there is a gap in their memory or awareness during the time between leaving the cantina and falling asleep in their truck, highlighting the potential for unpredictable actions or events during that period.

Dialogue:
Person1: Wrap her up in blankets. Bring the car around to the back of the hotel, throw her off the balcony, put her in the car...Done.
Person2: You don't think someone will have a problem with a body being thrown off a balcony?
Person1: We check out the area and wait for a time when it's clear.
Person2: What about the blood?
Person1: Someone goes to Walmart, gets some buckets, brushes, mops, Spic and Span, the works.
Person2: Have you ever done this before?
Person1: The reality is, you take away the horror of this situation, take away the tragedy of the death, take away the moral and ethical implications of all the crap you have had conditioned, beaten, into your head since grade one. What are we left with? What? A 115 lb. problem. 115 lbs. that must be moved from point A to point B. Now, a straight line in the shortest distance but we are denied the luxury of a visible straight line. But that line exists and I see it.I see that line. Trust me. Adam. Trust me...I can take care of this.
Intent_p1: Person1 is discussing a plan to dispose of a body and reassuring Person2 that they can handle the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and questioning the practicality and consequences of disposing of a body in such a manner.

Dialogue:
Person1: Listen to me, Neo.  I know why you're afraid to go through that door.  You can't get free of thinking that I could be wrong.  You must believe me.  There is a greatness inside of you, Neo.  A greatness that is going to lift you to unimaginable heights and that in time will change the world.
Person2: Morpheus, I don't know --
Person1: I know.  That is why it is so important for you to go.  Please, Neo, I'm asking you to find whatever respect you may have for me and trust me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convince Neo to trust in his own potential and follow his guidance to achieve greatness.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express uncertainty and hesitation about the situation despite Morpheus' plea for trust and belief in Neo's potential greatness.

Dialogue:
Person1: Gillian... Would the whales be at sea by now?
Person2: Yes... If you have a chart on board, I can show you.
Person1: All I need is the radio frequency to track them.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm coming with you.
Person1: You can't. Our next stop is the 23rd Century.
Person2: What do I care? I've got nobody but those whales...
Person1: I have no time to argue, Gillian. Or even tell you how much you've meant to us... The frequency.
Person2: All right. The frequency is 401 megahertz.
Person1: Thank you. For everything.  Beam me up, Scotty.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urgently requesting the radio frequency to track the whales before leaving for the 23rd Century and expresses gratitude towards Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to provide the radio frequency needed to track the whales and express their willingness to accompany Person1 on their journey.

Dialogue:
Person1: Sugar and cream for Goetz; I take mine black.  You're absolutely correct.  The politicians don't want panic headlines spoiling the Festival of Love.
Person2: Well, let's thank God you and Inspector Goetz are on the case, then.
Person1: Would you want to work with us on this?
Person2: Oh, my God, no!  I'm a clinical hysteric, with panic syndrome, and anxiety neurosis, agoraphobic, I'm afraid of everything, real and imaginary.  I never leave this apartment now.  Nobody ever comes here.  I just wanted to get your attention.  I write and I used to lecture on these crimes, but... I'm not competent.
Person1: I think you are.  I really admire everything you've done; it would be an honor to work with you, and we need all the help we can get, especially yours.
Person2: Inspector Halloran, that is so much bullshit, you don't like or admire me, but the beautiful part is I don't give a care.  That's the upside of having a breakdown.
Person1: Well, it's a hell of an apartment you got here.  I'm living one step away from the projects, myself, but I get to go to work every day, wading in blood and guts.  I guess the books you wrote about these sons of bitches paid off pretty good.
Person2: Will you go.  Andy, make them go.
Person1: You can't go out lecturing?  Tough shit.  Women are dying.  Where can I lay this stuff out?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing admiration for Person2's work and seeking their help in solving a case, emphasizing the urgency of the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are not capable of working on the case due to their mental health issues and personal limitations.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, I can understand if you and Foley are close.
Person2: We're not.  I'm helping him, yeah--
Person1: Wait.  Have you helped him, Glenn?  At this point, technically, I doubt you could be charged with aiding a fugitive. So you still have a choice.  You can help him and risk going down again, get cuffed and shackled, hope to God you pull a reasonable judge, not some hard-on.  Or, if you want to play it another way...
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the potential consequences of helping Foley and is suggesting that Person2 still has a choice in the matter.
Intent_p2: Person2 is being warned by Person1 about the consequences of helping Foley and is being given a choice to either continue assisting him or change their approach.

Dialogue:
Person1: Now look -- please --
Person2: Ben, I think we're two civilized human beings. Do you think it's necessary to threaten each other?
Person1: I am not threatening you.
Person2: Do you want to unclench your fists, please? Thank you. I can see in the dark, you know. I've been here quite a while.
Person1: I am trying to tell you I have no personal feelings about you, Mr. Robinson. I am trying to tell you I do not resent you.
Person2: You don't respect me terribly much either, do you?
Person1: No, I don't.
Person2: Well, I don't think we have a whole lot to say to each other, Ben. I do think you should know the consequences of what you've done. I do think you should know that my wife and I are getting a divorce soon.
Person1: But why?
Person2: Why?
Person1: It shouldn't make any difference what happened.
Person2: That's quite a statement.
Person1: Listen to me. We got -- we got into bed with each other. But it was nothing. It was nothing at all. We might -- we might just as well have been shaking hands.
Person2: Shaking hands. Well, that's not saying much for my wife, is it?
Person1: You miss the point.
Person2: Don't shout at me, Ben.
Person1: The point is -- I don't love your wife. I love your daughter, sir.
Person2: Well -- I'm sure you think you do, Ben, but after a few times in bed with Elaine I feel quite sure you'd get over that as quickly as you --
Person1: HUH?
Person2: I think I've talked about this enough. I don't know how far I can go, Ben. I don't know if I can prosecute or not, but I think maybe I can. In the light of what's happened I think maybe I can get you behind bars if you ever look at my daughter again. I have seen Elaine and I have spent the afternoon taking steps to insure...
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to clarify to Person2 that he does not have personal feelings or resentment towards him, but admits to not respecting him.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to confront Person1 about their inappropriate relationship with his daughter and warn them about the potential consequences, including the possibility of pressing charges.

Dialogue:
Person1: This is so patronizing.
Person2: Leave it to you to use big words when you're shitfaced.
Person1: Why 're you doing this?
Person2: I told you
Person1: You don't care if I die
Person2: Sure, I do
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because then I'd have to start taking out girls who like me.
Person1: Like you could find one
Person2: See that?  Who needs affection when I've got blind hatred?
Person1: Just let me sit down.

Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a sarcastic and dismissive attitude towards affection and relationships.

Dialogue:
Person1: Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --
Person2: Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.
Person1: Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.
Person2: Thanks for the diagnosis, Ben. Thank you. So let's just go to this fiasco if that's what you want to do. Let's just go on in. I'd rather talk to anyone else but you.

Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing sarcasm and frustration towards Person1 for their behavior and lack of honesty.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well sure, look at it!  Young trophy wife, I mean, in the parlance of our times, owes money all over town, including to known pornographers-- and that's cool, that's cool-- but I'm saying, she needs money, and of course they're gonna say they didn't get it 'cause she wants more, man, she's gotta feed the monkey, I mean-- hasn't that ever occurred to you...? Sir?
Person2: No.  No Mr. Lebowski, that had not occurred to me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that the young trophy wife owes money and needs more to satisfy her desires, implying that she may resort to desperate measures to obtain it.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement indicates that the idea presented by Person1 had not crossed their mind before.

Dialogue:
Person1: I believe you.
Person2: The truth is, I'm a lot of things, but communist isn't one of them.
Person1: But if you only went to one meeting, why does anyone care? Besides, why should it even matter if you were a communist?
Person2: Come on, Delly, look at the country today.  We're fighting communists in Korea, we're paranoid about the Russians, we've got this thing with the Rosenbergs and the atomic bomb...  You think they want "suspected communists" entertaining the American public with party propaganda like, gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of the Sahara?"
Person1: Forget about all that.  You want to do the right thing?  Then defend your name.  If someone says something about you that's untrue, you have to stand up and say so.  I know the law, and the law's on your side.
Intent_p1: Person1 is encouraging Person2 to defend their reputation against false accusations by standing up for themselves and utilizing the law to protect their name.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining the societal and political context of the time period, highlighting the fear and suspicion surrounding communism and the potential consequences of being associated with it.

Dialogue:
Person1: You won't?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: But you might.
Person2: I might.
Person1: Is that so? You might marry me?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: When?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: How about tomorrow? I don't mean to be pushy but --

Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies uncertainty and confusion about the situation and their feelings towards it.

Dialogue:
Person1: Where do I put ashore?
Person2: Cahuenga Pass. Make your way up through the mountains toward the Hollywood Bowl. You should be able to pick up Utopia's tracer there.  Once you go inside, you're on your own.  You know what you have to do with the girl, don't you?  We have to spare this nation her trial - for treason.
Person1: So you want me to take her out?  Is that an order from the President?
Person2: Let's just say it's what's best for the country.
Person1: By the way - who gives me the anti-toxin?
Person2: A medical team will be standing by.
Person1: Not you?
Person2: No.
Person1: Good.
Intent_p1: Person1 is being instructed to eliminate the girl for the country's benefit, with the assurance of receiving the necessary anti-toxin from a medical team.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to instruct Person1 to eliminate the girl for the country's benefit, without directly confirming if it's an order from the President, and to reassure that a medical team, not Person2, will provide the anti-toxin.

Dialogue:
Person1: We're not going to get a ride tonight.
Person2: I can't stay on this planet.
Person1: No one's traveling in this weather.
Person2: You promised you would get me to my ship.
Person1: I will. I will. We still have another day.
Person2: You promised.
Person1: What do you want from me? There are no cars on this road. I didn't ask for this stupid storm.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and helplessness about the situation due to the weather preventing them from getting a ride.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and disappointment that they cannot leave the planet as promised due to the weather conditions.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're unnerved because you've spent your whole life thinking nobody is looking over you, and suddenly your subconscious is an open book.  We are, for the first time, experiencing changes in natural reality by a force not our own.  That proves that --
Person2: -- we are not sure of that.  We are not sure we aren't all hallucinating.
Person1: If God is beyond our comprehension, and she --  -- is here for reasons that can't be understood, isn't God here?
Person2: Not necessarily.
Person1: Stop equivocating!  Unbelievable, how you equivocate!  You, the atheist, you're more dogmatic than any holy person I've ever seen!  This is happening, Kelvin.  Wake up.
Person2: Consciousness is enough, that's all I've saying.  Consciousness should be enough for anybody.
Person1: Who are you trying to convince?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration with Person2's skepticism and urging them to acknowledge the significance of the mysterious changes happening around them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing skepticism and uncertainty about the existence of a higher power or divine presence.

Dialogue:

Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and anger towards Person1 for bringing up a sensitive topic related to their father's death.

Dialogue:
Person1: After hanging up there a few days you will be mad for food...crazed! You will lust for it! YOU WILL BE WORSE THAN ANY OF THEM!
Person2: NO...NOOOOOOO...SHOOT ME! SHOOT ME! SHOOOOOOOOOT MEEEEEEEEE!!!
Person1: I'll bargain with you. How many of you are on the island?
Person2: Two of us...only two of us...me...and him.
Person1: I don't believe you, rebel. Where are your headquarters? On the mainland?
Person2: The mainland...is dead...a dead place...nobody there...
Person1: Where are your headquarters, rebel? Tell me or I'll let you hang there forever...FOREVER!
Person2: There are no...headquarters. There are no...rebels. Only the walking dead. Don't you see. They have won.
Person1: Then why did you come here?
Person2: To look...look for a place...a place to live in...an empty place...a... new...place...
Person1: How did you know we were on this island? Do others know? Will others come?
Person2: Nooooo. Believe me. There are no others...no rebels...nobody...it's over...it's ooooo....
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to extract information from Person2 about the presence of rebels and their headquarters on the island.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement conveys a sense of despair and resignation, indicating that there are no more rebels or survivors left, and that the walking dead have emerged victorious.

Dialogue:
Person1: Zerzura, the White City of Acacias, the Oasis of Little Birds.  As me about the scent of acacia - it's in this room.  I can smell it.  The taste of tea so black it falls into your mouth.  I can taste it. I'm chewing the mint.  Is there sand in my eyes?  Are you cleaning sand from my ears?
Person2: No sand.  That's your drugs speaking.

Person2: Are you remembering more?
Person1: Could I have a cigarette?
Person2: Are you crazy?

Person2: Because I'm a nurse.

Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to emphasize their professional duty and responsibility as a nurse to prioritize the well-being and care of the patient.

Dialogue:
Person1: You manipulated me into this...!
Person2: That's bullshit, Jeff!
Person1: You greased the rails!
Person2: I greased the rails for a guy who wanted to say yes. I helped him to say yes. Alright. You're not a robot, Jeff! That's all. You got a mind of your own, don't you?

Person2: I fought for you... and I still fight for you.
Person1: You fought for me...?!  ...you manipulated me... into where I am now... staring at the Brown & Williamson Building. It's all dark. Except the 10th floor! That's the legal department. That's where they mess with my life!
Person2: Jeffrey, where you going with this? So where you goin'?  You are important to a lot of people, Jeffrey. You think about that. You think about them.

Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to remind Person1 that he has the power to make his own decisions and that he is important to many people, urging him to consider the impact of his actions on others.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: Will... you saw this in the papers. The second one was all over TV. Did you ever think about givin' me a call?
Person2: No.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: When we go inside, you let me handle everything, you hear?  This is my man, you dig?  My informant. You know what an informant is?
Person2: Stooly.

Person1: Yeah, somethin' like that.  OK, now this is a nasty ass place. When you go into a place like this, the most important thing is control. You got to maintain control. You following me? You lose it, you get hurt. Now, you're my responsibility and I don't want you hurt. You understand?  OK, let's go.
Intent_p1: Person1 is instructing Person2 to let them take charge and maintain control in a dangerous situation to ensure their safety.
Intent_p2: Person2 is summarizing the term "informant" as "stool pigeon" and emphasizing the importance of maintaining control in a dangerous environment to keep Person1 safe.

Dialogue:
Person1: Today, I'm offering you a lousy job at a lousy wage.  You think you're better than that?  Fine.  Show me.  Show me that you're really willing to change and we'll talk about something better. A lot better.  But first, Jack, you gotta earn it.
Person2: How, Dick?  The way you earned it?  By marrying some rich broad owns the company, selling it off a piece at a time, then divorcing her?  What is this Knute Rockne, pull yourself up by the bootstraps bullshit?  Back in prison, guy like you, place like that, you were ice cream for freaks.  You were a goddamn dumpling.  Maurice and a dozen other guys coulda bled you till you had nothing.  Till you were nothing.  I saved your ass.  So you'll pardon me if I don't wanna sit on a damn stool all day saying "sign in here please" or "hey, pal, you can't park there."  Okay, Dick?  I can't do it.
Person1: Jack, I'm disappointed.  I guess I misjudged you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is challenging Person2 to prove their worth and willingness to change by starting with a low-level job, but Person2 refuses due to their past experiences and feelings of inadequacy.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies resentment towards Person1 for their unethical actions and expresses a refusal to accept a menial job after having saved Person1 from harm in the past.

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:

Dialogue:
Person1: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...
Person2: I bumped into him after you dropped me off Last night. I didn't feel like going home, so we went for a ride.
Person1: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?
Person2: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.
Person1: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.
Person2: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?
Person1: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.
Person2: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over.  I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.
Person1: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.
Person2: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.
Person1: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?
Person2: I just can't trust you anymore.
Person1: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...
Person2: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!
Person1: But what has to be different?
Person2: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.
Person1: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?
Person2: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.
Person1: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us.  ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing confusion and frustration over their relationship with Person2, questioning why things have changed and pleading for understanding and support in pursuing their dreams.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to break up with Person1 because they believe it is best for both of them, expressing concern about their future and wanting Person1 to focus on their education and career.

Dialogue:
Person1: Lecter carved up nine people - that we're sure of - and cooked his favorite bits. We've tried to study him, of course - but he's much too sophisticated for the standard tests. And my, does he hate us! Thinks I'm his nemesis... Crawford's very clever, isn't he? Using you.
Person2: How do you mean, Dr. Chilton?
Person1: A pretty young woman, to turn him on? I don't believe Lecter's ever seen a woman in eight years. And oh, are you ever his "taste" - so to speak.
Person2: I graduated magna from UVA, Doctor. It's not a charm school.
Person1: Good. Then you should be able to remember the rules.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the dangerous and manipulative nature of Lecter, suggesting that Person2 has been strategically placed by Crawford to interact with Lecter.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are not just a pretty face and should not be underestimated, emphasizing their intelligence and capabilities.

Dialogue:
Person1: Like following me around and pestering the people I work with wasn't bad enough, but breaking into my apartment--
Person2: It was open.
Person1: You got a lotta nerve.
Person2: Me?  You're the one who tried to rip off this piece.
Person1: Completely different situation.  I steal things in order to sell them.  For money. It's called commerce.  But some stranger sneaking into a girl's bedroom is...bent.
Person2: Bent?
Person1: Bent.
Person2: You make it sound I pawed through your priceless collection of underwear.
Person1: How do I know you didn't?
Person2: So saw my hands off, I left you a present.
Person1: Am I s'posed to be grateful?
Person2: That would be appropriate, yes.
Person1: How'm I s'posed to ever sleep there again knowing some pervo's probably touched everything I own?
Person2: You're that nervous, you're welcome to stay here.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and anger towards Person2 for breaking into their apartment and invading their personal space.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to downplay the seriousness of their actions and suggest that Person1 should be grateful for the present left behind, while also offering a solution to the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yes.  It is, George.  Yes.  It's a big decision.  And it's a big reward.  It's a big reward.  For one night's work.  But it's got to be tonight.
Person2: What?
Person1: What?  What?  The leads.
Person2: You have to steal the leads tonight?
Person1: That's right, the guys are moving them downtown.  After the thirtieth. Murray and Mitch.  After the contest.
Person2: You're, you're saying so you have to go in there tonight and...
Person1: You...
Person2: I'm sorry?
Person1: You.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the urgency and importance of stealing the leads that night.
Intent_p2: Person2 is seeking clarification and confirmation about the urgency and necessity of stealing the leads that night.

Dialogue:
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain here. I thought you might like to talk to someone.
Person1: About what?
Person2: You tried to take your life. You do remember that, don't you?
Person1: So?
Person2: In the sight of God that is a sin.
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: Do you understand that you have sinned? Gravely.
Person1: Leave me alone.
Person2: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.
Person1: Do you know who I am? You never heard of me, did you?
Person2: That makes no difference. All men are equal in God's eyes.
Person1: Are they?
Person2: Offer me your confession. I can offer you God's forgiveness.
Person1: I do not seek forgiveness.
Person2: My son, there is something dreadful on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm here only for you. Please talk to me.
Person1: How well are you trained in music?
Person2: I know a little. I studied it in my youth.
Person1: Where?
Person2: Here in Vienna.
Person1: Then you must know this.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to divert the conversation away from discussing their attempted suicide and sin by shifting the focus to music and testing Person2's knowledge in the subject.
Intent_p2: Person2 is attempting to offer spiritual guidance and support to Person1, who is struggling with thoughts of suicide and sin, by emphasizing the importance of confession and seeking forgiveness from God.

Dialogue:
Person1: What's it to you?  I declare it.  Here I am, back in the States for less than a month --
Person2: You're under arrest. Incredibly, you still have the right to remain silent --
Person1: What're you gonna do with me gone?  You'll drive your wife and kid nuts! I bet your daughter is just about ripe by now. What's her name, Janie?
Person2: Mention my family once more and you're dead.
Person1: You can't kill me, Jon. I've got something going this Saturday night ... it's gonna be worse than anything God ever dumped on the Pharaohs -- and only I can stop it.
Person2: You can tell me all about it -- from your prison cell.
Person1: Don't count on it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is defiant and threatening, implying that they have a plan that only they can stop and suggesting that they will not be easily captured or stopped by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is warning Person1 that if they mention their family again, they will face serious consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, I'm not saying you'd be able to do it without some hard work...
Person2: You still think this is about me, don't you?
Person1: Sure it's about you.  But it's about society, too.
Person2: Oh man, I'm gonna enjoy this one... Just remember, Jack, you did this.  You brought this on yourself...
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging that hard work is necessary but also emphasizing that the issue at hand involves both the individual and society.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that Person1 is responsible for the situation and will face the consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Who d'ya think you're foolin'?  I know you better than you think...
Person2: ...You're hurting me...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief in Person2's attempt to deceive them and asserting that they have a deeper understanding of Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that they are feeling hurt by Person1's words or actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, it does smudge after all--isn't that fascinating?
Person2: I thought you'd be interested. I'd like you to be in on everything, Annie. Not just the finished book, but how it's written.
Person1: Thank you for thinking of me.  Anything else I can get while I'm in town? Any other crucial requirements that need satisfying? Would you like a tiny tape recorder? Or maybe a handmade set of writing slippers?
Person2: No, just the paper will be fine.
Person1: Are you sure? 'Cause if you want, I'll bring back the whole store for you.
Person2: Annie, what's the matter?
Person1: What's the matter? I'll tell you what's the matter. I go out of my way for you. I do everything to try and make you happy. I feed you, I clean you, I dress you. And what thanks do I get? "You bought the wrong paper, Annie. I can't write on this paper, Annie." Well, I'll get your stupid paper, but you just better start showing me a little more appreciation around here, Mister Man.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses frustration and a desire for appreciation from Person2 for their efforts and thoughtfulness.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express gratitude for Person1's efforts and to emphasize the importance of being involved in the entire writing process, not just the final product.

Dialogue:
Person1: It's terrible -- the price society demands in the name of fidelity... ultimately?
Person2: Not fooling around.
Person1: I know, but I mean -- not fooling around physically?... Or not fooling around intellectually?
Person2: I see what you mean.
Person1: There can never... ever... be anything physical between us. You know that, dear.
Person2: I know Frederick.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the societal expectations and consequences related to fidelity, questioning whether it pertains to physical or intellectual fidelity.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies an understanding and acknowledgment of the boundaries set by Person1 regarding their relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: As for you, my galvanized friend, you want a heart! You don't know how lucky you are not to have one. Hearts will never be practical until they can be made unbreakable. I could have been a world figure, a power among men, a - a successful wizard, had I not been obstructed by a heart.
Person2: But I still want one.
Person1: Yes -- ....
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing the belief that having a heart is a hindrance to achieving success and power, and implies that not having one would have allowed them to reach greater heights.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses a desire for a heart despite the practical challenges associated with having one.

Dialogue:
Person1: Do you know what he's saying?
Person2: What who's saying?
Person1: Manzanita....  ... if one day I die, and you read this piece of paper, I want you to know how much I love you. Although I'll never see you again, Gypsy, Gypsy, your hair, your hair, your face, your face'
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing the sentiment of a heartfelt message left behind for someone named Manzanita, conveying deep love and longing for them even in the event of their own passing.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asking for clarification on who Person1 is referring to when they mention "Manzanita" and seems confused about the context of the conversation.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm curious about something.  I'm wondering just how it is you happen to know where the bedroom's at.
Person2: Wh . . . what are you talking about?
Person1: This morning when I came in on you and Grace, you swore you hadn't so much as been near the bedroom.  Now you make straight for it.
Person2: Come on, Jake--
Person1: Don't Jake me, boy!  It's a big house.  Odd that you would know your way, except maybe you've been in the bedroom before.  Maybe with Grace to keep you company.
Person2: Nothing happened with me and Grace this morning.
Person1: Then maybe this afternoon.  When I sent you to kill my wife you ended up sexing her instead.
Person2: Jake, please--
Person1: Is that what happened?  Did you even make it out to the desert, or did you just ply the afternoon between my sheets?
Person2: You're not talking sense.
Person1: Sense?  If I had any sense I would have killed you this morning and been done with it.
Person2: What are you . . . you can't . . . you can't kill me.
Person1: A drifter, a loner, a trouble maker like you?  Just passing through town, need money so he busts in on an, old man.  Only this old man's got himself an automatic, and he knows how to use it.  A man's got to protect his home.  His wife.  You're dead, boy, and your own mother wouldn't convict me.
Person2: What difference does it make if I slept with her.  You don't care about Grace.
Person1: You're right.  I don't give a damn about her.  But to betray a man's trust like that? That just makes a fool out of him. I don't like being made a fool of.
Person2: I don't blame you.  What man would? I admit it, okay?  I came back here and I made it with Grace.  But if you kill me you're making a big mistake.
Person1: Not from where I stand.
Person2: It's not me you have to worry about. It's her.  She wants you dead, Jake. She wants you dead and she wants your money.
Person1: What are you babbling about?
Person2: Think about it.  How do you think I got in here?  Did you hear any glass break?  Did you hear a door splinter?  How did the evening end? After you went to bed did she linger a bit?  Maybe just long enough to leave the back door unlocked?  Is that what happened?
Intent_p1: Person1 suspects Person2 of betraying him by having an affair with his wife, Grace, and is contemplating taking revenge.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to deflect blame and sow doubt by suggesting that Person1's wife, Grace, may have ulterior motives and could be involved in a plot against Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm glad you came.  I can't breathe without you.
Person2: I want us to be together.  But I need to know you're serious about turning over a new leaf.  I need a sign.
Person1: How about dangerous curves?
Person2: Of trust. Tell me your plan.
Person1: Kiss me and I'll tell you.
Person2: Tell me and I'll kiss you.
Person1: Freeze has turned the new telescope into a freezing gun.  He's about to turn Gotham into an ice cube.
Person2: I've got to stop him.
Person1: One kiss, my love.  For luck.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their love and desire for a kiss from Person2 before revealing crucial information about a dangerous situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing the need for reassurance and commitment from Person1 before moving forward in their relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: I saw the messages on your phone. Why didn't you tell me about Jake?
Person2: He's just a friend, Max. We were catching up after so many years.
Person1: But you talked about our issues with him. Why?
Person2: I needed someone to talk to.
Person1: It seems like you’ve never really loved me if you can just share our private moments with others.
Person2: That's not fair, Max. Loving you and needing someone to talk to are two different things.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing hurt and questioning the depth of Person2's love based on sharing private moments with a friend.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining to Person1 that seeking emotional support from a friend does not diminish their love for Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: What if she doesn't want to go?
Person2: She will if you think she should.
Person1: And you think it's best if I don't come.
Person2: No, that's not what I said. I'm not a dictator. If you feel you should come, then come. Just do whatever you think is right.
Intent_p1: Person1 is seeking reassurance and permission from Person2 to make their own decision about attending an event, rather than feeling pressured to do so.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing that Person1 should make their own decision about whether to come or not, rather than feeling pressured by their opinion.

Dialogue:
Person1: Your feet are cold.
Person2: Go back to sleep.
Person1: I asked you to wake me when Babe Brother comes.
Person2: You all act like two roosters.
Person1: I'm not going to let him get away with murder.
Person2: You and Babe Brother are so much alike...
Person1: He ain't nothing like me. How come a man has to have sons that are day and night apart? You ought to stop protecting him.
Person2: Hush.
Person1: You're always taking his side.
Person2: Hush.
Person1: I'm trying to make him a man but you keep babying him.
Person2: You're going to find yourself on the floor.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2 for constantly defending and babying Babe Brother instead of holding him accountable and helping him become a responsible man.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a warning or a threat to Person1 to stop talking or face consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: Dad, please stop.  Please.  I'm sure I know what you're talking about.
Person2: Sure you know, son, but I think you've been having a little problem with it. It's okay, though.  What you're doing is perfectly normal.  It's like practice.  Like when you play tennis against a wall.  Some day, there'll be a partner returning the ball.  You do want a partner, don't you son?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: That's great.  Now remember, it's okay to play with yourself.  Or, as I always called it --  "Stroke the salami!"  Ho-ho, Jim.  There's nothing to be ashamed of.  Hell, I'm fifty-two, and I still enjoy masturbating.  Uncle Mort masturbates.  We all masturbate.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to politely ask their dad to stop talking about masturbation and reassure him that they understand what he is referring to.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to normalize and reassure Person1 about masturbation by comparing it to a common practice and emphasizing that it is a natural and normal behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: I have cramps. I can't believe I let you talk me into this.
Person2: Come on, we've been double dating since the fourth grade.
Person1: Yeah even then look what happened. Michael Mortenson kissed you and Billy Sullivan threw a worm at me.
Person2: Well that's not going to happen tonight. George said Carlton's a nice guy.
Person1: Translation: a total geek.
Person2: Anything's better than Mark.
Person1: My shrink says he's not so bad.
Person2: Your shrink always gives you bad advice. He only hears what you choose to tell him. Mark's an asshole, he cheated, he borrowed money and never paid it back, he's never had a regular job.
Person1: He's a very talented musician.
Person2: Every woman at some point has to date a musician. I wish you'd get rid of Mark for good. Every time you break up you see him more than when you were going out.
Person1: I guess I have a weakness for him. It's those big brown Bambi eyes.
Person2: So don't look in his eyes.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses reluctance and frustration about being persuaded into a situation, reflecting on past experiences and personal weaknesses.
Intent_p2: Person2 is advising Person1 to avoid getting drawn back into a relationship with Mark by suggesting she should not look into his eyes.

Dialogue:
Person1: There's a slot for a boss loader on the new pier we're opening up.
Person2: Boss loader!
Person1: Ten cents a hundred pounds on everything that moves in and out. And you don't have to lift a finger. It'll be three-four hundred a week just for openers.
Person2: And for all that dough I don't do nothin'?
Person1: Absolutely nothing. You do nothing and you say nothing. You understand, don't you, kid?
Person2: Yeah yeah I guess I do but there's a lot more to this whole thing than I thought, Charley.
Person1: You don't mean you're thinking of testifying against
Person2: I don't know I don't know! I tell you I ain't made up my mind yet. That's what I wanted to talk to you about.
Person1: Listen, Terry, these piers we handle through the locals you know what they're worth to us?
Person2: I know. I know.
Person1: Well, then, you know Cousin Johnny isn't going to jeopardize a setup like that for one rubber-lipped
Person2: Don't say that!
Person1: ex-tanker who's walking on his heels ?
Person2: Don't say that!
Person1: What the hell!!!
Person2: I could have been better!
Person1: The point is there isn't much time, kid.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convince Person2 to stay silent and not testify against someone, emphasizing the importance of their current setup and the consequences of going against it.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses uncertainty and conflict about potentially testifying against someone, indicating that there is more complexity to the situation than initially thought.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't WORRY!!!?   You've GOT it!!? Are you CRAZY?
Person2: Roger, I've got it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and reassurance towards Person2's ability to handle the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reassuring Person1 that they understand and have the situation under control.

Dialogue:
Person1: A bad mother. By any standards. I've thought about it, you know, from your side, since then. I know just how bad I was.
Person2: Uh-huh.
Person1: I wonder did you ever think about it from my side.
Person2: Never.
Person1: No, I guess not. It was pretty lousy of me, I guess, to be a child at the same time you were. Not to stop being a child just because I had a child. I guess I was a real stinker not to be a grown-up when you needed a grown-up.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing regret and self-awareness about their past behavior as a parent and acknowledging the impact it had on their child.
Intent_p2: Person2 acknowledges that they never considered the situation from Person1's perspective and the challenges they faced as a parent.

Dialogue:
Person1: Are you crazy, you'll get stung!!
Person2: You're right, let's knock it down.
Person1: What do you want it for anyway?
Person2: For their meat.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the danger of getting stung while Person2 is suggesting knocking down something, prompting Person1 to question the purpose of wanting it, which is revealed to be for obtaining meat.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to knock down the object to obtain meat from it.

Dialogue:
Person1: Tell the court, Bright Eyes -- what is the second Article of Faith?
Person2: I admit, I know nothing of your culture.
Person1: Of course he doesn't know our culture - because he cannot think.  Tell us why all apes are created equal.
Person2: Some apes, it seems, are more equal than others.
Person1: Ridiculous. That answer is a contradiction in terms. Tell us, Bright Eyes, why do men have no souls? What is the proof that a divine spark exists in the simian brain?
Person2: Show this to the President.
Intent_p1: Person1 is challenging Person2's understanding of their culture and beliefs by questioning their knowledge of the Articles of Faith and the concept of equality among apes and humans.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a sarcastic dismissal of the questions being asked and suggests redirecting the conversation to a higher authority.

Dialogue:
Person1: What the hell did you think you were doing?
Person2: You have a real gratitude problem. You know that, Bruce? I need a name. Batboy? The Dark Earl? What's a good side kick name?
Person1: How about Richard Grayson, college student?
Person2: ...I missed Two-Face by a heartbeat. When we catch him, you gotta let me kill him!
Person1: We don't kill. Killing is what damns you. It-. What am I talking about? This conversation is over. You're going away to school.
Person2: I saved your life. You owe me. So either you let me be your partner or I'm going after Harvey on my own.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disapproval and setting boundaries by emphasizing the importance of not resorting to killing and insisting on sending Person2 away to school.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a desire to be a partner or sidekick to Person1 in their crime-fighting endeavors, and is threatening to go after Two-Face alone if not allowed to do so.

Dialogue:
Person1: I can't do it, Rita -- that's the policy here on colored prisoners, and I ain't about to change it, not even for a friend like you.
Person2: Charlie, just because a man and his family are colored, you--
Person1: Now look, Rita, I don't make the rules -- you puttin' yourself on a limb, comin' here, askin' me to do a thing like this. And I be damn if I'm going to jeopardize my job because you are in love with a little colored boy!
Intent_p1: Person1 is unwilling to bend the policy regarding colored prisoners, even for a friend, due to fear of jeopardizing their job.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Charlie is being discriminatory and unjust by refusing to help Rita because of her relationship with a person of color.

Dialogue:
Person1: So you're courtin' the preacher's girl. Well, just watch your step, boy, or he'll preach you right into hell.  I'm counting on you, Reverend.
Person2: I understand.
Person1: Wouldn't do for one of your people to sue at a time like this.
Person2: I know.
Person1: I'll talk to the Mayor.
Person2: That'll make the folks very happy.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 to be cautious in their relationship with the preacher's daughter and is relying on Person2 to handle the situation carefully.
Intent_p2: Person2 is acknowledging and agreeing with Person1's statements and actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Excuse me sir. Are you a guest of the club?
Person2: Yes, I'm with the Underhills.
Person1: They just left, sir.
Person2: They'll be back. He had to go in for a urinalysis.
Person1: Would you care for a drink while you're waiting? I can put it on the Underhill bill.
Person2: Great. I'll have a Bloody Mary and a steak sandwich.
Person1: Very good sir.
Intent_p1: Person1 is offering Person2 a drink on the Underhill's bill while they wait for them to return.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to have a drink and a meal while waiting for the Underhills to return, and is comfortable with the charges being added to their bill.

Dialogue:
Person1: "Row, row, row your boat..." I love "Row..."  Do - do you know "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat?"
Person2: That song did not come up in my research, Captain.
Person1: The lyrics are - are very simple. It's, er, "Row, row, row your boat, gently down the stream. Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily, life is but a dream.." The Doctor and I will start it off, and then when we give you the signal, you jump in.  Doctor, if you please.
Intent_p1: Person1 is introducing the song "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" and explaining how they will sing it together with the Doctor.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to acknowledge that they are not familiar with the song "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat" mentioned by Person1 and to address them as "Captain" in a playful manner.

Dialogue:
Person1: Y'know, you got an awful short memory for direct orders. I told you to stay beside me.
Person2: -- C'mon, Stephen.
Person1: -- You split the team, man. And what was that crap with the standpipe? You'd think you and a hose were never introduced before.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disappointment towards Person2 for not following direct orders, splitting the team, and not handling a task properly.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "C'mon, Stephen." implies a dismissive and possibly frustrated response to Person1's criticism and instructions.

Dialogue:
Person1: If you're determined to revive the crew now, I can handle the whole thing myself. There's no need for you to trouble.
Person2: I'm goin to do this myself, Hal. Let me have the control, please.
Person1: Look, Dave your've probably got a lot to do. I suggest you leave it to me.
Person2: Hal, switch to manual hibernation control.
Person1: I don't like to assert myself, Dave, but it would be much better now for you to rest. You've been involved in a very stressful situation.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2 should let them handle the task at hand because Person2 needs to rest after being in a stressful situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting their authority and insisting on taking control of the situation by requesting Hal to switch to manual hibernation control.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: Actually, I have no idea what the World's Record is.  I was just kidding.
Intent_p1: Person1 is accusing others of being jealous.
Intent_p2: Person2 is admitting that they were joking and did not actually know the World's Record, implying that their previous statement was made in jest.

Dialogue:
Person1: There you are, Selina. I've been thinking..I have some.."positions" opening up..
Person2: Stop.
Person1: Oh, what?  I offer you a job in implied exchange for physical favors and suddenly it's "sexual harassment..."
Person2: Can I be frank, Frank?  Your entire existence is sexual harassment. I accept there's not much you can do about it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is using their power to offer a job in exchange for sexual favors, and Person2 is calling out their behavior as pervasive sexual harassment.
Intent_p2: Person2 is calling out Person1 for their inappropriate behavior and making it clear that they are aware of it but have chosen to tolerate it.

Dialogue:
Person1: You better get going, hon.
Person2: Oh Louis, I just don't know about this--
Person1: I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy.
Person2: Louis, are you sure?
Person1: I'm sure.
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to leave because they believe that attending an event related to Gage's death could help mend their relationship with their family.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing doubt and uncertainty about the situation, seeking reassurance from Louis.

Dialogue:
Person1: The driver's name was Locus Fender. We know that he was in on the heist. INT. ARMORED CAR -- NEXT LOCUS FENDER  is behind the wheel of the armored car. His unshaven, disheveled appearance looks totally out of place in his security uniform. INT. VEGAS SECURITY LOCKDOWN -- NIGHT Taryn is now scrawling notes on a pad.
Person1: Where is the money?
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: I think that you're lying. I think you know exactly where the money is.
Person2: You're trying to scare me into falsely incriminating myself... and it's not working. I said I'd tell you everything I know. You and your friends behind the mirror.
Intent_p1: Person1 is accusing Person2 of lying about the location of the money from the heist.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting that they are not being intimidated into confessing and are willing to share all the information they have with Person1 and their associates.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't know. Please...
Person2: I'm going to be here a few more days. I'll be at the Inn. We have some time. Let's not say any more now.
Person1: No. Don't do this.
Person2: I CAN'T SAY GOODBYE YET! We'll leave it for now. We're not saying goodbye. We're not making any decision. Maybe you'll change your mind. Maybe we'll accidentally run into each other and ... and you'll change your mind.
Person1: Robert, if that happens, you'll have to decide. I won't be able to.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing reluctance and uncertainty about making a decision regarding their relationship with Robert.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their reluctance to say goodbye and their hope that Person1 may change their mind in the future.

Dialogue:
Person1: Brad!
Person2: I'm sick of hearing about that lame dog.  I've got a lot going for me.  I'm going places.  I'm going to be someone.  I'm gonna win my way into the lives and hearts of people even if I have to kill to do it.  I'll make the pathetic little crumbs love me. I don't even know why I'm wasting my time here with you.  I should be with my people...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and a desire to be recognized and appreciated by others, feeling that they are wasting their time with the person they are currently speaking to.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration with constantly hearing about Brad's dog and asserts their own ambition and determination to succeed and be loved by others, even if it means resorting to extreme measures.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm all right.
Person2: You saw him sitting out there in front, didn't you?
Person1: I was in his cabin--
Person2: What!--are you crazy?
Person1: I'll explain later--
Person2: If he comes near you again, I'll break his neck--
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to reassure Person2 that they are okay and will explain their actions later.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and a protective instinct towards Person1 regarding the person they saw sitting outside.

Dialogue:
Person1: This whole week has gone sour. It isn't turning out like it was supposed to.  I want to go home.
Person2: Who's being selfish now? I'm the one getting married. I thought this week was supposed to be about me.
Person1: We gotta slow down.  I'm so tired. Let's just get out of here.
Person2: I know what you need.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their exhaustion and disappointment with how the week has been going and is suggesting leaving the current situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration that Person1 is focusing on their own needs and not considering the importance of their upcoming wedding.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm not a murderer, Mr. McKenna.
Person2: How do you know if you've never tried?
Person1: This is a joke, right?  You just want to rattle me.  Right?
Intent_p1: Person1 is denying being a murderer and questioning the seriousness of Person2's comment.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that one cannot be certain of their actions until they have experienced them, implying a potential dark side to Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yeah...?
Person2: Mr. Wood, you have bounced your third and final rent check.
Person1: I'm real sorry.  My stockbroker must have transferred the wrong account... C'mon in, I'll write you another one.
Intent_p1: Person1 is apologizing for bouncing the rent check and offering to write another one because they believe their stockbroker made an error in transferring funds.
Intent_p2: Person2 is informing Person1 that they have bounced their third and final rent check and is requesting a replacement payment.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh? Anything else?
Person2: Oh yes. She thinks you like policing because you think you're right about everything. And you're the only one who can do anything. And that when you drink a lot of beer you say things like none of the other police would know a crook from a... um... bag of elbows.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking for more information or details about the situation being discussed.
Intent_p2: Person2 is conveying that the person being talked about has a tendency to believe they are always right, have a sense of superiority, and make derogatory comments about their colleagues when under the influence of alcohol.

Dialogue:
Person1: Did Bobby give you that or is there someone new?
Person2: Leland leave her alone... She doesn't like that. Stop it.
Person1: How do you know what she doesn't like?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's assumption about what the woman likes or dislikes.
Intent_p2: Person2 is telling Person1 to stop bothering the girl and to respect her boundaries.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're seeing bugs where they don't exist, Striker.
Person2: Look at this wiring.  It's shorting out under high temperatures.
Person1: You're tired, Striker, overworked.  That wiring meets all the safety specifications.
Person2: I know you've been subtly spreading the word that I'm having a breakdown.
Intent_p1: Person1 is dismissing Person2's concerns and attributing them to fatigue and overwork.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and suspicion towards Person1 for spreading rumors about their mental state.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't, Beth.
Person2: But I have to, Norman.
Person1: I promise --
Person2: Promise what, Norman?  Tell me!
Person1: Beth --
Person2: You think I'd belive you?  Believe anything you might say now?  After you lied to me about telling Barnes about my past.  About my problems.  My problems.  Not yours.  Not his.  Mine.
Person1: Don't, Beth.  Please.
Person2: It's either this... or I kill you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is pleading with Beth not to take a drastic action, possibly out of concern for her well-being or to prevent a violent outcome.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and betrayal towards Person1 for lying about sharing personal information, and is now considering extreme actions due to feeling cornered.

Dialogue:
Person1: Instead of worryin' about Reggie, you better worry about me...
Person2: Don't give me this, we were partners.
Person1: Billy, go ahead, break it...
Person2: No! Don't kill her.  I can get you the money.
Person1: When?
Person2: I can't get it until Monday. Honest.
Person1: You chickenshit punk...
