Person2: Honest. The place we stashed it opens Monday morning. I can't get it till then. Monday morning, that's when it opens. After that, I'll get the money to you right away...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and impatience with Person2's excuses and delays in getting the money they are owed.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to negotiate with Person1 to spare someone's life by promising to get the money they need by Monday morning.

Dialogue:
Person1: No way that jerk's driving you.
Person2: Maybe if you didn't go Rambo every time I did a lapdance, you'd still be doing it yourself. Meantime, I gotta feed my little girl.
Person1: Maxie's fucking with me. He put you with the spook to get under my skin.
Person2: Ho's a good guy --
Person1: Ho's a pimp! He encourages Wendy to turn tricks. And she's his wife!
Person2: Shhh. He'll hear you.
Person1: Good! It'll save me the trouble of repeating myself. He's not driving you!
Person2: Listen to me, Bobby. This is my job. It puts a roof over me and my daughter and you for as long as you want to stay.
Person1: I want you to quit.
Person2: Look at the bills. I can't. I'm not gonna put my daughter through what I went through.
Person1: I'll support you.
Person2: With what?
Person1: Max offered to stake me.
Person2: Yeah, well Max offers a lot of things. And I got news for you. He's not the sweet old man you think he is.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about Person2's safety and well-being, urging them to quit their current job as a driver for someone they perceive as dangerous.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are unable to quit their job as a driver due to financial obligations and the need to provide for their daughter, despite Person1's offer of support.

Dialogue:
Person1: They let you out?
Person2: Yeah, of course they let me out. Chickenshits. I gotta pay some class C misdemeanor ticket. So did I call it or did I call it? She spent the night, didn't she? Hm? Oh, that sucks for you, pal. Oh, shit.
Person1: You lied to me.
Person2: You want to know what your problem is, Jeff? You want to believe so bad, you'll buy anything. It's true. Look at you. You're gullible and you're gutless.
Person1: No, no. That's not the way it is at all. No, I stayed up all night trying to figure out how to protect my best friend. Wait, yeah, no, I was trying to come up with some lie so that you wouldn't have to go to jail for the rest of your life.
Person2: Wow. You did that for me?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Well, you know, all I can say is, you're a fool.
Person1: Why? Because I give a shit?
Person2: Oh, shit.
Person1: Because I care, I'm a fool?
Person2: Oh, Jeff, give me a break. You didn't even have the guts to go look in the van, did you?
Person1: Oh no, no. You know what? Forget that. No, you lied to me. You lied to me because you're gutless. You're a gutless, drunken looser.
Person2: I'm a loser. And I'm drunk. But I'm not gutless.
Person1: You know, and what are you doing here in the first place, man? He's just gonna call the cops again.
Person2: Good, good. I, I hope he does.
Person1: The sun hasn't even come up yet and you're drinking.
Person2: Hey, you saw that brown bitch point a gun at me last night, man. Did you think she was gonna use it?
Person1: I don't know.
Person2: You don't know?
Person1: No.
Person2: Come on. You don't think that after they called the cops on me, her and Mohammed had a nice laugh?
Person1: No.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses disappointment and frustration towards Person2 for lying and not showing appreciation for their efforts to protect them.
Intent_p2: Person2 implies that Person1 is naive and easily manipulated because of their willingness to believe and care for others, despite being called a fool for their actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Did you tell them that I flooded the school?
Person2: I didn't say shit.
Person1: That's not what I heard. Now they think I did it.
Person2: Well, if you're innocent, then you have nothing to worry about.
Person1: You know what? I think that you did it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and suspicion towards Person2 for potentially spreading false information about them flooding the school.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that if Person1 is innocent, they shouldn't be worried about the accusations.

Dialogue:
Person1: I haven't broken any laws.
Person2: Oh, but you have, Ma'am.  You lied to us, that could be obstruction of justice.  A man's been killed in part 'cause of your silence, I could make out a charge of reckless endangerment and I'm sure PETA would be annoyed at how you treat your cows.
Person1: The reason I lied is if I'd told you the truth, you'd just hunt it down and kill it which seems to be exactly what you're doing.
Intent_p1: Person1 is justifying their lie by expressing concern that revealing the truth would lead to harm or death, implying a lack of trust in the intentions of Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is accusing Person1 of lying and potentially committing obstruction of justice, reckless endangerment, and mistreatment of animals.

Dialogue:
Person1: You see Max Cherry in the dress department. We're about to be handed half-a-million dollars -- Man, look at me when I'm talking to you! And you don't think nothing of him being there!
Person2: Do Max Cherry and Jackie Brown know each other?
Person1: Hell, yes, they know each other. He bonded her out of county.
Person2: How am I supposed to know that?
Person1: You know the bail bondsman, don't ya? You know every last one of them folks is crooked as heck?
Person2: Why should I think anything's weird, if I don't know nothin' about them knowing each other?
Person1: Man, I don't want to hear your excuses!
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2 for not realizing the significance of Max Cherry being in the dress department and not connecting the dots about his relationship with Jackie Brown.
Intent_p2: Person2 questions the connection between Max Cherry and Jackie Brown and expresses confusion about why they should be considered suspicious if their relationship is unknown.

Dialogue:
Person1: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.
Person2: You did?
Person1: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.
Person2: Over a girl?
Person1: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?
Person2: No, I don't.
Person1: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here --  -- you know where I finally shot myself?
Person2: Where?
Person1: Here.
Person2: In the knee?
Person1: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!
Person2: That's terrible.
Person1: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.
Person2: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?
Person1: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake.  And you want to see my knee?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to reassure Miss Kubelik that despite feeling like it's the end of the world, they have also experienced heartbreak and attempted to end their life over unrequited love, but eventually got over it.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses sympathy and disbelief at Person1's story of attempting suicide over unrequited love, only to accidentally shoot himself in the knee, and questions if the story is fabricated to console Miss Kubelik.

Dialogue:
Person1: That shirt, Mr. Boone.
Person2: It's new.
Person1: I'm sorry.  It's too white, too distracting.  Would it be asking too much for you to take it off?
Person2: I'm not wearing an undershirt.
Person1: Pish posh, Mr. Boone.  I'm not your Aunt Tilly.
Person2: But it's just my face you want to draw.
Person1: Oh if it's going to make you uncomfortable...  Perhaps we can find something else for you to wear.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2 should change their shirt because it is too distracting for the drawing session.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express discomfort with the idea of taking off the white shirt because they are not wearing an undershirt and suggest focusing on drawing their face instead.

Dialogue:
Person1: You coming to the party tonight, Ostreicher, you jerk?
Person2: Depends if my date wants to stop by.
Person1: That junior chick?
Person2: Nah, gave her the Heisman. I'm working on something new.
Person1: Yeah right. I got an idea for something new. How 'bout you guys actually find some courage, remove the barriers, and use 'em.
Person2: Dude, it's gotta happen -- she's a college chick!
Person1: Nonsense. From where?
Person2: She works part-time at my dad's store.
Person1: Hah! Yeah, Oz, I bet it's more like your dad works at her store.
Person2: Dude, he does not.
Intent_p1: Person1 is teasing Person2 about his romantic pursuits and implying that he is not being genuine about his intentions with the college girl he is interested in.
Intent_p2: Person2 is indicating that he is interested in pursuing a new romantic interest who works part-time at his dad's store.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. Just open the drawer.
Person2: We never should have done this to him...
Person1: Well, what are we gonna do about it now?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disappointment towards Justin for not meeting their expectations and is urging him to take action by opening the drawer.
Intent_p2: Person2 regrets their actions and feels remorse for what they have done to someone.

Dialogue:
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: You're pretty when you're angry.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking Person2 about their desires or preferences.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to compliment Person1 by saying they look attractive even when they are angry.

Dialogue:
Person1: What happened to you?
Person2: Dad, did you do it?  Did you take that money?
Person1: Sweetheart, no.  Don't be ridiculous.
Person2: Swear to god, I need to know the truth.
Person1: Honey!
Person2: Swear to god.
Person1: I swear to god.
Person2: But I found the money.
Person1: Honey, it's not what you think.
Person2: What am I supposed to think?
Person1: Honey, about what?
Person2: You stole from them, you lied to me.  How do you think that's supposed to make me feel?
Person1: You think you know what this money is?
Person2: Yes, I...
Person1: No, you don't know what it is.  It's not for me.  This money's for you, for when you come back from England with honors to set you up, so you don't have to depend on anybody again.  Diane, I take better care of these people than their families do.  I care for them, I give them flowers, I feed them, I wipe their mouths...
Person2: No, but you stole from them.
Person1: I made their lives better.
Person2: You let me believe you.  You knew you were guilty, and you let me become a part of it.  God, how... how could you...
Person1: Alright, alright.  Go ahead.  When I'm old, give me someone like me, but go ahead.
Person2: I trusted you.  I stood up in court five years ago and I picked you.
Person1: Why are you being so hateful to me?  Is this because of Lloyd?
Person2: No.  I told you everything, you lied to me.  I would have done anything for you.
Person1: That's right, work it out.
Person2: No, I will.  I don't want to leave something out because I know I can say anything to you.  You're a liar, and a thief.
Person1: Take it easy how mad you make me, I'm the only dad you've got.
Person2: I'm so ashamed dad.
Person1: Don't say that, it's not good for you.  You're...
Person2: You're right.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to explain to Person2 that the money they found was intended for their future success and well-being, not for personal gain, and expresses disappointment in being perceived as a thief.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses feelings of betrayal, disappointment, and shame towards Person1 for lying and stealing, despite the intentions behind the actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Gal, you ain't right yet.
Person2: I'm right enough to stand on my own two feet. Now take this Goddamn chain off...
Person1: How you let men treat ya like they do?
Person2: What?
Person1: These men you up under. How you let them do ya like that?
Person2: Do me? Do me like this, you mean? Like chainin' me up?
Person1: You know what I'm talkin' about.  All that mess with ya teachers and... boys in the backs of trucks.
Person2: The hell you know about me?! You got no right to talk to me about that shit! The hell you think you are?
Person1: I've saved ya life, gal. I can do and say whatever I want.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's choices and behavior, expressing concern and asserting authority over them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and anger at Person1 for bringing up their past experiences with men and implying that they have the right to speak about it because they saved Person2's life.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, in any case, Rocky, I'll send you my book.  "Six Crises."
Person2: Whatcha predicting -- your boy Goldwater going to split the party?
Person1: Some say you are, Rocky.
Person2: The Republican Party was never home to extremists.  You should know better. This guy's as stupid as McCarthy, and McCarthy never did you any good in the long run, now did he?
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that some people believe Rocky is predicting Goldwater will split the party, hinting at potential consequences similar to those caused by McCarthy.
Intent_p2: Person2 is cautioning Person1 against supporting Goldwater and comparing him to McCarthy, implying that aligning with extremists like them could be detrimental in the long run.

Dialogue:
Person1: Listen, is this your idea of a joke?
Person2: More of a game really.
Person1: What kind of a game?
Person2: You seem to be familiar with the STAB movies. Here's how we play. I ask you a question. You get it right, your girlfriend lives. You answer wrong, she dies.
Person1: I swear to God if you lay a finger on her I'll kill you!
Person2: Maybe so, but right now, we play the game. First question, Your girlfriend's counting on you, Name your girlfriend's character in STAB 2?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing anger and concern about the dangerous situation involving their girlfriend and is determined to protect her.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to create a life-and-death game based on knowledge of the STAB movies, where answering questions correctly determines the fate of Person1's girlfriend.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't even tell me you're hot for Miss Titty Pom Poms over there.
Person2: Christy's a very talented journalist. I see a Pulitzer in her future.
Person1: I didn't know they gave them for Best Lip Gloss Retention During a Blow Job.
Person2: Me-ow.
Person1: Go ahead. Ask her to the prom. Get it over with.
Person2: I have absolutely no intention--
Person1: --Do it. I triple-dog-dare you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is teasing Person2 about their potential romantic interest in Christy and daring them to ask her to the prom.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they have no romantic interest in Christy and no intention of asking her to the prom.

Dialogue:
Person1: What're you doing?
Person2: I'm looking for a phone...
Person1: No, I don't think you can do that.
Person2: Watch me.
Person1: No, I don't think you can do that, Stanley...
Person2: Watch me.
Person1: Stanley.  Stanley... you knew the... Stanley.  You knew the deal when you signed on.
Person2: Deal's changed.
Person1: No, the deal isn't changed.  The Deal isn't changed. You can't ... what is it?  Money?  Money?  You want Money?
Person2: Money?  You think I did this for money...?  I did this for Credit.  Credit, paalll...
Person1: But you always knew you couldn't take the credit....
Person2: That's one thing, but I'm not gonna let two dickheads from Filmschool take it... are you Nuts?  Are you Nuts?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to remind Person2 of the agreement they made and is questioning their motives and actions.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their determination to not let two individuals from film school take credit for their work, emphasizing that they did it for recognition rather than money.

Dialogue:
Person1: How?
Person2: Avionics compartment! It's the only place. You better get Zedeck down there fast Unless, of course, you'd rather be a martyr than a savior.
Person1: Go! Take Serge.. and watch your backs.
Intent_p1: Person1 is instructing Person2 to go to the avionics compartment with Serge, emphasizing the urgency and importance of the task.
Intent_p2: Person2 is emphasizing the urgency of getting Zedeck to the avionics compartment quickly to prevent a potential disaster and implies that sacrificing oneself for the greater good is a noble act.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, Snoop, I don't know what Glenn promised you or what you think you're gonna get, but the deal is me and Buddy get half of whatever we take from Ripley, understand?  How you and Glenn cut up the rest is up to you.
Person2: Let's go outside and talk.
Person1: What's the matter with right here? It's nice and warm.
Person2: Warm?  Man, it's ninety-five degrees in here, sometimes a hundred -- the way Emanuel always kep' it so his boys'd sweat, get lean and mean like Tommy Hearns.  No, I ain't talking any business in here.  To me this is holy ground, man.  You understand?  I got to be someplace anyway.  Y'all want to talk, come to the fights tomorrow night, we'll sit down and look at it good. The State Theater.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their claim to a share of the profits from a deal involving Ripley, while also suggesting discussing the matter further at the fights the next night.
Intent_p2: Person2 intends to have a private conversation outside because the current location holds personal significance and is not suitable for discussing business matters.

Dialogue:
Person1: Your place or mine?
Person2: Despite my love of weird metaphysics and my rejection of most Judao-Christian ethics, I am, within the framework of a baseball season, monogamous.
Person1: Fact is you're afraid of meeting a guy like me 'cause It might be real so you sabotage it with some bullshit about commitment to a young boy you can boss around--  Great deal.  You get to write self- indulgent little poems all winter about how hard it is to find a man even though you just sent him packing-  So what do you really want?  You wanta be a tragic woman figure wallowing in the bullshit of magic?  Or do you want a guy?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's fear of commitment and suggesting that they may be using excuses to avoid a real relationship.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that despite their unconventional beliefs and rejection of traditional ethics, they are committed to monogamy within the context of a baseball season.

Dialogue:
Person1: Don't try and change the subject.  Oh God, it feels great!  He's just a little narcissistic, irresponsible and unreliable.
Person2: And Cal's this massive adult?
Person1: Cal knows who he is.  Did you notice how happy Joe was when the drugs came out tonight?
Person2: You weren't exactly horrified.
Person1: I don't have a drug problem.
Person2: Neither does Joe.
Person1: His sister does.  Big time.  And the New York Times says addiction is genetic -- I'll e-mail you the article.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about Joe's behavior and his potential drug problem, linking it to his sister's addiction and suggesting a genetic predisposition to addiction.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning the assumption that Joe doesn't have a drug problem by pointing out that his sister struggles with addiction and suggesting a genetic link based on an article.

Dialogue:
Person1: HEY!!!
Person2: Show's over unless I get to see what you've been working on after hours.
Person1: I haven't been working on anything.
Person2: Do I get to see it or not?
Person1: Bastard...  Sheila, don't go anywhere. I'll be right back.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated and reluctantly agrees to show Person2 what they have been working on after hours.
Intent_p2: Person2 is demanding to see what Person1 has been working on after hours.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jesus, do you make a lot of noise. Can't you see I'm trying to work?
Person2: I'm sorry. They just... they just slipped out of my hands.
Person1: A little less clumsiness around here would be nice, don't you think?
Person2: I'm a teenager. All teenagers are clumsy. It's because we're still growing. We don't know where our bodies end and the world begins.
Person1: The world is going to end pretty soon if you don't learn fast.  Look, why not make yourself useful? I'm just about out of smokes.  Go around the corner to the Brooklyn Cigar Company and buy me two tins of Schimmelpenninck Medias.
Person2: Twenty dollars is a lot of money. Are you sure you can trust me with it? I mean, aren't you afraid I might steal it?
Person1: If you want to steal it, that's your business. At least I won't have you around here making noise.  It might be worth it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2's clumsiness and noise, and suggests sending them on an errand to get rid of them.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses their teenage clumsiness as a natural part of growing up and suggests that teenagers are still learning to navigate their bodies in the world.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jack, I think I should get a job.
Person2: But we agreed your job is running the baby machine...
Person1: I know, but that was before.
Person2: Ah!  I almost forgot gas for the baby machine.  I'll grab your Snickers and get a place in line.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire to find a different job than running the baby machine.
Intent_p2: Person2 is reminding Person1 of their agreement that their job is to take care of the baby, and is also acknowledging the need to get gas for the baby machine.

Dialogue:
Person1: But suppose you find nothing but a wasteland. How will you survive?
Person2: He won't survive.  Do you know what sort of life awaits you out there, Taylor? That of an animal. If you aren't eventually hunted down and killed by apes, some jungle beast will devour you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the challenges and dangers of surviving in a wasteland.
Intent_p2: Person2 is warning Taylor about the harsh and dangerous reality of survival in a wasteland, suggesting that they will likely face a brutal fate if they attempt to survive in such conditions.

Dialogue:
Person1: Every time we talk, it ends up in an argument.
Person2: I know. You always challenge my opinions, but I still care about you.
Person1: It's just hard when we don't see eye to eye on things.
Person2: I believe it's our differences that make our relationship richer. We just need to learn how to navigate them.
Person1: You might be right. I'm willing to try if you are.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses frustration about their conversations often turning into arguments but is open to working on navigating their differences in order to improve their relationship with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 acknowledges the disagreements but emphasizes the value of their differences in enriching their relationship and suggests working on navigating them together.

Dialogue:
Person1: You see, Rose? Now that's the kind of dress you ought to wear.
Person2: Yeah, it's kinda nice.
Person1: You look very pretty in it, Rose. Really, you do.
Person2: Well, you're real sweet to make it for me.  There never was nobody like you. And you don't need to worry, I ain't goin' out no more.
Person1: Well, there's no reason you shouldn't go out, Rose... in moderation.
Person2: I don't want to. When I was lyin' there in that hospital bed at death's door I says to myself, I ain't goin' out no more. If I ever get outta this, I'll just stay home.
Intent_p1: Person1 is complimenting Rose on her appearance in the dress and encouraging her to go out in moderation, but Rose expresses her desire to stay home after a near-death experience.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses gratitude towards Person1 for making the dress and reassures them that they have decided not to go out anymore after a near-death experience.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't need that, Buddy.  I'm not Jack Kennedy.
Person2: No, you're not.  So stop comparing yourself to him.  You have no reason to ... You have everything you ever wanted. You've earned it.  Why can't you just enjoy it?
Person1: I do.  I do.  In my own way.
Person2: Then what are you scared of, honey?
Person1: I'm not scared, Buddy.  You don't understand.  They're playing for keeps, Buddy.  The press, the kids, the liberals -- they're out there, trying to figure out how to tear me down.
Person2: They're all your enemies?
Person1: Yes!
Person2: You personally?
Person1: Yes!  This is about me.  Why can't you understand that, you of all people? It's not the war -- it's Nixon!  They want to destroy Nixon!  And if I expose myself even the slightest bit they'll tear my insides out.  Do you want that?  Do you want to see that, Buddy?  It's not pretty.
Person2: Sometimes I think that's what you want.
Person1: You've been drinking.  What the hell are you saying?  Jesus, you sound like them now! ...  I've gotta keep fighting, Buddy, for the country.  These people running things, the elite ... they're soft, chickenshit faggots!  They don't have the long-term vision anymore.  They just want to cover their asses or meet girls or tear each other down.  Oh, God, this country's in deep trouble, Buddy ... and I have to see this through.  Mother would've wanted no less of me ... I'm sorry, Buddy.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their fear of being torn down by the press, kids, and liberals who are trying to destroy Nixon, and they feel the need to keep fighting for the country despite the challenges they face.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to reassure Person1 that they have achieved everything they wanted and earned it, encouraging them to enjoy it and questioning their fear and paranoia about being torn down by the press, kids, and liberals.

Dialogue:
Person1: I didn't mean to start that....
Person2: Don't be such a Grandma...I was always climbing something....
Person1: You were a monkey....
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging Person2's adventurous nature and playfully teasing them for being like a monkey.
Intent_p2: Person2 is playfully teasing Person1 for being cautious or hesitant by calling them a "Grandma" and reminiscing about their own adventurous nature in the past.

Dialogue:
Person1: It's worse than war. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been.
Person2: I doubt it. I don't think prison's so bad you don't want to remember it...
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the severity and harshness of a situation, suggesting that it is worse than anything Person2 has experienced, including war and prison.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing skepticism about the severity of the situation being described by Person1, suggesting that prison might not be as terrible as implied.

Dialogue:
Person1: Everyone knows what we look like, Dennis. We won't be able to hide.
Person2: Jesus, first Mars, now you.  You two need anti-depressants.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern that they will not be able to hide due to their recognizable appearance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and disbelief at the idea of needing to hide or take anti-depressants due to the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why not?
Person2: I don't know. Everything seems like nothing now against that I want you in my bed. I don't care if I burn in hell. I don't care if you burn in hell. The Past and Future is a joke to me now. I see that they're nothing, I see they ain't here. The only thing that's here is you. And me. I want you to come upstairs. Now. I tried to take everything last night, like you told me, but I couldn't. I couldn't take everything in a hundred years. It's the way we are. We compound each other.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: I'm freezing to death.
Person2: Come upstairs. I don't care why you come. No, that's not what I mean. Loretta, I love you. Not like they told you love is and I didn't know this either. But love don't make things nice, it ruins everything, it breaks your heart, it makes things a mess. We're not here to make things perfect. Snowflakes are perfect. The stars are perfect. Not us. We are here to ruin ourselves and break our hearts and love the wrong people and die! The storybooks are bullshit. Come upstairs with me, baby! Don't try to live your life out to somebody else's idea of sweet happiness. Don't try to live on milk and cookies when what you want is meat! Red meat just like me! It's wolves run with wolves and nothing else! You're a wolf just like me! Come upstairs with me and get in my bed! Come on! Come on! Come on!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing a desire to leave and go home despite Person2's intense declaration of love and desire for them to stay.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their intense desire for Person1 to be with them, emphasizing that love is not about perfection but about embracing imperfections and living passionately.

Dialogue:
Person1: Nobody's going anywhere with that gold now. Anybody tries to board, we'll know about it.  You can do what you want, Greer. But neither of us is gonna risk saving your ass down here if it comes to that.
Person2: Fine with me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Greer that they will be monitoring anyone trying to take the gold and that they will not risk helping Greer if they get caught.
Intent_p2: Person2 is indicating that they are okay with the situation and are willing to accept the consequences of their actions.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm sorry to put all this on you, Stanley --
Person2: I have money.
Person1: ...what...?
Person2: I have money to give you.
Person1: No.  No.  I have to do this on my own.
Person2: I can take you to get money.  I don't need it...I don't need it -- listen to me
Intent_p1: Person1 is refusing financial help from Person2 and insists on handling the situation independently.
Intent_p2: Person2 is offering financial assistance to Person1, but Person1 insists on handling the situation independently.

Dialogue:
Person1: I thought maybe I could put in a word for you with Mr. Sheldrake -- get you a little promotion -- how would you like to be an elevator starter?
Person2: I'm afraid there are too many other girls around here with seniority over me.
Person1: No problem. Why don't we discuss it sometime over the holidays -- I could call you and pick you up and we'll have the big unveiling --  -- you sure this is the right way to wear it?
Person2: I think so.
Person1: You don't think it's tilted a little too much --
Intent_p1: Person1 is offering to help Person2 get a promotion as an elevator starter and is suggesting discussing it further during the holidays.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about other colleagues having more seniority and potentially hindering their chances of getting a promotion.

Dialogue:
Person1: Of all the crazy things. I understood when you dropped out of law school. And during this whole mess, I've tried to be supportive. But, really, Letty, what can you be thinking?
Person2: I love him.
Person1: You're going to throw away our life together for some shared experience with a looney-tune that you misguidedly think is love?
Person2: Here's the ring.
Person1: No way. You keep the ring.     You'll come to your senses.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and disappointment in Person2's decision to leave their relationship for someone else.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their love for someone and their decision to leave their current relationship for that person.

Dialogue:
Person1: I want to do him!
Person2: I bet! Actually he reminds me of that one creep you went out with -- you always go for guys with some lame, fake shtick.
Person1: What are you talking about -- who?
Person2: That Larry guy -- what look was he going for? A gay tennis player from the forties?
Person1: Forget you!
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a desire to pursue a romantic interest, but Person2 criticizes their past choices in partners, specifically mentioning Larry as an example.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that Person1 has a pattern of being attracted to men with insincere or artificial personas, citing a previous experience with a guy named Larry as an example.

Dialogue:
Person1: Running out of time, are we? Tick- tock, tick-tock, how long till your witnesses fly the coop?
Person2: Fifty minutes.
Person1: Not much time to solve the crime. Tell me, detective, how did it feel taking blood money from Guissepe Torres? Did it weigh on your conscience or did you just not think about it?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the detective about their involvement with Guissepe Torres and the ethical implications of accepting money from him.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they are aware of the detective's past actions involving Guissepe Torres and questions the detective's moral integrity in accepting money from him.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh, uh... they were a present from Dana.
Person2: And you like them?
Person1: Well, you know... what do I know about clothes... I've never been the most fashionable guy -- it's nice to have someone do all the work for me...
Person2: So that's it? You don't ever want to see me again?
Person1: No, of course I do... It's just that right now I need to --
Person2: What's her problem anyway?  Did she actually tell you you couldn't see me?
Person1: No, no... not exactly... she just doesn't understand how I would know somebody like you...
Person2: What does she mean by that - "somebody like me"?
Person1: Just someone so young...
Person2: You must have done something to make her think you like me.
Person1: I... I don't think so.
Person2: Does that mean you don't like me?
Person1: No, of course not.
Person2: So, do you like me, Seymour?
Person1: In what way do you mean?
Person2: In whatever way you think I mean.
Person1: I don't know... I'm sorry, but Dana's a very jealous person. I just don't want to screw that up right now... I'm sure she'll dump me soon and we can go back to being friends...
Person2: I don't think you understand how I really feel about you, Seymour.
Person1: ...What do you mean?
Person2: Nothing. Don't worry, I won't bother you any more.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to navigate a complicated situation where they are receiving gifts from someone named Dana and trying to maintain a friendship with Person2 while also considering Dana's feelings and potential jealousy.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses their feelings for Person1 and hints at a deeper emotional connection, but ultimately decides to step back to avoid causing any trouble in Person1's current relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: Merde... Wait here. When I return you tell me about last night, huh?
Person2: But... I don't remember anything, I swear...
Person1: I leave these open. Maybe something comes back to you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking Person2 to wait for them to return so they can discuss what happened the previous night, hoping that leaving the conversation open might help jog Person2's memory.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing their inability to remember anything from the previous night and is worried about not being able to provide any information when Person1 returns.

Dialogue:
Person1: You got it?  Four year scholarship to a top college, plus Medical School or Law School or whatever Joey wants; pay off the $2,500 to my attorney, plus pay her fee in full, plus my annual consulting fee...
Person2: And give a deposition to the jUdge.
Person1: Listen, John, you better double my attorney's fee.  She's very inexperienced, but she done a great job for me. And give her your autograph.  She thinks you're some kinda holy man.
Person2: On the deposition for the jUdge, Bernie... I mean there's no way I can promise anything.  I can't tell him what we're up to...
Person1: You'll tell him I talked you out of jumping, right?  Just keep me outta prison.
Person2: I... I'll do the best I can, Bernie.
Person1: That's good enough for me.  You better take that "letter" there and get rid of it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is instructing Person2 to ensure that their attorney is well compensated and to handle the legal situation in a way that keeps Person1 out of prison.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to assure Person1 that he will do his best to handle the situation with the judge regarding the deposition and keeping Person1 out of prison.

Dialogue:
Person1: I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much.
Person2: Let me talk to him.
Person1: No.
Person2: You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law.  C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out.
Intent_p1: Person1 is hesitant to involve their partner in the conversation to avoid revealing too much about their plan and potentially jeopardizing their game.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to persuade Person1 to let them talk to their partner by offering to make it worth their while financially and potentially help finance a future project.

Dialogue:
Person1: Are you going to provide me with an opportunity to prove my love to my girl? Or are you gonna save yourself some trouble and step up like a gentleman and apologize to her?
Person2: Don't mess with me, man. You look like a clown in that stupid jacket.
Person1: This is a snakeskin jacket, and for me it's a symbol of my individuality and my belief in personal freedom.
Person2: ...Asshole.
Person1: Come here.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their individuality and personal freedom through their choice of clothing.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement is meant to insult Person1's fashion choice and express disdain towards them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Agnes. What did your mother do to you?  If you can't answer me, just shake your head yes or no. Did... did she hit you?  Did she make you do something you didn't want to?  Did it make you feel uncomfortable to do it?  Did it embarrass you?  Did it... did it hurt you?  What did she make you you do?
Person2: No...
Person1: You can tell me.
Person2: I can't.
Person1: She's dead isn't she?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: She can't hurt you any more.
Person2: She can.
Person1: How?
Person2: She watches... she listens.
Person1: Agnes, I don't believe that. Tell me. I'll protect you from her.
Person2: She...
Person1: Yes?
Person2: ... makes me...
Person1: Yes?
Person2: ... take off my clothes and then... she makes fun of me.
Person1: She tells you you're ugly?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And that you're stupid?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: That you're a mistake?
Person2: She says my whole body's a mistake.
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because she says if I don't watch out I'll have a baby.
Person1: How does she know that?
Person2: Her headaches.
Person1: Oh, yes.
Person2: And then...
Person1: What?
Person2: She touches me down there with a cigarette.  Please Mommy, don't touch me like that any more. I'll be good,  I won't be a baby any more.
Person1: Agnes, oh Agnes, Agnes I want you to do something. I want you to pretend that I'm your mother. Oh yes, only this time I want you to tell me what you're feeling, alright?
Person2: I'm afraid.
Person1: Please!  I want to help you. Let me help you.
Person2: Alright.
Person1: Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say? Of course you do. Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say?
Person2: No I'm not.
Person1: Are you pretty?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Agnes, you're stupid.
Person2: No I'm not.
Person1: Are you intelligent?
Person2: Yes I am.
Person1: You're a mistake.
Person2: I'm not mistake, I'm here aren't I. How can I be a mistake if I'm really here. God doesn't make mistakes, you're a mistake...
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to help Person2 overcome the emotional abuse inflicted by their deceased mother by encouraging them to challenge the negative beliefs instilled in them and empowering them to see their own worth.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express the emotional and physical abuse they suffered from their deceased mother, including being made to undress and being ridiculed, and to seek comfort and validation from Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: The wasps were meant for Michael - but there's only so much you can control, isn't there?  The great and powerful lasher - undone by a faulty ladder-..  Why would you hurt him...?!  Answer me.
Person2: I 1ove you, Rowan.  I've always loved you.  I only wanted to be in your thoughts. To bring myself into your thoughts - so I could be as we are now.
Person1: YOU VIOLATED ME!!!  ON MY WEDDING NIGHT!
Person2: Explain this to me --- violated...?
Person1: You bastard...
Intent_p1: Person1's statement expresses frustration and anger towards Person2 for causing harm and betrayal on their wedding night.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that their actions were driven by a desire to be close to Person1 emotionally and to be in their thoughts, rather than with malicious intent.

Dialogue:
Person1: Galvin, look, many years ago...
Person2: And don't give me this shit, 'I was a lawyer, too.' 'Cause I know who you were. You couldn't hack it as a lawyer. You were Bag Man for the Boys and you still are. I know who you are.
Person1: Are you done?
Person2: Damn right I'm done. I'm going to ask for a mistrial and I'm going to request that you disqualify yourself from sitting on this case. I'm going to take a transcript to the State and ask that they impeach your ass.
Person1: You aren't going to get a mistrial, boy. We're going back this afternoon, we're going to try this case to an end. Now you get out of here before I call the Bailiff and have you thrown in jail.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their authority and determination to proceed with the case despite Person2's threats and attempts to disrupt the proceedings.
Intent_p2: Person2 is accusing Person1 of being corrupt and threatening to take legal action against them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh, I used to be such a Catholic.
Person2: You still believe in God?
Person1: Oh sure... Gotta believe in God.  But I don't think God made man in his own image.  No.  'Cause most of... the bullshit that happens, is because of men.  No, I think man was made out of the devil's image and women were created out of God -- because women can have babies which is sorta like creating, and which also explains why women are attracted to men, because, lets face it, the devil is a helluva lot more interesting -- I slept with a few saints and let me tell you... Booooorring!!!... And so the whole point of life, I think, is for men and women to get married so the devil and God can live together and, ya know -- work it out...  ... Not that we have to get married.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing their belief that men were made in the devil's image and women were created in God's image, suggesting that the purpose of life is for men and women to come together in marriage to reconcile the devil and God within themselves.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies skepticism towards the traditional belief that God made man in his own image, suggesting instead that men were made in the devil's image and women in God's image, with the idea that the dynamic between the two genders is essential for balance and growth.

Dialogue:
Person1: There's someone out there, Mack, I know, some man killing for the fun of it, sniffing human glue, without regard to age or sex, without predicable M.O. Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.
Person2: I already have an employer.
Person1: If you won't do it for me, do it for your cousin, Nadine, right? The girl in the pink sweater.
Person2: Who told you about her?
Person1: You did. You were with her when she disappeared, right? She took you to the mall or the movies, you turn around and she's gone.
Person2: It was the mall.
Person1: I know you, Lionheart. I watched your mind work, heard your dirty thoughts --
Person2: Those were just fantasies.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking Person2 to help investigate a serial killer for the sake of their cousin who went missing.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that their previous thoughts were merely fantasies and not indicative of their actual actions or intentions.

Dialogue:
Person1: The acceptance of a secret is an obligation and in this case my dear, the obligation carried with it the necessity of dying if one betrayed that secret. You understand that don't you?
Person2: Yes, I understand.
Person1: Then, you also understand that you must die.
Person2: No.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing the seriousness of keeping a secret by implying that betrayal of the secret would result in death.
Intent_p2: Person2 is refusing to accept the obligation of dying if they were to betray the secret.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well...  what do you think about then? I mean...  well what do you think about?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Well ... if you don't remember anything, I mean what goes through your mind then if you don't remember anything?
Person2: Nothing. I do remember the car crash... I told you... I remember the glass ... I think about that sometimes ... I remember walking here, sort of. Now I remember this place and you. That's about it.
Person1: How do you remember how to talk?
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning Person2's memory and thought process when they don't remember certain things.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they remember specific details and events, such as the car crash and certain moments, but overall, they do not have a continuous stream of thoughts or memories.

Dialogue:
Person1: What?... Oh suck my dick!
Person2: What?
Person1: These assholes are saying that I have to go to Summer school and take some stupid art class!
Person2: Why?
Person1: Remember that stupid hippie art teacher who failed me sophomore year? I didn't think that just because you get an "F" that means you have to take the class over again.
Person2: You loser.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated and angry about being required to attend Summer school and take an art class because of failing a class taught by a teacher they dislike.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disdain towards Person1 for their negative attitude and lack of responsibility regarding their academic situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: No, I think it's better if you just stay here to heal. At least a week.
Person2: I'm going.
Person1: Quiet, or I'll sew up your mouth too.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern for Person2's well-being and is insisting that they stay to recover for at least a week, even threatening to take extreme measures to ensure their compliance.
Intent_p2: Person2 is determined to leave despite Person1's suggestion to stay for a week to heal, prompting Person1 to threaten to sew their mouth shut if they continue to argue.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're back.
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: I'm glad. Seriously... I'm very glad.
Person2: Angela, I just heard Sal was alive.
Person1: Sure. Why not.
Person2: Where? Where is he?
Person1: Nick, he's fine. He's in a hospital and they're fixing him up.
Person2: You talk to him?
Person1: Oh, sure... Twice a day.
Person2: What hospital is he in? Where?
Person1: Nick... Sal is very weak. He suffered a severe wound... and right now he doesn't want a whole lot of people to get involved in a whole thing.
Person2: Hey, Angela, Sal and I go back a long way.
Person1: He doesn't want people bugging him, Nick!
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to convey to Person2 that Sal, who is alive but in the hospital, is not ready to have many visitors or people involved in his situation due to his severe condition.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern and a desire to see their friend Sal, who is in the hospital, but Person1 is trying to convey that Sal is not ready for visitors and needs space to recover.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, apparently it was a big mistake to try talking to you. Don't you remember what we promised to each other?  Honesty - trust!
Person2: Come on, this isn't about honesty. You just need a good night's sleep. The way you toss and turn all night, even I hardly get any sleep.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disappointment in Person2 for not upholding their promise of honesty and trust in their communication.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1's current behavior and frustration may be due to lack of sleep rather than a lack of honesty or trust.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, no...
Person2: Then that's all you had to say.
Person1: But
Person2: You always been this selfish?
Intent_p1: Person1 is being accused of being selfish by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration with Person1 for not being straightforward and accusing them of being selfish.

Dialogue:
Person1: I was home on leave y'know and everybody's just worried 'bout making money, everybody's out for themselves, they don't even want to talk about it man, it's like Twilight Zone back there - you wouldn't even KNOW there's a war on here. My sister says to me why you have to go there like I started this...
Person2: Baaaa! Fuck it, they sold us out - so what! What'd you'all expect? Civilian life is phoney BULLSHIT man. They're ROBOTS man - watchin' dopey television and drivin' dopey cars, and they mess up, nobody dies. That's all right, you keep messing up, politicians keep lyin'. Cause it don't really matter. Don't mean shit. So what! Whatcha want - a parade! Fuck that too! No war time no grunt never got no respect. Till he was dead - and even THEN! You're fighting for YOURSELF man! You're fighting for your SOUL, dat's all. Remember dat. And it's some goddamn battle too - if you'se a man, wrestle with that angel...  ...Love and Hate - the whole shitbang show, that's the story then and now and it ain't hardly gonna change...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and disillusionment with the lack of acknowledgment and understanding of the war experience by people back home.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing a disillusioned and cynical perspective on civilian life and the lack of recognition for soldiers, emphasizing the personal struggle and battle for one's soul amidst societal indifference and hypocrisy.

Dialogue:
Person1: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. The projectors were run by hand, like this, with a crank. And you wound the crank all day long. It was really rough going! If you got tired and slowed down' boom! Everything would go up in flames!
Person2: Then why don't you want to teach it to me too? Now that there's no more cranking, and it's easier?
Person1: Because I don't want to, Toto! This is not a job for you. It's like being a slave. You're always alone. You see the same film over and over again, because you have nothing else to do. And you start talking to Greta Garbo and Tyrone Power like a nut! You work on holidays, on Christmas, on Easter. Only on Good Friday are you free. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!
Person2: Then why don't you change jobs?
Person1: Because I'm an idiot. How many other guys in town know how to be a projectionist? None! Only a jerk like me could do it. Besides I wasn't lucky. When I was a kid there was the war! When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!
Person2: No...
Person1: Good for you, Toto. Good for you... I'm only saying this for your own good...  Cooped up in here you die of heat in the summer and of cold in the winter. You breathe in smoke, gas fumes, and earn practically nothing.
Person2: But don't you like anything about what you do?
Person1: With time...you get used to it. Besides, when you hear from up here that there's a full house and that people are laughing, having fun... Then you're happy too.  So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!
Person2: Alfredo, go forget yourself!
Intent_p1: Person1's statement conveys the hardships and challenges of being a projectionist, discouraging Person2 from pursuing the same profession due to its isolating nature, demanding work conditions, and lack of financial reward.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses a desire to learn the profession of being a projectionist from Person1, highlighting the ease of the job now that modern machines have replaced the manual labor of cranking projectors.

Dialogue:
Person1: What did I tell you? Supposing he goes back home and makes a beef?  I gotta know exactly what you said. Tell me what you said to him.
Person2: Me? I said... nothin'. I said, I said, 'No, no, no.' Everything he said, I just kept sayin' no.
Person1: I told you this was dangerous. Remember I said, 'Ginger, this is a dangerous situation. Be very careful.' You yessed me to death.
Person2: If it's so dangerous, then why don't you kill him?
Person1: I'm not gonna kill him. Shut up. What, do you know what you're talkin' about? I'm not killing anyb-
Person2: Oh, well, then, have him killed and get it over with.
Person1: Hey, don't be such a smartass, will you?  I mean, I know the guy thirty-five years, I'm gonna whack him for you?  Fuck...  I knew this, I knew it.
Person2: What about my money?
Person1: How am I gonna get your money now? You think he's gonna give you money? Are you out of your mind?!  Look what you just did to this guy! If you would have just kept your mouth shut!  Ah, what is the use? I should've never got involved.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2 for causing a dangerous situation by not keeping quiet and is regretting getting involved in the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express frustration and concern about the situation, questioning why Person1 doesn't take more decisive action to resolve the issue.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't know how to say this, Jeff, except to just say it right out, so I'll say it. They do not want to air it.
Person2: What?!
Person1: B & W may have threatened litigation... CBS is on the block...  But you, I mean, I know how...
Person2: No.
Person1: No? No, what?
Person2: I do not think that you "know" for me... what it is to walk in my shoes...  ...for my kids to have seen it... for them to know why I've put them through what I did... the public airing of that... the testament to why I did what I did... you're telling me is not going to see the light of day.
Intent_p1: Person1 is informing Person2 that the story they wanted to share may not be aired due to potential legal threats and the network being up for sale.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement conveys that they do not believe Person1 truly understands the impact and significance of their experiences and decisions, especially in relation to their children, and they are frustrated that the truth may not be revealed to the public.

Dialogue:
Person1: I had a lunch break so I thought I'd come by and see you. Your teacher is a fox!  Why don't we discuss that after class. But the burning is totally normal.  Oh look. Class is over already.
Person2: I thought this was a 45-minute seminar.
Person1: Right. Right.
Intent_p1: Person1 is casually mentioning various topics and events that occurred during the class, including the teacher being attractive, the need to discuss something after class, and the unexpected end of the class session.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing surprise and confusion about the seminar ending early.

Dialogue:
Person1: Question withdrawn, you may step down.
Person2: You're implying th...
Person1: I said.  No further questions.
Intent_p1: Person1 is instructing Person2 to stop asking questions and step down.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that they were about to make a point or objection regarding the withdrawn question.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jefferson City?
Person2: No, Leavenworth.
Person1: I've never been in there. They just jumped you out of the blue?
Person2: I had to get up anyway.
Person1: Me, I'm riding along, minding my own business. Four cowboys come by and we decide to ride together for a while, friendly as can be. I always figure you might as well approach life like everybody's your friend or nobody is... don't make much difference. We get out in the middle of that frying pan and suddenly everybody's pointing their gun but me. I guess they admired my horse. She's a great one, a sweet little bay.
Person2: Looks like that's not all they admired.
Person1: Yup. The whole rig. I don't care much about the rest, but I surely will miss that bay. Least they didn't kill me. That was right considerate, I thought. They were laughing when they left me. Thought it was real funny. I walked for a little while but there was no use, so I gave it up. Figured it was just bad luck.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses a philosophical outlook on life and recounts a recent encounter where they were robbed but spared their life, attributing it to bad luck.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that the thieves not only admired the horse but also stole the entire rig, showing a level of admiration for the belongings taken.

Dialogue:
Person1: No reason to fret.  It's just a prick of the finger and a few drops of blood.
Person2: Turner blood doesn't flow pure in his veins.  Best play it safe, and spill it all.
Person1: I guess there is a reason to fret.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing concern about the situation escalating due to the potential risks involved.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that it's better to be cautious and spill all of Turner's blood, implying that there may be something dangerous or unusual about it.

Dialogue:
Person1: She's gone already!  Gone already! Couldn't wait.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: That's all you got to say? "Yes".
Person2: Yes.
Person1: She won't be here for a half hour. Think you can stand it that long?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Where do you expect to wait for her? Obviously downstairs with the other kids isn't good enough.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration and impatience towards Person2 for their lack of reaction and questioning their ability to wait for someone who is running late.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to convey a sense of calm and patience in response to Person1's agitation and impatience.

Dialogue:
Person1: But I thought you'd be cool if...
Person2: I want you guys to adopt the Buglet. I wanted everything to be perfect. Not shitty and broken like everyone else's family. Listen, once I have the baby, Vanessa is going to finally be happy, and everything will be all right. Believe me on this one!
Person1: A baby is not going to fix everything. Besides, I don't know if I'm ready to be a father.
Person2: But you're old!
Person1: I... How do you think of me, Juno? Why are you here?
Person2: I don't know. I just liked being your friend. I sort of liked becoming furniture in your weird life.
Person1: This...  ...this is what my life has become. Stuff in boxes. Stuff underground. Is that so appealing to you?
Person2: Yeah, I guess... Is this my fault? Is Vanessa mad at you because of me?
Person1: That's not the point. We're just not in love anymore.
Person2: Yeah, but didn't you love Vanessa when you married her? If you love someone once, you can love them again, I know it. My friend Leah has gone out with the same guy, like, four times. You're just not trying.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing doubts about their readiness to become a father and reflecting on the complexities of their current relationship with Vanessa.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convince Person1 that they can rekindle their love for Vanessa by pointing out examples of people who have successfully rekindled relationships in the past.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yeah, well, me too.
Person2: Trouble with the car again?
Person1: You could say.  I don't even have it yet.
Person2: Darrell giving you problems?
Person1: He did more work on the car.  He wants fifty bucks extra for it.
Person2: Fifty dollars more.  That's a lot of money when you don't have a dime. And where'd you plan on getting the money from?  Maybe you thought you'd pay your friend Jake McKenna a visit.
Person1: It's not like that.
Person2: Maybe you heard old Jake's got some money stashed away and you thought you'd help yourself to a little.
Person1: Wait a minute.  Just listen to me--
Person2: You thought you'd come in here in the middle of the night and wham! Wail off and clock old Jake McKenna and turn his brains into wall paper.
Person1: Jake--
Person2: And then with Jake out of the way you could borrow two-hundred dollars.  Or maybe two-thousand.  Or twenty-thousand.  Who's to stop you? Not Jake McKenna, 'cause old Jake would be dead.
Person1: That's not the reason I'm here.  I swear it.
Person2: There's another reason?  It better be good.
Person1: I came for Grace.
Person2: You came to take my wife from me?
Person1: I came to kill her.
Person2: Liar.
Person1: It's the truth, Jake.
Person2: That's a thick change of heart.
Person1: Yeah, well, a couple of hours ago I just about killed some guy over a girl.  Not for money, for a girl. And she was just going to stand there and let it happen, or let him kill me.  Same way Grace played us this morning.  I don't like that, Jake.  Not twice in one day.  And maybe I'm so pissed I'd twist the next off my own Grandma to get out of here.
Person2: That's a lot of talk.  A whole lot of talk.
Person1: Damn it, Jake.  If I don't get out of here some guys are going to come gunning for me.  And if it comes down to me or Grace, then I pick Grace.  You were going to give me thirteen-thousand.  Give me two- hundred.  I'll kill her and dump the body where no one will ever find it. But I need the money.  I've got to have the money.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing desperation and a willingness to do whatever it takes to get out of a dangerous situation, even if it means resorting to extreme measures like killing someone for money.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disbelief and shock at Person1's sudden confession and request to be paid to kill Grace, questioning the sudden change of heart and motives behind the request.

Dialogue:
Person1: You don't expect me to believe that for one minute, do you?  Does it matter what's on them? Really? ... Murder, Dick?  Sex?  Your secrets, your fantasies?  Or just me and you and ...
Person2: Don't be ridiculous!
Person1: I remember Alger Hiss.  I know how ugly you can be -- you're capable of anything.  But you see, it doesn't really matter, at the end of the day, what's on them.  Because you have absolutely no remorse.  No concept of remorse.  You want the tapes to get out, you want them to see you at your worst ...
Person2: You're drunk!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing skepticism and accusing Person2 of having no remorse and wanting the tapes to be seen at their worst.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement "You're drunk!" is intended to dismiss Person1's accusations and insinuations as being influenced by alcohol and not based on reality.

Dialogue:
Person1: You haven't said a word since we left the club -- what happened back there?
Person2: I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to tell you or not.
Person1: I don't think I follow you.
Person2: He said if I told anybody it could prove fatal for them as well as me.
Person1: Who said?
Person2: That's what I'm not supposed to say.
Person1: Stop this nonsense! If you're in some sort of trouble I want to know about it.
Person2: Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying me.
Person1: I wasn't --
Person2: Yes, you were -- you called it nonsense. Being murdered in cold blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it happens to you sometime.
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to understand why Person2 is being silent and is concerned about their well-being, but Person2 is hesitant to share information due to a threat they received.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing fear and frustration about a serious threat they received but is hesitant to disclose the details due to potential danger to others.

Dialogue:
Person1: Give me a break. Remember five years ago, when your kidneys failed? If you were a loser would they have been able to find a donor with an exact tissue match? What are the odds of that, one in a million?
Person2: Oh, so I'm lucky because my brother got killed in an explosion?
Person1: I never said that. I'm saying your lucky those kids found his kidneys.  Besides, your brother Jimmy never gave a shit about you.
Intent_p1: Person1 is implying that Person2 should be grateful for the fortunate circumstances surrounding the kidney transplant, despite the tragic loss of their brother.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing frustration and disbelief at the implication that they are lucky for receiving their brother's kidneys after his death.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know, to me dressing up was always just putting on my dark blue suit.
Person2: I don't like those studs they've sent.  I want you to have pearls. Nice big pearls.
Person1: Now, I'm not going to wear ear- rings, I can tell you that.
Person2: Cute.  Let's have some drinks.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement implies that they prefer a simple and classic style when it comes to dressing up.
Intent_p2: Person2 is suggesting that Person1 should wear pearls instead of studs and is dismissive of the idea of wearing earrings.

Dialogue:
Person1: And I really wanted some ice cream too.
Person2: I can run out and get it.
Person1: No!  No!  You won't come back either.
Person2: I can't be staying long anyway.
Person1: How long then?
Person2: Long enough for us to do the nasty.
Person1: That's out.  No!  It's too hot! You think I'm gonna let you get some, put on your clothes, then run outta here and never see you again in who knows when?
Person2: A quickie is good every once in a blue moon.
Person1: You a blue-moon fool.
Person2: Then we'll do something else.
Person1: What else?
Person2: Trust me.
Person1: Trust you?  Because of trusting you we have a son.  Remember your son?
Person2: Trust me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing skepticism and reluctance towards Person2's suggestion due to past experiences and lack of trust.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to reassure Person1 that they have a plan for spending time together and that they can be trusted.

Dialogue:
Person1: That wouldn't be very sporting. Remember Huxley?  "His play is always fair and just."
Person2: You're groping.  I have been fair. It's my move now.
Person1: I'll give you anything you want. Anything!  Please!
Person2: Don't beg, Peter.  She has to die.  I can't win unless she dies.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing reluctance and desperation, willing to offer anything to avoid a situation where someone has to die.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting that in order to win, the other person must die, and they should not beg for mercy.

Dialogue:
Person1: Oh my God. You're completely p-whipped.
Person2: No, I'm not.
Person1: P-whipped, p-whipped.
Person2: What's wrong with you? Why are you acting this way?
Intent_p1: Person1 is teasing Person2 for being overly submissive or controlled by their partner.
Intent_p2: Person2 is denying the accusation of being "p-whipped" and questioning why Person1 is behaving in such a manner.

Dialogue:
Person1: You followed me. I can't believe it!
Person2: I didn't follow you!
Person1: You followed me!
Person2: Why? 'Cause I... was walkin' along a block behind you staring at you? That's not following!
Person1: Well, what is your definition of following?
Person2: Following is different. I was spying.
Person1: Do you realize how paranoid you are?
Person2: Paranoid? I'm looking at you. You got your arms around another guy.
Person1: That is the worst kind of paranoia.
Person2: Yeah-well, I didn't start out spying. I-I thought I'd surprise yuh. Pick you up after school.
Person1: Yeah-well, you wanted to keep the relationship flexible, remember? It's your phrase.
Person2: Oh, stop it. But you were having an affair with your college professor. That jerk that teaches that incredible crap course "Contemporary Crisis in Western Man"!
Person1: "Existential Motifs in Russian Literature"! You're really close.
Person2: What's the difference? It's all mental masturbation.
Person1: Oh, well, now we're finally getting to a subject you know something about!
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and frustration at Person2's behavior and accusations.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to deflect the accusation of following by claiming they were spying instead and to bring up the issue of infidelity in the relationship.

Dialogue:
Person1: Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?
Person2: But I got a train to make.
Person1: It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall.
Person2: But what about all these other people?
Person1: We'll get 'em!  Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here, ya know.  We go around advertising ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh?  You think I'm wearin' this rag here 'cause I like it?  Christ, everybody thinks life's a holiday or somethin' when you got a badge.  I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes.
Intent_p1: Person1 is explaining the necessity of impounding money to ensure its authenticity and expressing frustration about the lack of appreciation for their efforts in catching counterfeiters.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about catching their train and questioning the fairness of holding them up when there are other people involved.

Dialogue:
Person1: Dude, somebody's on the rag.
Person2: Shhh!
Intent_p1: Person1 is making a crude and disrespectful comment about someone menstruating.
Intent_p2: Person2 is indicating to Person1 to be quiet or stop talking about the topic being discussed.

Dialogue:
Person1: Of course I like women... I LOVE 'em.
Person2: You don't love ME.
Person1: No... right... this is RAPE... Mark you, I'm not saying I couldn't get to like you... in fact... well, to be quite honest, I prefer it when there's some sort of mutual feeling between two people...
Person2: What -- rape?
Person1: No. It isn't rape then, is it?
Person2: Oh, get it over with.
Person1: I don't suppose... no...
Person2: What?
Person1: I don't suppose you... you DO like me at all?
Person2: What d'you expect? You come in here, burn my village, kill my family and try to rape me...
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to justify their actions and express a preference for mutual feelings in relationships, despite the serious accusations made by Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses frustration and disbelief towards Person1 for their inappropriate and disrespectful behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why did you go to the boss with that report without showing me first?
Person2: I thought it was the right thing to do. It was complete.
Person1: That was our project, Aria. You just threw me under the bus.
Person2: It wasn't like that. I just wanted to be efficient.
Person1: You will be sorry for this. Trust is hard to rebuild.
Person2: Derek, I didn't intend to sideline you. I hope we can move past this.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disappointment and betrayal towards Person2 for going to the boss with a report without consulting them first.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express regret and a desire to reconcile with Person1 after unintentionally causing conflict by going to the boss with the report without showing it to Person1 first.

Dialogue:
Person1: Charlie MacCorry!...You weren't fixin' to marry HIM??
Person2: She sure is!...An' don't think your comin' back is goin' to change it!
Person1: As to that, I don't know, Charlie... We hadn't got around to talkin' marriage...
Person2: What right you got to be talkin' marriage to any decent woman...
Person1: If you're talkin' about that crazy murder charge...
Person2: AND other things...Mebbe you thought you was gettin' away with being comical about that Indian wife you took...I bet she wasn't the first squaw you...
Intent_p1: Person1 is denying the assumption that they were planning to marry someone named Charlie and clarifying that they had not discussed marriage yet.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Person1 has no right to discuss marriage with any woman due to his questionable behavior, including a murder charge and potentially disrespectful actions towards his previous Indian wife.

Dialogue:
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: It's what you want from me.
Intent_p1: Person1 is questioning the expectations or desires that Person2 has towards them.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that the expectations or desires being discussed are actually coming from Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: I'm telling you he's dirt. He's a douche bag, gutter slime, dog crap, puke chunks...
Person2: Hey, hey! I'm eating here!
Person1: Audrey, you're too damned nice, that's your problem. Nice gets you nothin' in this town. You gotta be a killer to get ahead, you know what I'm sayin'? I'm sorry, baby, but you just don't got what it takes.
Intent_p1: Person1 is criticizing Audrey for being too nice and suggesting that she needs to be more ruthless to succeed in their town.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing discomfort with the negative and inappropriate language being used while also disagreeing with the idea that being ruthless is necessary for success.

Dialogue:
Person1: I hardly know him. I saw him only once, some years ago. I can't even remember him.
Person2: In any case he's asking you to come and stay with him.
Person1: I don't want to leave the convent, Mother.
Person2: I'm afraid that his health is not good. He's your only relative and you ought to say farewell to him before taking your vows. You will certainly never see him again.
Intent_p1: Person1 is hesitant to leave the convent to visit a relative who they hardly know and have no recollection of, but is being urged to do so due to the relative's poor health and the likelihood of never seeing him again.
Intent_p2: Person2 is urging Person1 to visit their relative who is unwell before taking their vows at the convent, emphasizing the importance of saying farewell as it may be the last chance to see him.

Dialogue:
Person1: THAT is your dream, not mine. My dream is so far beyond anything YOU PEOPLE could even imagine.
Person2: Watch your tone, mister.
Person1: Why don't you just admit what this is really all about? I'm not your real kid and you can't control me anymore.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their independence and challenging the authority of Person2 by expressing that their dreams and identity are separate and beyond the expectations of others.
Intent_p2: Person2 is warning Person1 to be respectful and mindful of their tone.

Dialogue:
Person1: You know it amazes me that someone as bright as you can be so horrible.
Person2: What? Another letter from your friend?
Person1: This is my favorite part.  Even more treacherous and dangerous than he is charming and fascinating. He has never taken a single step or spoken a single word without some dishonorable or criminal intention. Every young girl he has successfully pursued has regretted it.
Person2: You know you could at least have the decency of telling me who's badmouthing me so I might have the opportunity to confront them face to face. How do you know it's not some girl who's pissed off at me for breaking up with her?
Person1: I sincerely doubt it.
Person2: Give me the letter.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing disbelief and disappointment in Person2's behavior and character based on information received in a letter.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to confront the person badmouthing them and potentially address any misunderstandings or confrontations face to face.

Dialogue:
Person1: God... why of course -- we'd forgotten about him!  Strange, I don't seem to remember seeing him at Agincourt.
Person2: Damn right!
Person1: Oh, but I forgot!  It was a Sunday... that explains it.  God's day off.
Intent_p1: Person1 is sarcastically commenting on the absence of God during the Battle of Agincourt, attributing it to God's supposed day off on Sundays.
Intent_p2: Person2 is sarcastically agreeing with Person1's statement about God not being present at Agincourt.

Dialogue:
Person1: You need to come down here, everybody meets everybody.  Ho ho ho.  Ha ha ha. We do one for good faith and then we talk about airplanes.
Person2: I can't go anywhere, Diego.  I'm on parole.  I can't leave the state.
Person1: But you must.  It's the only way.
Person2: I just got released five minutes ago.
Person1: George, are we gonna do this or not?
Intent_p1: Person1 is urging Person2 to come meet everyone in person, emphasizing the importance of the meeting and suggesting it is necessary despite any obstacles.
Intent_p2: Person2 is explaining to Person1 that they cannot leave the state because they are on parole and were just released five minutes ago.

Dialogue:
Person1: Well, just stop for a little second and think about it. Will ya do that for me?
Person2: Okay, I'm thinking.
Person1: No. You're too busy being a smart aleck to be thinkin'. Now I want ya to think and quit bein' such a smart aleck. Can ya do that for me?
Person2: Look ... where's this going? What do you want me to do?
Person1: There's sometimes a buggy. How many drivers does a buggy have?
Person2: One.
Person1: So let's just say I'm drivin' this buggy and you fix your attitude and you can ride along with me.
Person2: Okay.
Person1: Now I know a few things. I know you have had a rough day. You're probably thinkin' I don't know the half of it, but in actual fact I know every part of it. The business of gittin' thrown off your movie, the heartache of seeing your wife with another man... losin' access to that precious film vault...
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to get Person2 to stop being a smart aleck and to think seriously about their situation and emotions.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to understand where the conversation is heading and what Person1 wants them to do.

Dialogue:
Person1: You should know if you bring in anything over ten thousand you have to declare it. You forgot or what? You could get a two hundred and fifty thousand dollar fine, plus two years in prison. Now you want to talk to us about it, or you want to talk to Customs?
Person2: I'm not saying another word.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 about the consequences of not declaring items over ten thousand dollars and is giving them the option to discuss it with them or with Customs.
Intent_p2: Person2 is choosing to remain silent and not provide any further information.

Dialogue:
