Person1: Your guilt is because you feel the same.
Person2: Oh, please, I have to go.  I have to get my teeth cleaned.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2's guilt stems from their own feelings and experiences.
Intent_p2: Person2 is dismissing Person1's statement and using a mundane excuse to avoid further discussion.

Dialogue:
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: You know what I want.  You know why I need you.
Person1: You need to leave.
Person2: I know everything about you, Diana.
Person1: That's it, we're done.
Intent_p1: Person1 is setting boundaries and ending the relationship with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 is implying that they have information about Person1 (Diana) that gives them power or leverage in the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Look, you little clown, do you know how many people I've hired for you? Do you know how many people are waiting?
Person2: Leave him alone!
Person1: I'm paying these people. Do you realize that?
Person2: He's doing his best.
Person1: I'm paying people just to wait for you. It's ridiculous!
Person2: You know what's ridiculous? Your libretto, that's what's ridiculous. Only an idiot would ask Wolfi to work on that stuff!
Person1: Oh yes? And what's so intelligent about writing a Requiem?
Person2: Money! Money!
Person1: You're mad! She's mad, Wolfi.
Person2: Oh yes, and who are you? He's worked for Kings. For the Emperor.  Who are you?
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated with Person2 for defending Wolfi's work and questions the intelligence of hiring him, highlighting the financial aspect of the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is defending Wolfi's efforts and talent, highlighting the absurdity of Person1's criticism and emphasizing Wolfi's prestigious work history.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're a son of a bitch.
Person2: Yes--well--uh--that's another one of those statements which more or less automatically requires an apology.  Whenever you feel like it. It's sort of like turning off an alarm clock that's ringing loudly. Your apology turns off the alarm.
Intent_p1: Person1 is acknowledging that their insult towards Person2 requires an apology, likening it to turning off a loud alarm clock.
Intent_p2: Person2 is acknowledging the insult and suggesting that apologizing is necessary to rectify the situation, likening it to silencing an alarm.

Dialogue:
Person1: Comical part of it is, it isn't what you want at all. In a couple of weeks you'll be looking for the nearest exit . . .  People like you spend all your life on a merry-go-round. I guess that's what makes you so dizzy.  You're always chasing after something. At least you think you are. Truth is, you're just running away.  From yourself, mostly. 'Cause you're miserable. You hate yourself. The world's full of people like you. Don't know what they want.
Person2: Do you know?
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2 is constantly chasing after things to distract themselves from their own unhappiness and self-hatred.
Intent_p2: Person2 is questioning whether Person1 knows what they want in life.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jackie... Jackie?... answer me, for God's sake, answer me.
Person2: If you knew how many times I wanted to hear you say that...
Person1: So I'm saying it...
Person2: It's too late...
Person1: What's too late about it? Look, we're not dead, are we? That's the only thing that's too late.
Person2: Lester's left Felicia. He's taking me to Acapulco on the five o'clock flight. He's asked me to marry him.
Person1: So what? You don't love him, do you? Answer me.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I don't know... Jackie?
Person2: What?
Intent_p1: Person1 is desperately trying to get Jackie to answer and confront the reality of their situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies regret and longing for hearing Person1 express their feelings earlier.

Dialogue:
Person1: ...The juice is climbin' every week.
Person2: I know the juice is climbin' -- I been workin' six months just to pay the damn interest.
Person1: Ya still light seventy.
Person2: Waits! -- Be smart. Ya don't have to break nothin' -- Here, take my coat, it's worth fifty-sixty dollars. It's yours.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2 can use their coat to cover part of the remaining amount they owe, implying a solution to reduce the debt.
Intent_p2: Person2 is offering their coat as a way to help Person1 pay off the remaining amount they owe.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yes, but no one is in control of their emotions.  that's all we have time for today...
Person2: I don't understand.
Person1: You said that you have "decided." That your... your feelings of persecution, as you put it are a "self-indulgence," and you are going to put them aside.  And get on with your job.
Person2: That's right.
Person1: And you have decided to accept... to accept this "emotion," as you put it, to the ... the "sweepings. of the Lechter case.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And you've decided to get married.  You've decided a lot of things.  But, in spite of your decisions--you are still "nagged" by feelings of despair, of failure of... you still have the nightmare, you...
Person2: What is your point?
Person1: That if decision were a useful tool, you wouldn't be here.  Why are you here...?
Person2: I..
Person1: ...yes...?
Person2: I want to do something positive...
Person1: You want some advice.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Your life has been defined by institutions.  The Orphanage where you were raised, the FBI Academy, the Bureau.  If the Institution is your life, accept it.  Ask to be reinstated on the "Drumgo" task force.  Play their game.
Person2: ...why?
Person1: Because it's the game you've chosen. That's really all we have time for.
Intent_p1: Person1 is emphasizing to Person2 the importance of accepting their emotions and decisions, and advising them to align their actions with the institutions that have defined their life.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to seek advice on how to move forward positively by accepting the institutions that have defined their life and playing the game they have chosen.

Dialogue:
Person1: Here.  Finish the job.
Person2: I'm utterly satisfied.
Person1: You're making a mistake.  Obsolete old carnivores like me are most dangerous when wounded.  You've wounded me.
Person2: More clowning!  Don't you see?
Person1: We never quit fighting until we're dead.
Person2: You'd be killing a friend.  Don't you know how much I like you?
Person1: I'm going to shoot you now.
Person2: No!
Person1: My self-respect is gone--and my soldier's honor with it.  It is now very easy for me to shoot an unarmed man.
Person2: New dignity can be yours--as a merciful man.  You can change!
Person1: Like the saber-toothed tiger.
Person2: Oh God--you're really going to kill me. HAROLD It won't hurt as much as the sting of a bumblebee.  Heaven is very much like Paradise, they say. You'll like it there.
Person2: Can I beg for mercy--on my knees?
Person1: If you want to be found that way.
Person2: What is this thing that kills me?
Person1: Man, as man was meant to be--a vengeful ape who murders.  He will soon be extinct.  It's time, it's time.
Person2: Don't shoot.
Person1: I've enjoyed being man.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to convey a sense of acceptance and resignation towards the inevitability of their actions and the nature of humanity.
Intent_p2: Person2 is pleading for mercy and trying to appeal to Person1's sense of mercy and humanity.

Dialogue:
Person1: Damn that Charlie I
Person2: It's not Charlie. It's me.
Person1: Peggy, let me ask you something.  You're not... expecting are you?
Person2: At my age? Don't be silly.
Person1: Thank God for that.
Person2: Dad.. it's not a big deal. Didn't you ever stay out all night when you were young?
Person1: Yes but I was a boy. And I still had hell to pay.
Person2: Calm down. Just listen for a minute.. Please.
Person1: All right. But this better be good.
Person2: I want to help with the family finances. I want you to buy some stocks. And gold. By 1980 gold is going to be worth eight hundred dollars an ounce. Then you sell.
Person1: Do you know how ridiculous you sound? First of all, it's illegal for U.S. citizens to buy gold. And in the second place, the price of gold is regulated by the government.
Person2: I think they're going to deregulate it.
Person1: That's your problems The more women think, the more trouble they get into.
Person2: Oh boy, that's another thing that's going to change. Who's going to think for us? Our husbands? You know, you treat Mom like a maid. It's not entirely your fault. Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.
Person1: I've heard just about enough of this lunacy! Go to your room!
Person2: Listen Dad, please. Buy IBM, buy Polaroid, buy Apple Computer. No, no. Not yet. Buy Xerox!
Person1: Evelyn, take her to her room!
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses skepticism and disapproval towards Person2's suggestions and attempts to offer financial advice, dismissing them as unrealistic and inappropriate.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to share financial advice with Person1 and challenge traditional gender roles and attitudes towards women.

Dialogue:
Person1: That's not
Person2: I'm not stupid enough to repeat your mistakes.
Person1: I guess I thought I was protecting you.
Person2: God, you're just like him! Just keep me locked away in the dark, so I can't experience anything for myself
Person1: Not all experiences are good, Bianca. You can't always trust the people you want to.
Person2: I guess I'll never know, will I?
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing regret for trying to protect Person2 by sheltering them from negative experiences.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses frustration and resentment towards Person1 for trying to control and limit their experiences, comparing them to someone who keeps them in the dark.

Dialogue:
Person1: This is Barry.
Person2: Hey it's me, what are you doing?
Person1: Hello, Karen. I'm just working.
Person2: Yeah but what are you doing?
Person1: I'm just working....I have some customers here.....
Person2: So you can't talk to me?
Person1: I have a few people here, I can't really chat right now.
Person2: "chat?" Did you just say "chat?"
Person1: Well, I can't talk though --
Person2: You just said "chat," that is so -- what are you now? "chat." I'm just calling to make sure you show up at this party tonight.
Person1: Yes, I'll be there.
Person2: Fine. You get back to chatting with your precious customers.
Person1: Ok, bye-bye.
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to politely inform Person2 that they are currently busy with customers and unable to chat, but they will attend the party later.
Intent_p2: Person2 is teasing Person1 for using the word "chat" instead of "talk" and expressing slight annoyance at not being able to have a conversation due to Person1's work.

Dialogue:
Person1: You tricked me.  I wouldn't have - I've never - never.
Person2: I know, but it wasn't all bad was it? I think you found it quite pleasurable.  Oh so soft.  So sensual.
Person1: Ahhh - no - stop - I mean Janet.  Janet.
Person2: Shush.  Janet's probably asleep by now. Do you want her to see you like this?
Person1: Like this.  Like how?  It's your fault - you're to blame.  I thought it was the real thing.
Person2: Oh come on, Brad, admit it.  It was enjoyable, wasn't it?  There's no crime in giving yourself over to pleasure.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing regret and confusion about being tricked into a situation that they found pleasurable but now feel guilty about.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to convince Person1 to acknowledge and accept the pleasure they experienced, despite feeling guilty, and to embrace the idea that indulging in pleasure is not a crime.

Dialogue:
Person1: To do my work well, I have little time for --
Person2: You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?
Person1: I usually take lunch by the River.
Person2: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.
Person1: I did not realize it was obligatory.
Person2: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing --  why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?
Person1: No, sir.
Person2: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.
Person1: Well, I --
Person2: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?
Person1: -- Eduard --
Person2: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is being advised by Person2 to change their attitude towards work and social interactions in order to advance in their career and be happier.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing concern about Person1's lack of social engagement and active interest in their work, suggesting that their attitude may be hindering their advancement and overall happiness.

Dialogue:
Person1: Hello?
Person2: We got disconnected before....
Person1: No. No. We got disconnect -- why?.....you're calling me at work....how did you get this number -- ?
Person2: See the thing is I could make it really easy on you -- I already have your credit card number, your information, address and stuff. This is so awkward asking like this, I'm sorry --
Person1: This makes me very uncomfortable.
Person2: I need help.
Person2: Should I just ask your girlfriend?  Maybe I should call back and talk to your girlfriend?
Person1: I don't have a girlfriend --
Person2: -- you said you did.
Person1: I know I did. But I don't.
Person2: You lied to me?
Person1: I didn't lie.
Person2: Why did you tell me you did, then?
Person1: This is....illegal....I'll call the police.
Person2: No you won't.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing discomfort and concern about the situation and is considering involving the police.
Intent_p2: Person2 is attempting to manipulate Person1 by threatening to disclose personal information and is dismissive of the consequences.

Dialogue:
Person1: You think I'm a fake.
Person2: I think it's what you think.
Person1: No, it isn't what I think.
Person2: Look... You made a very calculated move, and then made me feel embarrassed for responding to you. That wasn't necessary.
Intent_p1: Person1 is denying the accusation of being fake and expressing disapproval of Person2's calculated and embarrassing behavior.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing that Person1's actions were calculated and made them feel embarrassed unnecessarily.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're crazy.
Person2: But only on purpose, Tommy.
Person1: This is nice. I mean it.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing genuine appreciation for the situation or conversation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is playfully acknowledging that they may act crazy intentionally, possibly as a way to bring humor or excitement to the situation.

Dialogue:
Person1: Stay near the house, for Christ's sake- someone's killing people. I have to be out of my mind to be doing this, you know.
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's great!
Person1: One of the reasons I love you, Marty, is that you're almost as crazy as I am. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay? Just bright colors. Can you tell the difference?
Person2: Yeah... sure.
Person1: Save this one for last.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 to stay near the house and not set off anything dangerous, expressing concern about the situation.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies a willingness to engage in risky or dangerous behavior.

Dialogue:
Person1: Shut up a second...
Person2: Okay.  Pretty petty party, isn't it, pal?
Person1: I made one rule for myself when this started and I realized I was going to take a lot from you people because of being from sports...
Person2: And the rule was...
Person1: Never to pretend to know more than I did.
Person2: Can you name all the members of the Cabinet?
Person1: Okay, let's drop it.  I didn't mean I'd take a test for you -- I mean if that came up in conversation I'd...
Person2: We're conversing...Oh my, the names of the entire Cabinet has slipped my mind.  What are they?
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to explain that they made a rule for themselves not to pretend to know more than they actually do, especially when it comes to topics like politics.
Intent_p2: Person2 is playfully challenging Person1's rule of not pretending to know more than they do by asking them to name all the members of the Cabinet.

Dialogue:
Person1: I don't, I don't remember. What do I owe you?
Person2: Uh, eleven twenty-five.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asking how much money they owe Person2 because they cannot remember the amount.
Intent_p2: Person2 is informing Person1 of the amount they owe.

Dialogue:
Person1: Sir, I took the call.  It's my case.
Person2: Edmund, you don't want it and you can't have it.
Person1: Yes, I do, sir.
Person2: It's mine.  I'll make you my second in command.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their desire to handle the case and is willing to accept a promotion to second in command.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting their authority and offering Person1 a promotion to be their second in command instead of taking the case.

Dialogue:
Person1: Your girl's a menace.  Here, givver this... Getter off the street and teach her some humility.
Person2: I don't think so...
Person1: Well, then, you have insufficient information.  I'm grateful for this opportunity to set you straight.
Intent_p1: Person1 is suggesting that Person2's girlfriend is causing trouble and needs to be taken off the streets and taught some humility.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing disagreement with Person1's suggestion to take their girl off the street and teach her humility.

Dialogue:
Person1: You're wrong.
Person2: Am I...?  Would you be willing to plant corroborative evidence on a suspect you knew was guilty in order to ensure an indictment?
Person1: Dudley, we've been over this.
Person2: Answer yes or no.
Person1: I... No.
Person2: Would you be willing to rig crime scene evidence to support a prosecuting attorney's working hypothesis...?  Yes or no, Edmund.
Person1: No.
Person2: Would you be willing to beat confessions out of suspects you knew to be guilty?
Person1: No.
Person2: Would you be willing to shoot hardened criminals in the back to offset the chance --
Person1: No.
Person2: Then for God's sake, don't be a detective.  Stick to assignments where you won't have to make those choices.  Patrol, Internal Affairs, but not the Bureau.
Person1: I know you mean well, Dudley, but I don't need to do it the way you did.  Or my father.
Person2: At least get rid of the glasses. I can't think of one Bureau man who wears them.
Intent_p1: Person1 is asserting their ethical stance against planting evidence, rigging crime scene evidence, using violence to extract confessions, or shooting criminals in the back, and expressing a desire to pursue a different path in law enforcement.
Intent_p2: Person2 is advising Person1 to consider a different career path within law enforcement that does not involve compromising their ethics or principles.

Dialogue:
Person1: Did they give you a rough time?
Person2: No.  You bastard. You knew they'd come back.
Person1: No, I didn't,  Does Albert Swift still live over the ferry?
Person2: Get knotted.
Person1: All right. All right. I want to square things with you first.
Person2: Oh yes? How?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to address a past issue and reconcile with Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express skepticism and distrust towards Person1's attempt to reconcile and make amends.

Dialogue:
Person1: Jesus Christ, Miles. Get out!
Person2: I want to go home now.
Person1: You've been divorced for two years already. People move on. She has! It's like you enjoy self-pity. Makes you feel special or something.
Person2: Is she bringing him to the wedding?
Person1: What do you think?
Person2: You drop this bombshell on me. Why didn't you tell me before?
Person1: Because I knew you'd freak out and probably get so depressed you wouldn't even come on this trip. But then I figured here would be the best place to tell you. We're here to forget about all that shit. We're here to party!
Person2: I'm going to be a pariah. Everyone's just going to be holding their breath to see if I'm going to get drunk and make a scene. Plus Tony Levin?
Person1: No, no, no. It's cool. I talked to Victoria. She's cool. Everyone's cool.
Person2: You've all been talking about it? Behind my back? Talking about it?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to encourage Person2 to move on from his divorce, reminding him that everyone is supportive and wants him to enjoy the trip and not dwell on the past.
Intent_p2: Person2 is feeling overwhelmed and anxious about the situation, questioning why they were not informed earlier and expressing concerns about being judged and scrutinized by others.

Dialogue:
Person1: Why do you look at me like that?
Person2: I did not know you were so beautiful... and --
Person1: And then --?
Person2: No irony. You're so appealing -- so soft -- so tired. I feel like taking you in my arms and not letting anything more happen to you -- ever.
Person1: And -- and --
Person2: How tired you are!
Person1: Yes -- tired...
Person2: So alone.
Person1: Alone. All alone.  Oh, you strange -- strange creature.
Person2: You mustn't talk Russian to me.
Person1: Strange man...
Person2: Am I quite strange to you?
Person1: Not quite strange now. It is as if I had been expecting you. You know, once when the Grand Duke was alive, I found a man hiding in my room -- a young officer --
Person2: And...?
Person1: He disappeared. Later he was found dead.
Person2: I never knew it was so dangerous to hide in a woman's room when she's alone.
Person1: Go away. Who are you --?
Person2: A man who could love -- that is all, who has forgotten everything else for you.
Person1: You could love me. It is so long since I have heard that word. Nobody has loved me for a long time. It is so icy-cold to be famous. One is so cruelly alone. How is it that you -- Let me look at you. Your hands. Your eyes. Why could you love me?
Person2: I saw you just now -- then I saw you cry -- and now I see you in the mirror -- Grusinskaya...
Person1: Grusinskaya... Oh -- oh if you knew how I slaved and slaved for Grusinskaya -- for the success of Grusinskaya -- for the triumph of Grusinskaya... and what is she now? Just someone who has found that on the day success ceases life ceases -- Are you listening to me -- Do you understand? -- I want you to understand.
Person2: Yes -- I do understand.
Person1: I think you must go now -- the key is on the floor.
Person2: I'm not going -- You know I'm not going -- Let me stay here?
Person1: I want to be alone.
Person2: That is not so -- you don't want to be alone.
Person1: I want to be alone --
Person2: No -- You don't want to be alone at all -- You were in despair before -- If I left you, you'd feel worse than you did before, You must not be alone -- You mustn't cry -- you must forget... Tell me that I can stay with you -- tell me.
Person1: Just for a minute then.
Intent_p1: Person1 expresses vulnerability and loneliness, seeking understanding and connection from Person2.
Intent_p2: Person2 expresses a deep emotional connection and desire to care for Person1, reassuring them that they are not alone and offering comfort and support.

Dialogue:
Person1: I thought you were through with it!
Person2: We cannot stay here and allow ourselves to be destroyed.  You can work with us.  An organized plan of escape must be devised first.  Could you see anything?  You want to leave.  You're not like them.  You must have left something, or someone.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing surprise and frustration that Person2 is still involved in a situation they believed was over.
Intent_p2: Person2 is urging Person1 to join them in devising an organized plan of escape because they cannot stay in their current situation and risk being destroyed, suggesting that Person1 may have a reason to leave and not be like the others.

Dialogue:
Person1: What are the notes?
Person2: "Mad about the boy."
Person1: Norma, I can't take it.  You've bought me enough.
Person2: Shut up.  I'm rich.  I'm richer than all this new Hollywood trash. I've got a million dollars.
Person1: Keep it.
Person2: I own three blocks downtown. I have oil in Bakersfield -- pumping, pumping, pumping. What's it for but to buy us anything we want.
Person1: Cut out that us business.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing discomfort with Person2's lavish spending and materialistic attitude.
Intent_p2: Person2 is asserting their wealth and power over Person1 by highlighting their financial success and ability to buy anything they desire.

Dialogue:
Person1: Are you sure?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: It just seems...kind of weird.
Person2: Why?
Person1: I don't know.
Person2: Nicole, I'm just going to pack all this stuff and give it to the church for charity.  Don't feel bad. Unless you feel strange about wearing it.
Person1: No.  I mean, I remember Mrs. Ansel wearing some of this stuff, but...I don't feel funny about that.  I really liked her.
Person2: And she really liked you.  She would've given you all this if she'd outgrown it, or...
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing uncertainty and hesitation about the situation involving the clothing items being given to charity.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to reassure Person1 that there is no need to feel guilty or strange about accepting the items for charity, as they were meant to be given away by someone who cared about Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: Game's over. Last chance to get out of this without a prison sentence.  You're not good enough to beat me, you little shit.
Person2: Yeah, maybe I'm not. But we are, you asshole.
Person1: Give it up! Just give it up.
Intent_p1: Person1 is warning Person2 that they have one final opportunity to avoid a prison sentence and belittling their abilities in a confrontation.
Intent_p2: Person2 is expressing confidence in their team's ability to succeed together against Person1.

Dialogue:
Person1: I...
Person2: Get Mitch Cohn on the phone in New York, tell him she's breaking her contract and we're very up...
Person1: I...
Person2: We're very upset with her.  Get someone to double for her, her tits, the tits scene, call L.A.  I want to see some pictures of the women's tits.  Of their tits.
Person1: I'm very sorry I...
Person2: You're very sorry, you passive aggressive, son-of-a-bitch...can we replace him?
Intent_p1: Person1's intent is to apologize for the situation and express regret.
Intent_p2: Person2's intent is to express frustration and anger towards Person1 for their perceived lack of action and to consider replacing them.

Dialogue:
Person1: Every single time we plan something, you're late!
Person2: It was just a few minutes, Alex.
Person1: You always do this. It's disrespectful to my time.
Person2: And you never acknowledge when I do make an effort. We both have things to work on.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing frustration about Person2's consistent lateness and feeling disrespected.
Intent_p2: Person2 is highlighting the need for both individuals to acknowledge each other's efforts and work on improving their punctuality.

Dialogue:
Person1: You all went out for dinner last night and didn't even think to invite me?
Person2: We thought you were busy with your project, Sam.
Person1: That's not the point. I constantly feel left out of group plans.
Person2: We genuinely didn't mean to exclude you.
Person1: Nobody cares about me. Maybe I'm just not meant to be a part of this group.
Person2: That's not true, Sam. We value you. We just need to be more considerate in the future.
Intent_p1: Person1 is expressing feelings of being consistently left out of group plans and feeling unappreciated by their friends.
Intent_p2: Person2 reassures Person1 that they are valued in the group and acknowledges the need for more consideration in including them in future plans.

Dialogue:
Person1: Miss Kreutz, please... I'm gonna have to ask you to keep your voice down.
Person2: All the papers -- all the papers they asked for -- I brought all the papers --
Person1: Miss Kreutz, excuse me, but you entered into a fraudulent marriage in an effort to circumvent the immigration laws of the United States --
Person2: You only know that because I told you!  Ask the case officer -- find his name -- it's on the papers -- I told him all this myself! --
Person1: -- it's not the source of the information that's important here --
Person2: -- I paid this guy -- I paid him four thousand dollars -- my last four thousand dollars to marry me, okay? -- I told this to the case officer last week...  ...here -- Mr. Thomas.  I told Mr. Thomas I didn't know this guy was already married -- I admitted this!
Person1: -- Miss Kreutz, please --
Person2: -- I'm the one that got ripped off! -- not you -- not the United States government -- me -- I'm the one being ripped off!
Person1: So now you're asking for a student visa?
Intent_p1: Person1 is trying to calm down Person2 and address the issue of her fraudulent marriage to circumvent immigration laws.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to explain that they were deceived into a fraudulent marriage and are now the one being taken advantage of.

Dialogue:
Person1: Yes -- what is it?
Person2: Open the door.  It's me.
Person1: Go away -- I'm busy.
Person2: I know what you're doing in there.
Person1: Don't be ridiculous and go away -- I'm busy working.
Person2: Where is Madame Trillaud?
Person1: How should I know.  Ask Roquier -- he's cleaning her dress.
Person2: What are you doing in there?
Person1: Oh -- now, this is absolutely ridiculous!  If you don't want to be humiliated in front of your guests, you will return to the table at once.
Person2: Will you be joining us, soon?
Person1: I will be there in five minutes.  Go back to your guests.
Person2: Five minutes.
Person1: Yes!!
Person2: Five minutes.
Person1: Goodbye.
Intent_p1: Person1 is frustrated and trying to get Person2 to leave them alone so they can continue working without interruption.
Intent_p2: Person2 is trying to subtly hint to Person1 to join the guests at the table soon.

Dialogue:
Person1: He's got your prick in his back pocket, son, and you're standing naked in the display window of Macy's. He's using you. Only you're too blind to see it.
Person2: No, what I see is a jealous old machinist who can't stand that his son's become more successful than himself.
Person1: What you see, son, is a man who never measured success by the size of a man's wallet.
Person2: That's because you never had the guts to go out into the world and stake your claim.
Person1: Boy, if that's what you think, I must've really screwed up my job as a father.
Intent_p1: Person1's statement implies that they feel like they have failed as a father because their son believes they did not have the courage to pursue success outside of material wealth.
Intent_p2: Person2's statement implies that Person1's definition of success is different from his own and suggests that Person1 may have regrets about his parenting.

Dialogue:
Person1: You can do it, Sal.
Person2: No. No, no.
Person1: Sal... listen to me, Sal! You have to do it.
Person2: I want to go home, Merle.
Person1: You have to think about this, Sal. Listen to me, Sal! You have to think about this.
Person2: This is horrible!
Person1: Listen to me, Sal. If you don't do it they'll put you in the pit. If they put you in the pit, Sal, you're gonna die... Sal, do you understand?
Person2: Merle, I wanna go home!
